[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	The set is one of those warehousey sort of places, where 
	the merchandise is behind the assistant who wears a 
	brown warehouse coat. Lots of blue plastic trays with 
	pro-ey looking bits and pieces.'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Stephen enters with a list.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Help you, sir?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Um, a dozen grollings please.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Flushed or galvanised?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Flushed.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right. That be it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A copper flange-pipe, braced, two jubilees, seven
		nipples ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Greased?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Greased nipples, yeah. Five olive-spantles, jigged
		and onioned.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Twelve or seventeen mill?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Twelve. Metre of fleeling wire, coaxial, twenty UJ's
		and a parping couplet.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Male or female?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Male. No, second thoughts, one of each.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Do you want the parping couplet standing proud?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No, embarrassed I think.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	An embarrassed parping couplet. That it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Two rolls of spowling tape.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Double-sided?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Do they do single-sided?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Only in Viennese lengths.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Better go with double then. Six sheets of gruddock
		paper.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Parkinised?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Nearly there. Four felching pens and a bevelled
		spill-trunion.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Only got one felching pen left. Got some frotting
		pencils though.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Will they do?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, you know the thrush-plate?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yeah.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	You can use a frotting pencil on that, rude to the
		look-out valve on the fumpspoke and you can cut
		out the felching altogether. As long as you rim the
		satchel-arm properly first.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Right. Four frotting pencils then.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	So, that's it, is it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yup.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You've already got a clip-jawed double lock brace
		have you?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Do you reckon I'll need one?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, are you going straight or curved?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Straight, then curved.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ah. Well you should be all right then, as long as
		you remember to suck the clenching pin tight to
		the arc thrust.
		Stephen slaps Hugh in the face.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	How dare you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Sorry.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
		(As woman) I had shares in
			Gas, Electricity, Water, the lot.
			But then the government sold
			them all.
	'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen is in the drawing room of a stately home. He 
	plays an old aristocratic dowager called Rosina, Lady 
	Madding.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I live here alone in what, when I was a girl, used
		to be called the Dower House. I suppose I am
		technically a dowager, though my son Rufus,
		the fourth earl, is not yet married. I love the
		country, it's very peaceful here. I am surrounded
		by photographs of my past. On the piano I have
		a photograph of myself dancing with David, the
		Prince of Wales - later of course Edward the
		Eighth and subsequent Duke of Windsor. David
		was a very bad dancer, always trod on one's toes
		and I remember he once crushed the metatarsal
		bones in the foot of a girlfriend of mine - discreet
		lesbianism was fashionable at the time.
		Here's a photograph of Noel Coward - darling
		Noel as we always called him. He was a very witty
		man, you know - it's a side of him not many
		people are perhaps aware of. I recall an occasion
		when I came out onto the dance-floor of Mario's
		in Greek Street wearing a very daring frock,
		very low-cut, a frock that revealed more of my
		decolletage than was then considered proper -
		now of course I dare say it would raise nothing
		more than an eyebrow - but at the time it was
		very wicked. I came onto the floor and darling
		Noel came up to me and said "Rosina" - he always
		used to call me Rosina - it is my name, you must
		understand. "Rosina," he said in that voice of his,
		"Rosina, where did you find such an alluringly
		high-cut body?" This was Noel's little way, you see.
		The portrait above the fireplace was made
		when I was in Paris - Claude my husband was
		Ambassador in the late 20s and I used to hold
		very literary parties at the embassy - Plum and
		Duff Cooper, Scott and Garrett Fitzgerald,
		darling Geoffrey Chaucer of course, Adolf Hitler
		and Unity Mitford, Gertrude Stein and Alice
		B.Topless, Radclyffe Hall and Angela Brazil -
		they could always be relied upon to attend. And
		of course O. Henry James Joyce Carey Grant. I
		remember F.E.Smith, later Lord Birkenhead
		of course, (Pointing, but we stay on Stephen) that's
		his picture there, just below the dartboard,
		F.E. used to say "All the world and his live-in
		lover go to Rosina's parties" which pleased me
		very much. Later when Claude and I went to
		India to take up the Vice-regency I met Gandhi
		with whom I used to play French cricket - he
		was awfully good at cricket, as a matter of fact,
		Claude always used to say "what the loin-cloth
		trade gained, the wicket-keeping trade lost."
		Pandit Nerhu was very impressive too, though if
		Edwina Mountbatten is to be believed his length
		was too variable for him ever to enter the ranks
		of Indian leg-spin immortals. The large bronze
		statue of the nude male which stands on top of
		the synthesizer is of Herbert Morrison the Cabinet
		Minister. I use it to hang my bracelets on when
		I'm playing at the keyboard now. I spend a lot of
		time here in this room, remembering the past.
		Silly Poles Hartley, L.P.Hartley, you know, once
		said that the past is a foreign country, but I don't
		agree. The food was better for a start, and the
		people didn't smell. People often tell me I was
		one of a spoilt generation, rich, beautiful, idle,
		parasitical. It is true that I had every conceivable
		luxury lavished upon me during my life, met
		many famous and influential people, saw many
		exciting places and never did anything more
		taxing than organise large house-parties. But
		you know, despite that, if I had my time over
		again I wouldn't change a thing. Regrets? A
		few. I shouldn't have let dear T.E.Lawrence
		borrow my motorbicycle. I'm tired now. Let
		me rest.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Now Kenneth Baker, it seems to
		me, is a perfect argument for why
		one should always try and kill
		Kenneth Baker.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'Caption', 'text': '
	"The Rhodes Boysons Hour"
		
	Stephen and Hugh are both dressed and made-up 
	to look like Rhodes Boyson the popular and absurd 
	Conservative member of parliament.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hello there, I am Rhodes Boyson.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Good evening. My name is Rhodes Boyson.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	We are the Rhodes Boysons. And this is our hour.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	This is very much our hour. An hour in which
		phrases ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Certainly phrases ... phrases yes, certainly.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Phrases like "centres of excellence" will be much in
		evidence.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You will find, in this our hour, that phrases
		comparable to, congruent with and exigent under,
		"centres of excellence" will be, to some extent,
		utilised.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And by a centre of excellence we mean ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	We mean, primarily ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Primarily that is ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A centre that is ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	By and large.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	By-ly and large-ly.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Excellent. In some regard.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	In some regard or other.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	In some, or other, regard.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	That is what we mean when we say "centre of
		excellence". I hope that's cleared that one up.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Absolutely. Another phrase meaning "centre of
		excellence" might be "school that is quite good".
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	That is substantially correct in essence. A centre
		of excellence is a school that is quite good. But the
		phrase "school that is quite good" doesn't sound
		nearly as ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ludicrous?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Nearly as ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Pompous?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	The phrase "school that is quite good" doesn't
		sound as ludicrous or pompous as the phrase
		"centre of excellence".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And for that reason ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And that reason alone.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	We will be using the phrase "centre of excellence"
		throughout our hour.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Our hour.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Another word that can't be stressed enough is
		"standards".
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Standards as in "standards of excellence", moral
		standards, standards of accountability.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I like that one. Standards of accountability.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Rolls off the tongue, doesn't it? Standards of
		accountability.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	So for the time being, we'll leave you with those
		two. "Centres of excellence".
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's centres of excellence.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And "Standards of accountability".
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Standards of accountability. Ooh, I do like that
		one. I shall be using that in bed tonight. Standards
		of accountability. Lovely.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Really quite lovely.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Perfectly lovely.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	So until the next time, it's goodbye from Rhodes
		Boyson.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	And it's goodbye from Rhodes Boyson.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Goodbye.

'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(As woman) If you lick the top bit,
		very slowly, you get arrested.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'A German castle. Stephen, as Major Donaldson, is 
	slumped over a desk. Hugh is looking at a painting on 
	the wall, his back turned towards Stephen.'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Stephen stirs to some kind of conciousness.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Still not looking at Stephen) Ah, we return to some
		form of consciousness, Major.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Who ... whirr ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	You must forgive the rough methods of my
		colleagues. They are barbarians, barbarians. No
		finesse, it grieves me to say.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Where the hell am I?
		
	Hugh is inspecting another painting.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	You admire Matisse, Major? Such bold strokes of
		the brush, such masterly control. What were you
		doing so far in front of your lines, Major? What
		was the nature of your operation?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Donaldson, Eric, Major. Serial number 46589320.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Come, come, Major Donaldson, you can do better
		than that, you know. Really so much better.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's all you'll get out of me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(Still hasn't faced Stephen) Such a pity our two
		nations were ever at war. We have a great deal in
		common you know. (Swings round) Tell me please
		when exactly is planned your invasion of France?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(Looking down) Do you think I know and do you
		think if I did know (He looks up) I'd ... tell ...
		you ... oh my God!
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes what is the matter please?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You ... I can't believe it!
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	You are not believing what, please?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You! You're so ... so beautiful!
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What are you saying?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I can't ... this is ... oh my God, this is it!
		Who'd've believed it? Here? Now? You're just the
		most fantastic, the loveliest creature I've ever set
		eyes on.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Don't play games with me, Major Donaldson. I'm
		not very good at them.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Games? Games? This is no game! This is the
		reallest thing that's ever happened to me. I just
		don't ... where the hell have you been all my life,
		you fabulous darling?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Now look ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh God there's so much I want to know ... your
		name, I don't even know what he's called ... God,
		we've so much lost time to make up for.
		
	Stephen turns round a name card on Hugh's desk.
	It reads in Gothic upper case "Oberleutnant Friedrich 
	von Stoltz".
		
		Friedrich! Yes, Friedrich! it suits you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Have you taken leave of your senses?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes! Yes, Friedie, I have! For the first time in my
		life I have taken leave of my senses, and I love it!
		Did anyone ever tell you you have the sweetest,
		silliest little nose ... and the biggest bluest eyes?
		
	Hugh turns angrily away.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I give you one last warning, Major Donaldson!
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Get that arse! That has got to be the cutest little
		bum ever!
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Furious by now) No, now this is enough! Enough
		you hear?! Perhaps you are trying on me some of
		your English senses of humour, but I tell you ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	And the accent, it's just so dreamy! 
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	WHEN IS PLANNED THE INVASION?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh, who cares about the stupid little invasion,
		Friedrich, honey-puss? July the third, three beach-
		heads on Normandy codenamed Omaha, Utah
		and Nebraska, I think. But what does that matter?
		What matters is that we've found each other.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Normandy?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Normandy. Now, don't you think that deserves a
		kiss?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, maybe just a little one.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	There was a very famous
		writer once, I can't actually
		remember who it was, but
		he was once asked by a hotel
		porter for his name, and he said
		"G.K.Chesterton". I think it
		might have been Oscar Wilde.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "
	Hugh enters Control's office. Stephen appears to be 
	taking his own pulse."}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hello, Control. (No reply) Control? Are you all
		right? You appear to be taking your pulse.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I am a Russian spy, Tony. That's what I am.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I beg your pardon?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I plan to overthrow the Queen.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Control, this is a bit of a surprise. All the more
		so because you're actually the head of the British
		Intelligence.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I aim to undermine the entire Western way of life.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Mmm. Before you do that, I'll go and telephone
		the relevant authorities. And as a precaution,
		please don't open any more letters.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No, it's all right Murchison. I'm not really a
		Russian spy.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Now Control. You mustn't say that just to spare
		me the paperwork.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No honestly, Tony, I'm really not a Russian spy.
		And you were right, by the way. I was taking
		my pulse.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I thought as much. Because you were gripping
		your wrist lightly but firmly and counting to
		yourself.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You see, our American counterparts have invented
		a new machine called a lie-detector, that let's you
		know when people are telling you fibs.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Surely that would be rather useful for people in
		our line of work, Control?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Exactly, Tony. The machine works on the well-
		known scientific principle that when someone's
		telling you a fib, their pulse speeds up.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Gosh, Control, how incredibly ingenious but at the
		same time how quite simple.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sadly however, these machines are rather
		expensive to buy.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh dear. Our American counterparts do often
		seem to have lots more money to spend than we
		do, don't they, Control?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes, but what they have in money, I like to think
		we make up for in British know-how.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm not quite following, Control.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well, Tony, at a fraction of the cost I have come up
		with this lie-detector.
		
	Indicates (stop-watch).
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	A stop-watch, of course! It cuts out the need for
		expensive and cumbersome equipment.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	When I told you I was a Russian spy, I was telling
		a deliberate fib.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ah. You wanted to see if your pulse got faster?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's right.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Did it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh dear. If your pulse didn't speed up, that must
		mean ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes. When I said I was a Russian spy, I must have
		been telling the truth.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Mm. So on the very first try of this technique
		you've discovered that you, the Head of British
		Intelligence, are a Soviet agent.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's right. And Tony?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Control?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	The 9.50 that it cost me to buy that stop-watch
		turns out to have been money well spent.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Gosh, Control. The implications of your discovery
		are considerable.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Aren't they, Murchison? The Minister will be ever
		so pleased.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Mmm. Don't you think we ought to test the
		technique again, just to make sure?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Good idea. We don't want to go round boasting
		that we've discovered that I'm a top level Russian
		spy unless we're absolutely certain.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	My thoughts exactly, Control.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	All right, Tony, you tell me a fib, and I'll see if your
		pulse goes up.
		
	Stephen takes Hugh's pulse.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Hmm. Let's see if I can think of something that
		isn't true. Oh yes, I know. My name is Susan
		Donovan.
		
	Pause. Stephen counts and then withdraws his hand.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well, that seems to prove it.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Really?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes, Susan, really.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Mm. (Pause) Control?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes, Susan?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Why don't we go back to our old way?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You mean ... ?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes. The good old British Secret Service method
		of finding out if someone is telling you a fib or not.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	All right. You first. Is your name Tony Murchison?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(Holding up hand) Yes. Cub's Honour.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	My turn.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Are you a Russian spy?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I am not a Russian spy, cross my heart and
		hope to die.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Phew!
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Glad we're all sorted out again.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Me too! You know what, Control?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What, Tony?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm going to bring you a cup of nice coffee
		now ...
		
	Makes to leave. Stops and smiles at Control.
		
		... and that's the truth!
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Boh!
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(As woman) I've always loved
		that story.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh is on a couch. Stephen sits beside him'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So, Mr Sedelmayer, you believe yourself to be
		anally retentive?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Not half.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Not half. No, I imagine not half. Now
		anal retentiveness is a complex condition,
		Mr Sedelmayer. What gave you the idea that you
		were suffering from this problem?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	A book.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A book? Well, well, well, well, well. A book on
		psychiatry?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	First World War Biplanes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	First World War Biplanes. It was a book on First
		World War Biplanes that led you to believe that
		you were anally retentive?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's right.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Mm. I must say I can't pretend to understand you
		- not without going to Drama School and taking
		an expensive course of lessons in how to pretend
		to understand someone.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well it's like this. I'd just come in from the garden
		for a cup of tea and ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Please, Mr Sedelmayer, I'm not a machine.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I beg your pardon?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A little slower, if you please.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh right. I sat down on this chair ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well, get on with it.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right. I sat down on this chair.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	This chair?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No, no. The chair in my kitchen. And as I sat
		down I noticed that on the chair was this book all
		about First World War Biplanes and I sat down
		and had a cup of tea, nice cup of tea, very nice,
		the tea wasn't the problem, no sir, the problem
		was that when I got up I noticed that the book
		wasn't there.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It wasn't anywhere, you see. It had vanished.
		That's when I realised that I'd retained it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You'd retained it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Correct.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Anally?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Of course anally. Of course. What other
		explanation could there be?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You tell me, Mr Sedelmayer.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	All right. Now this chair. Describe it to me.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh you know, a chair. A kitchen chair. Made in
		Hungary.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A Hungarian kitchen chair. My oh my. And where
		is this chair now?
		Pause.
		Where is this chair now?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Isn't it obvious? I sat down again, you see, because
		I was shocked by the disappearance of the book on
		First World War Biplanes, and when I got up ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No chair?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Vanished. Gone.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Retained ... by you ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Anally.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Anally. Yes. I see. So the disappearance of
		a book on First World War Biplanes and a
		Hungarian kitchen chair have forced you to the
		conclusion ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh they're not all.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh lordy Belgrano. You mean there's more?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Much more. Look out of the window.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Mr Sedelmayer, I am a man of science, I haven't
		time to look out of windows.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Please.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Very well.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I came here today by car.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I've never been one for public transport. Too
		many germs. I came here today in a blue Vauxhall
		Carlton, purchased from Howden, the Used Car
		Dealers, for a pretty sum ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	On the Bardon Road?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's it. Big place, with a lot of cars. They're
		dear, mind, but they give you peace of mind.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	And you can't put a price on that.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, 6,299 was the price they managed to
		put on it.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Right, yes. Good, excellent. So you came in your
		Carlton, parked ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Exactly. I parked, got out of the vehicle, turned
		round to effect the security procedure ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	To wit ... ?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	To wit, locking the door ... and what do you
		think met my gaze?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Nothing?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You've got it in one. The blue Vauxhall Carlton
		had, in effect, been retained by me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I see.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	So I suppose what I'm asking in my stumbling,
		hopeless fashion is, what can I do?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well it wouldn't hurt to take the bus just once ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No, no, no. You misunderstand me for comic
		effect. I mean what am I to do about my anal
		retentiveness?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well now, Mr Sedelmayer, I could lie to you. It
		would be ridiculously easy just to tell you a lot of
		lies ... in fact that's what I think I'll do. You're
		fine, Mr Sedelmayer, you've got absolutely nothing
		to worry about.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Goodness me, that's a relief.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	And if you're worried about your car -
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Not particularly, it was insured.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh that's all right then. I was going to suggest a
		couple of pints of kaolin and morphine and a bowl
		of prunes, but if it's insured ...
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen plays Colin Essdale, a drama producer, Hugh 
	plays a complaining woman called Mary Barratt. The 
	presenter is called Elspeth.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well I thought it was disgusting. The whole thing
		was disgusting.
'}, {'speaker': 'Elspeth', 'text': '
	Yes, did ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	There was no warning of what was in store, none
		whatever ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Elspeth', 'text': '
	To be fair, the ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And for goodness sake what about my children?
		No thought was given to this at all.
'}, {'speaker': 'Elspeth', 'text': '
	Did your children see the ... ?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No they didn't. They didn't see it. But only thanks
		to the purest good fortune that they don't happen
		to have been born yet, otherwise I dread to think
		what damage may have been caused. It was simply
		disgusting.
"}, {'speaker': 'Elspeth', 'text': '
	Yes, the ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Simply disgusting.
		
	Pause. Elspeth thinks that Hugh has stopped.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Elspeth', 'text': '
	Turning to you Mr ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Simply disgusting.
'}, {'speaker': 'Elspeth', 'text': '
	Mm. Colin Essdale, as the producer, what do ... ?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(Nodding caringly) Mm. Mm. Mm. Mm. This is
		obviously difficult ... mm ... perhaps it would
		help if I explained that I couldn't give a flying toss
		about Mrs Barratt or her feeble views.
"}, {'speaker': 'Elspeth', 'text': '
	Er, well the ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I beg your pardon?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Now, if you don't mind, or even if you do ... I
		have only an estimated 45 years left on this planet
		and I don't propose to waste a further second of
		them talking to a confused old gasbag like you.
"}, {'speaker': 'Elspeth', 'text': '
	Well, on the other hand ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(Unhooks tie-mike a la John Nott) So, I'm off to
		see a colleague about making a programme which I
		fully hope will irritate you and your half-wit friends
		even more than the last one. Bye!
		Exit Stephen.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Elspeth', 'text': "
	So, Mrs Barratt are you satisfied with what
		you've heard?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well not really, no.
'}, {'speaker': 'Elspeth', 'text': '
	Tough. (Shouting off) A last word from you,
		Mr Essdale?
		Stephen re-enters with drink.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Pim-hole.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The people of Berlin are doing
		very exciting things with the city
		at the moment. Basically they
		had the idea of just knocking it
		through into one.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I was just sorting through my grandfather's old
		hairdriers the other day, when I came across this,
		wedged in the filter of an old Pifco Easy Tress
		Ultramatic.
		
		Holds up a small piece of paper.
		
		It's a letter addressed to my grandfather from
		the then Minister of Housing, Ernest Dalloway,
		later of course Lord Dalloway of Spalding. I'll
		read it to you, if I may. "Your letter to the Home
		Secretary has been passed on to me, as Minister in
		charge of urban development. I dream of covering
		your upturned face with a thousand burning
		kisses ..." and there's a bit more like that ...
		but, oh yes here we are ... this is the good bit,
		"I would direct your attention to Section 17 of the
		Housing Act (Urban) 1916, paragraph 5: "Where
		a local authority has given no other sanction," you
		furious ball of shining beauty, blah, blah blah, "the
		entitlement to grants under the scheme will come
		mandatorily into operation," please, please let me
		stroke your thigh. I hope this answers your enquiry
		in the matter of 14 Stanshall Avenue, I yearn to
		drink clarifed butter from your armpits, etc etc
		etc Ernest Dalloway." Fascinating little glimpse of
		history, there, I think.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ladies and gentlemen, many of you have expressed
		the worry that some of what Hugh and I do in
		this show is physically very dangerous, and have
		asked whether or not we ever use stuntmen in the
		performance of our sketches.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well the answer is basically that Stephen and I do
		all our own stunts.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	All our own stunts.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Every single one.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And almost none of our own acting.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's right. It's not widely known, but acting is in
		fact an incredibly dangerous thing to do ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Incredibly dangerous, and for insurance reasons
		we have been forbidden from delivering all but the
		simplest lines.
		
	Cut to Stephen and Hugh "in performance" while their 
	voices continue off ...
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Voice-over) Take for example this sketch, that
		we're about to record now. It's called "The
		Adventures Of Colin The Serving Hatch", and
		it begins with me diving through a plate-glass
		window, with my bottom on fire.
		
	Hugh dives through a window, trousers ablaze.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Voice-over) Those of you who are doing this sketch
		for A-level will know that the next thing is for me
		to smash Hugh in the face with a cricket bat ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Voice-over) Whereupon I crash through a wall and
		fall on to some iron railings.
		
	In vision, the relevant actions can be seen. Somebody 
	shouts "cut" and Stephen steps in and addresses 
	the camera.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Now comes the really dangerous bit - the
		first line. And to do this line, we've drafted in
		Alan Witheridge, who has almost twenty years
		experience of delivering lines like this one. Alan
		is going to "double" for Hugh at this point in the
		sketch, and say the line "I'm so sorry, I thought
		you were my brother."
		
	We can see Alan preparing for the line. Kneepads etc.
	Stephen goes over to interview him.
		
		Alan, how's it going?
'}, {'speaker': 'Alan', 'text': '
	Fine thanks, Stephen. Just putting the final
		touches to the preparation.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Are you nervous at a time like this?
'}, {'speaker': 'Alan', 'text': "
	Not nervous, no. If you've done your homework,
		which I think I have, there should be no problem.
		Anyway, we'll see.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well Alan, the very best of luck.
		
	Alan takes up his position in the set. A voice shouts
	"stand by".

		(Voice-over) Just to remind you that Alan is now
		going to try and say the line, "I'm so sorry I
		thought you were my brother." Fingers crossed.
		
	A voice shouts "action" and Alan begins.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Alan', 'text': "
	I'm so sorry, I thought ...
		
	Alan explodes and people run in with fire extinguishers.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well, a lucky escape for Hugh there.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Good evening and welcome to "Realising I've
		Given The Wrong Directions To". Tonight I shall
		be Realising I've Given The Wrong Directions to
		Rabbi Michael Leibovitz. Sadly, Rabbi Leibovitz
		is unable to be with us tonight. Till next time,
		bye bye.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Margaret Thatcher is the best
		thing that's ever happened to this
		country.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	A hotel bar at the foot of Ben Enormous. Stephen is the 
	bartender, with a ludicrously long beard. Hugh is a git.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh she's beautiful, isn't she?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	She?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The mountain.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ah.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I always think of the mountain as "she". To me, the
		mountain will always be "she".
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I know what you mean.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Do you? Yes, I think perhaps you do.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	But to me, you see, the mountain is an "it".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	An "it".
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	"It", yes. To me, the mountain has always had an
		"itty" sort of quality.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Interesting.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I think of my wife as a "she".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Is that right?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh yes. I always think of my wife as being a
		woman. Does that sound mad?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Mad? No, it's not mad. Your wife as a woman.
		Interesting.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well, romantic, perhaps. You married?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes indeed. Oh yes. Marriage is a wonderful thing.
		It's upstairs at the moment. It's a bit tired after the
		journey.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	"It"?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	My wife.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh I see. I thought you meant the mountain. I
		thought you meant the mountain was upstairs.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No no no.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So are you going to be climbing tomorrow?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh yes. I shall be up her face tomorrow morning,
		first thing.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	With your wife?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh no. It's never really enjoyed climbing.
		It doesn't like heights, you see. Mind you,
		neither do I.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Then why do you climb? That sounds very odd. It
		sounds very strange indeed.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It is strange, it's mad really. I can't think why
		I married it. That's why I climb mountains, I
		suppose. To get away from it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	And of course you're so beautiful.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I beg your pardon?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You are so ravishingly lovely.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well that's very kind of you I'm sure.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Wales, that is. I always think of Wales as a "you".
		Don't know why.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh, I understand. Yes, you certainly are lovely,
		aren't you?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh yes. What a great country you are.
		
	Drifting through the window we hear a lilting 
	Welsh hymn.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ah. You hear that? What a beautiful hymn.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ah. You think of that as a him, do you? That's
		funny, because I'd call that a "they". To me, that's a
		beautifully sung "they".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Ah, it's pure poetry, isn't it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Your wife? Your wife is poetry?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No, the hymn is poetry.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well I don't know. I don't think they is poetry. I
		always think that poetry is poetry.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You're talking now of Dylan Thomas.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Dylan Thomas, yes ... or any of the other great
		poets, like ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Dylan Thomas.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes and ... er ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Dylan Thomas.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Coal black ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Black as black ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Slow black ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Black ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Black ... Aye.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes. I always think of aye as yes. Yes, there's no
		doubt about it, we're very, very lucky.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	We?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	The Welsh. I always think of the Welsh as "we". A
		great stream of we.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes, a huge reservoir of we, I know what
		you mean.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh Wales, you're so lovely.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You certainly are. I'd live there if the bastards
		didn't keep burning down my holiday cottage.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh is on the phone in the boardroom. Stephen enters 
	and throws off his coat. Hugh nods a greeting.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Looking at his watch) Dammit to blue-rinsed
		Hades!
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Problem, Peter?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(Hangs up) Yeah. This watch keeps losing time,
		John. It was a birthday gift from Nancy and I
		haven't the heart to tell her that it keeps time
		about as well as a Rangoon stevedore. So tell me
		John, how did the meeting go?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I don't know how the meeting went, Peter.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I don't understand, John.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It's very simple, Peter. I didn't go.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You didn't go, John? I understand even less ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Would it help if I told you that Marjorie was at the
		meeting, Peter?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Marjorie?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Check. With her two lap-poodles, Dexter and
		O'Neill.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What the deuce was that hell-bitch Marjorie
		doing there?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Marjorie is a majority stockholder in Barraclough
		Leisure, Peter. She's entitled to attend any
		damned meeting she chooses.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh come on, John. Marjorie holds stock in just
		about every major leisure corporation in the
		Uttoxeter Yellow Pages. Are you telling me ... ?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I don't know what I'm telling you, Peter. But I
		decided there and then that if Marjorie and I were
		going to war, it would be on the ground of my
		choosing ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	But dammit, John ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Wait a minute, I haven't finished.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Sorry, John.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	It would be on the ground of my choosing
		... Peter.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Right. But there's something else on your mind. I
		can tell. I've seen that look before.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I was just thinking, how old's the boy now?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The boy? Where does he come into this?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Half that Barraclough stock is his, remember?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	You mean ... ?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I mean, Peter, the boy's old enough to think for
		himself. If he's anything like his father he'll have a
		mind of his own.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You're his father John.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No Peter. As a matter of record, I'm not.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	This is a story I've not heard.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Pouring himself a drink and staring into the distance)
		It was while I was working every hour that God
		sent and plenty more on top of that, making
		something of this health club, wheeling, dealing,
		bobbing, weaving, ducking and diving through
		every centimetre of red tape the local Uttoxeter
		bureaucrats could tie me up with, hustling,
		breaking my DAMNED ARSE to set this company
		on the right road.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And Marjorie wanted children.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's right. The business was just starting to turn
		the corner, and there was Marjorie, asking me to
		throw away ten minutes of my life in order to have
		a child. I just couldn't do that.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I understand, but I don't understand.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Simple. I did what any good businessman would
		have done in my place. I delegated. Put Tim on
		the case.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Tim ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Luckily he was able to fit it in. The rest, as they
		say, is damned history. Tim is the boy's father.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Not strictly true, John.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Peter? You have some input on this?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I swear to you John, I had no idea where the brief
		originated, but Tim came to me one night saying
		that he'd bitten off more than he could chew, and
		could I get him out of a jam.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Don't tell me ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm afraid so, John. Tim delegated the delegating.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Damn his arse! Are you telling me that you're the
		boy's father, Peter?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Not as simple as that, I'm afraid. I was up to
		my neck with Nancy at the time. Strung out on
		a wire trying to set up finance for her Vegetable
		Boutique.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So you delegated?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I had no choice, John. Things were happening so
		fast you had to run just to keep moving.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Come on, Peter. Who did you dump this one on?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You're not going to like it, John.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No ... you can't mean? Marjorie?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's right. Marjorie. Who else could I have
		turned to, John?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	So Marjorie is the boy's father? That is sick.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No no no. It gets a little bit complicated here,
		John. Marjorie was hustling some deal out
		Peterborough way, on the road day and night ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Marjorie delegated? I can't believe this. Who to?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The boy, John.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	To the boy? The boy is his own father?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's right. The boy is his own father.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Seven types of executive damn with a free
		hellblast!
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	But John, maybe this can still work for us. Maybe
		we can bring pressure to bear on the boy by
		appealing to his father.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Get the boy to persuade himself to vote our way,
		you mean?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	It might work.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What can we lose?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Daamn!!
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I don't think so.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh is sitting in a chat show swivel chair, addressing 
	the camera.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ladies and gentlemen, this is a genuinely exciting
		moment for me. We're extremely honoured to
		have on the show tonight one of those very rare
		performers - a man who perhaps more than any
		other can lay claim to the title "superstar". Ladies
		and gentlemen, will you please welcome, Michael
		Jackson.
		
	Applause and music: "Bad". Stephen enters, shakes 
	hands with Hugh and sits down.
		
		Michael, thank you very much indeed for coming
		on the show.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Pleasure.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I know you must be frantically busy.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Things are a bit hectic at the moment, yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I believe you're about to start work on a
		new album?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	A new album, that's right. It's absolutely brand
		new. Even the little hole in the middle is new.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I love these clothes, by the way.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh thank you, yes, this is a plain Irish
		Thornproof, very hard wearing, I've had it for
		some time actually.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I bet thousands of kids all over the world are trying
		to copy this look right now.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well haha ... perhaps.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Now Michael, you've been in the music business
		for ... well most of your life ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Just about, yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right, and of course "Thriller" has sold more
		copies than any other record, you're without doubt
		the biggest star of this or perhaps any generation.
		Have you ever wondered what your life would have
		been like if none of this had ever happened?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes. Yes, I do. There's no way of knowing this,
		obviously, but I sometimes think if all this hadn't
		happened, my life would have been very different
		indeed.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Really?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well I think so, yes. It's so hard to know,
		of course.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Now Michael, I have to ask you this. There has
		been some speculation over the years that you
		have, with the aid of plastic surgery, set about
		altering your appearance.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well I don't really pay any attention to that. That's
		just newspapers, you know ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	So you absolutely deny it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well I don't think it's even worth denying. All
		it boils down to is people being jealous of my
		success. People will say anything.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes. We've got a picture of you here, when you
		were with the Jackson Five - you'd just signed to
		Motown, I believe ...
		
	Cut to eight-year-old Michael Jackson.
		
		You do look a bit different ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I was eight years old, for heaven's sake. I mean of
		course I've changed. We've all changed.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Absolutely. Well, Michael, I hope that's answered
		your critics. Now I believe you're actually going to
		do a song for us now from the new album?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	That's right. This song is called "Move It On
		Out Girl".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ladies and gentlemen - "Move It On Out Girl" -
		Michael Jackson!
		
	Stephen walks over to "performance area" and starts 
	grooving to the intro. He somehow gets on to an 
	exercise treadmill to do the walking on the spot. He 
	apparently sings.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Move it on out girl,
		Don't leave it where it is, girl,
		Put it somewhere else, girl,
		Don't move it on in.

		If you move it on in, girl,
		I might have to find another girl,
		Who'll give me less trouble girl,
		Who'll move it on out ...
		
	Stephen does a groovy dance break, during which Hugh 
	comes over and interrupts the song.	
		Sorry, is there a problem?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No no, Michael, that was very enjoyable. It's just
		that I couldn't help noticing that you were miming.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No I wasn't.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes you were.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No I wasn't.
		
	From now on we begin to notice that Stephen is 
	actually miming his answers to Hugh's questions.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I mean I'm sorry, but you see I just think that
		this is so disappointing. It's almost impossible for
		the kids to see an artist doing a live performance
		nowadays ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Look, I know some people do it, but I promise you
		that miming is simply not the Michael Jackson way.
		Atishoo!
		
	Visually, Stephen's sneeze is about five seconds after 
	we hear it.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(To camera) It's tragic when stars don't live up to
		your expectations.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No, I was joking. She's as mad as
		a house.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	This is shot entirely from a low level. All we see are 
	bare legs, from the knee down.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Kissing the guests) Tom, Irene, welcome!
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Dick, thanks for inviting us.
'}, {'speaker': 'Selina', 'text': "
	First all-naked party I've been to for years.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes, well we thought it would make a change.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Saves the problem of having to decide what to
		wear anyway!
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Right!
		
	They find this really amusing.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Selina', 'text': "
	Nice carpet ... is it a Tideyman's?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Now how on earth could you tell that?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well I suppose it was the modern, up-to-the-
		minute design wasn't it darling?
"}, {'speaker': 'Selina', 'text': '
	And the practicability.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'm surprised by how large your breasts are, Irene.
"}, {'speaker': 'Selina', 'text': '
	Why thank you. And I must say you have a very
		amusingly shaped ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(Interrupting) ... Dick, I believe I'm also right in
		saying that it repels stains and resists spills.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	The carpet, I hope you mean! Yes, that's right.
		Nothing soaks into a Tideyman's.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I expect we'll be putting that to the test before the
		evening's out.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Rather. Let me stroke your thighs, Irene.
'}, {'speaker': 'Selina', 'text': "
	Thanks. I have so say it's a great colour. What
		would you call this colour, exactly?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well, flesh-coloured, I suppose.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I think Irene was referring to the Tideyman's
		actually.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh right.
'}, {'speaker': 'Selina', 'text': "
	No I wasn't.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh.
'}, {'speaker': 'Selina', 'text': "
	It's a sort of purple, really, isn't it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	But come to think of it, what made you choose this
		colour of Tideyman's?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well it was quite difficult at first, because they had
		so many to choose from, but with the aid of their
		highly trained sales staff we finally came to the
		right decision.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Seems to me you made the right decision right at
		the beginning.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	By going to Tideyman's in the first place.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Right! Dip?
'}, {'speaker': 'Selina', 'text': "
	Yes, it does rather, doesn't it.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	We took the caravan down to
		Dorset this year, and pushed it
		over a cliff.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen is sitting at a desk in a dingy office. Hugh and 
	a woman enter. Hugh is a supermarket security guard,
	she is a housewife.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Come on, in you go.
'}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': "
	There's no need to push. I can walk.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ah. Tango Four, is it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Sorry to bother you, Mr Turner. It looks like we've
		got a ten twenty-three on our hands.
"}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': '
	Will you let go of my arm?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A ten twenty-three, oh dear.
'}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': '
	You have absolutely no right to keep me here.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Won't you have a seat, Mrs ... ?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Target responds to the name of King, sir.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	All right, Tango Four, let's have your report.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Sir. As per your briefing instructions, I was
		positioned in aisle number three, between
		breakfast cereals and bread, operating a mobile
		figure of eight pattern around frozen vegetables.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Textbook stuff, Tango Four.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Thank you, sir. I then observed the target loitering
		opposite the Coco Pops.
'}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': "
	Look, I have to pick up my children at four
		o'clock, so if you ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	What's your name, son?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Lewis, sir. Oliver Lewis.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	This your first taste of action?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes, sir.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Quite a feeling, isn't it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh yes, sir. Quite a feeling.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I remember my first ten twenty-three. 1968. Still
		had me bum fluff.
'}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': "
	Look, I'm sorry to interrupt, but my children are
		waiting for me at school ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	My advice to you, Mrs King, is to pay a little more
		attention to your own problems just at the minute!
		(To Hugh) Doesn't hurt to shake 'em up a bit
		early on.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It's joy to watch you, sir.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Come come, my dear, dry those tears. Hanky?
'}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': '
	No thank you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(To Hugh) Hard, then soft, you see?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Beautiful, sir.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Now then, Mrs King, I'm going to tell you a story.
"}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': '
	Oh God.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	One day a woman goes into a supermarket and
		steals some Coco Pops. Do you like my story,
		Mrs King?
'}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': '
	Not really.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'm pretty near the mark though, aren't I?
"}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	She's lying, sir!
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	All right, Lewis. I think Mrs King and I understand
		each other.
'}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': "
	I don't think we do.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	After all, lifting a packet of Coco Pops isn't such
		a terrible thing, is it? Not when you look at what
		they get up to at football matches these days. No,
		I'd say that shoving a packet of Coco Pops down
		your cleavage and forgetting to pay for them is just
		being human, after all.
"}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': '
	Have you finished?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No, I haven't finished, you snotsucking ball
		of slime.
"}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': '
	Now look here ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No, you look here. See that? Know what
		that means?
		
	He points to a medal ribbon on his chest.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Tell her, laddie.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm afraid I don't know either, sir.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	This is a Distinguished Service Medal, from the
		Arndale Centre in Chippenham!
		
	He points to a photo on he wall.
		
		That's me! There! Shaking hands with the
		manager. Read out the citation, Lewis.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right, sir. (Reads) "Harry Turner is congratulated
		on his alertness in apprehending a shoulder of
		lamb - New Zealand."
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Stolen lamb, Mrs King. Stolen lamb, stolen Coco
		Pops. Comprendo?
'}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': '
	Are you accusing me of theft?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Affirmatory, Mrs King!
'}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': '
	Right. (She rootles in her handbag) What do you
		think this is? (Takes out piece of paper)
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Careful sir, it could be a trap.
'}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': "
	It's a bloody receipt. (Reads) Coco P. 48 pence!
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Have you got a receipt for that receipt?
'}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': "
	Of course I haven't.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Haha!
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No, course you haven't. 'Cos you nicked it,
		didn't you?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Confess, confess! You're from a broken home!
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Steady, Lewis.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Sorry, sir.
'}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': "
	Look, why don't we just call the police?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Police. Hear that, Lewis?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I did, sir. Very amusing.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I shouldn't worry too much about the police,
		Mrs King.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Police. Ha. (Spits)
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A fine body of men, on the whole, but amateurs
		when it comes to analysing the mind of a ten
		twenty-three. I could have joined the police if I'd
		wanted, Mrs King. The money's better of course,
		what with the housing allowance, but in the end I
		said to myself ... "Harry, my boy, you belong with
		the elite."
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Good on you, sir.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Thank you, Lewis. Or may I call you Oliver?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'd be honoured, Harry.
"}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': '
	You pathetic pair of twerps.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'm sorry?
"}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': "
	You sad, crappy, twerps. I'm leaving now.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well I'm afraid we're a long way from finishing
		yet ...
		
	The woman gets to her feet. Stephen tries to stop her 
	but she disables him with some fancy martial artwork 
	and then throws Hugh across the desk. She exits looking 
	cool. Stephen and Hugh pick themselves up off the floor.
		
		Yes, you're probably wondering why I let her walk
		out just like that?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well she was obviously innocent, sir.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Exactly. Knew it from the start. You get a nose for
		it after a while.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh yes. All of them. I've slept
		with every single one. Well every
		front-bencher, anyway.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hello. Welcome to "A Bit Of Fry And Laurie".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Grrrrr.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ladies and gentlemen, because Hugh and I are
		known for our anger, our satirical rage at the
		"human condition", for want of a better cliche ....
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Grrrr ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	We often get accused of lacking a sense of
		proportion. Here's a letter ... "It's very easy to
		knock, to rage and snarl and satirise, but what
		are you suggesting should go in the place of the
		institutions and people you so viciously decry?"
		This is a typical letter from Mr Alan Dense,
		absolutely typical. He writes letters like this all the
		time ... "It's oh so simple to knock Mrs Thatcher,
		isn't it?" Well of course he's quite right. It is
		ludicrously easy to knock Mrs Thatcher. It's the
		easiest and most obvious thing in the world to
		remark that she is a shameful, putrid scab, an
		embarrassing, ludicrous monstrosity that makes
		one frankly ashamed to be British, and that her
		ideas and standards are a stain on our national
		history. That's easy and clear, anyone can do that.
		But after tonight, no one can accuse us of not
		making a constructive suggestion as to what might
		go in place of Mrs Thatcher. Hugh.
		
	Hugh holds up a wire coathanger.
		
		That is our constructive suggestion, and I hope
		that's silenced some of our critics. Anyway, on with
		the blind, unreasoning rage.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes, here we go. I've written a savage, angry, satire
		on jam jars that get seperated from their lids.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Now that is anger.
		
	Hugh walks to piano. On top of the piano is a jar 
	with no lid.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Sings)
		Where is the lid
		Where is the lid
		Where is the lid
		Where is the lid
		
		Where is the lid
		Where is the lid
		Where is the lid
		Where is the lid
		
		Does anyone know
		Does anyone know
		Does anyone know
		Does anyone know
		
		Where is the lid
		Where is the lid
		Where is the lid
		Where is the lid -
		
	During this song Stephen has been saying:
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	"Yes, it's over here." "Hugh! It's on the table."
		"Hugh, it's over here for God's sake." etc.
		
	Eventually Stephen can take it no more and attacks 
	Hugh by beating him on the head with the jar or some 
	similar heavyweight object.

		'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': "Stephen looks down on Hugh's unconcious frame for 
	a second.
		"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	(Photo of Hugh appears)'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Voice-over) Hugh Laurie, who real name was
		Hugh Laurie, was better known by his stage name:
		Hugh Laurie.

		Cut to still of terraced house.

		Hugh was born and brought up in a working-class
		home that his parents had specially built ...
		
	Pull back on still to reveal that the slum terraced house 
	is actually set in rolling parkland in front of a beautiful 
	stately home.
		
		... in the grounds of their Gloustershire estate.
		Like many shy children, Hugh learnt from an early
		age simply to blend in.
		
	Cut to still of brick wall and lamp-post.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Caption', 'text': '
	"Hugh Laurie, High Wycombe, 1967"
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	His first acting job came in 1979, at Hereford
		Civic Centre, since renamed in Hugh's Honour,
		Hereford Civic and Amenities Centre.
		
	Cut to interview with Rowan Atkinson.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Caption', 'text': '
	"Nigel Havers"
'}, {'speaker': 'Rowan', 'text': '
	He was immensely dangerous. Such a dangerous
		actor. You always had this feeling when he was
		around that anything could happen. (Pause) Hugh
		Laurie, on the other hand, was about the dullest
		man I ever met.
		
	Cut to interview with Nigel Havers.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Caption', 'text': '
	"Paul Eddington"
'}, {'speaker': 'Nigel', 'text': '
	He brought to every one of his roles this quality of
		needing the money.
		
	Cut to interview with bow-tied critic.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Caption', 'text': '
	"Neil Hudd, TV and theatre critic for the
		Daily Mail" 
'}, {'speaker': 'Critic', 'text': "
	I'm so terribly clever, you see. That's one of the
		things I really admire about myself. I have this
		extraordinary ability to see, after the event, why
		something didn't work, and communicate it so
		wittily. I really am fabulous.
		
	Cut to film of Stephen interviewing himself.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Stephen Fry, what is your fondest memory of
		working with Hugh Laurie?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	The moment I knew he was really dead would be
		hard to beat.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Surprisingly enough, Roy
		Hattersley's actually a bit of a
		tiger in bed.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh enters a jewellry shop. Stephen is polishing the 
	back of his hand, for no particular reason, other than 
	that it is screamingly funny.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Er, good morning.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sir, it is a good morning. Sir is handsomely right
		to say so.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Is sir aware, I am busy wondering, that I made so
		bold to remark on the goodness of the morning to
		the youngest of my mothers earlier today as she
		wheeled me into an upright position. Was sir in an
		awareness of that?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No ... no I had no idea.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	"Here is a morning, mother of my bosom," I
		averred, "as fine and crisp and gutty as any since
		the days when Compton and Edrich opened for
		England and the sun never went down on the
		British without asking permission first."
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ha, did you?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I did, sir! Sir, I did. And if two broad-shouldered,
		long-fingered men such as ourselves can
		come independently to the conclusion that the
		morning they are currently experiencing is one
		of a goodness, then one of a goodness it must
		assuredly be.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Really?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes, sir, and you can spank me quietly with a
		chamois leather if it isn't so.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right, now ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	But sir hasn't come to trade insults on the state of
		the morning unless I am more vastly mistaken than
		a man who thinks Hilaire Belloc is still alive. Do
		sit down.
		
	They both sit.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No, I've ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sir has brought his handsomely sprung and finely
		wrought young body into this shop with the
		express purpose of going about the business of
		buying jewellry. Am I close to the mark?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Absolutely.
		
	Stephen stands.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Do you mind if I stand, sir? I think perhaps this
		"sitting down" idea of yours was a little ahead of
		its time.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(Also standing) Right. Yes. The thing is I'm getting
		engaged and I'd ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Would sir like an Opal Fruit?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Um ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A nice strawberry Opal Fruit? Or indeed any
		flavour?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Thank you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(Reaching for his hat) I won't be long.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Where are you going?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	There's a sweet-shop not half a mile up the road. I
		happen to know that they sell Opal Fruits.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well in that case, really don't bother.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Don't bother?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No, really.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Is sir in absolute possession of sureness in this
		regard?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Look. I really only came in here for jewellry, I
		thought if you happened to have an Opal Fruit on
		you ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Feeling about on the top of his head) "On" me? Sir
		I have no Opal Fruit "on" me. I can and will go
		further, I have never had an Opal Fruit on me.
		Eccentric, no doubt. Look, sir can search my head
		if sir in unconvinced.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Look, forget the Opal Fruit. The Opal Fruit is
		irrelevant. I want an engagement ring. Can we
		concentrate on that?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sir, I am chastened and bowed. Ever the man of
		affairs, sir has reminded us all, all of our duty. An
		engagement ring for sir.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's right.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What flavour of engagement ring had sir in mind?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Flavour? What are you talking about?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Just my little joke. You'll humour a dying man.
		We have a range of engagement rings that I would
		ask sir to cast over with sir's eyes, which I cannot
		help but notice are of a startling cobalt blue that
		would go very well with the wallpaper in one of my
		god-niece's back rooms.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(Leaving) Right, that's it. I'm leaving.
		
	Stephen comes round with a range of engagement rings 
	and blocks Hugh's egress.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What about this one?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What about this one?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It's rather nice, I suppose.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Sir, the issue of the rather niceness of this
		particular ring has been raised in Prime Minister's
		Question Time.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	How much is it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I would be wrong to let it go for more than forty
		thousand of your earth pounds.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Forty thousand pounds!
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I would be equally at fault if I let it go for less
		than ninety.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	So it's between forty thousand pounds and ninety.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sir is as dogged in his pursuit of detail as
		Roy Walker, presenter of the never-popular
		show Catchphrase is dogged in his pursuit of a
		thick earlet.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Perhaps you could, in preference to me walking
		out of here after hitting you very hard in the face,
		just tell me the frigging price.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Since sir has been kind enough never to be Peter
		Sissons I can let sir have it for two hundred and
		eighteen poundingtons.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	218?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	If you wish. And if sir will oblige me by promising
		never to wear green again I will throw in this for
		nothing.
		
	He brings out a velvet jewellry tray with a strawberry 
	Opal Fruit as its centrepiece.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	An Opal Fruit.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes, indeeding. A fruit of the genuine Opal
		persuasion. Perhaps sir will desist from ripping the
		kidneys from my nerveless frame if I offer him a
		taste to authenticate its strawberriness.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No, no. I believe you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	May I instead then, pausing only to pause ...
		Pause.
		... congratulate you on your excellent taste?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Thank you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sir, I was talking to the Opal Fruit. Strawberrine
		but with a faint tang of small urine.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes, yes. Quite so. Two hundred and eighteen
		pounds.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Two hundred and eighteen pounds that should be.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's what I said.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's what you said. I barely spoke at all.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Just put it in a presentation box if you would.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No need. I'll wear it now.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	And I really think you should speak to my father
		now, darling. He's upstairs in the cellar.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right. I really am leaving, now.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Leaving?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Goodbye.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	But we're engaged!
		
	Hugh leaves. Stephen turns to camera.
		
		Men are such bastards.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen is looking out of his office window with a 
	telescope. Hugh enters with a folder.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh. Morning Control.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Morning, Tony. I'll be with you in a minute.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I say, that's rather a splendid device. Where did
		you get that, if you don't mind my prying into
		your affairs?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I don't mind you prying at all, Tony. After all,
		you're only human.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's right, Control. I am.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	And what's more, you're a spy.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's true as well.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well to answer your question, Tony, you see it's
		my birthday today, and my sister Marie gave me
		this as a present.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I didn't know you had a sister called Marie,
		Control.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Marie isn't her real name of course, it's just a code
		name I've given her which prevents people from
		discovering her real name.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Ah well, that's cleared up that little confusion.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Her real name is Maria.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh. So you decided to opt for a code name that
		was quite similar to her real name, then Control?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes. It makes it much easier to remember.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Huh. You are a wily old fox, Control.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Anyway. This contraption is called a telescupe,
		Tony.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	A telescupe?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes. Although I should point out that that's also a
		code name, in fact.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Say no more, Control. Hush hush.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Mmm. Although I don't think I'm speaking out of
		school if I tell you that this device enables one to
		see things very clearly over quite a long distance.
		Here, you can have a go yourself.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Control, I really don't know what to say.
		
	Hugh goes over to the telescope.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Don't mention it, Tony. Now have a look at
		that man down there standing next to the
		telephone kiosk.
		
	Hugh looks through.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Gosh Control. You weren't exaggerating when you
		said it allowed you to see things very clearly. He
		could almost be in the room with us.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's very true, isn't it? But here's where the
		telescupe comes in. Because Tony?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	He isn't in the room with us.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well I thought he wasn't in the room with us
		Control, but it's nice to have it confirmed by you.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	He's actually on the other side of the street.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hmm. He appears to be looking this way, Control,
		with ... wait a minute ... yes, Control, that man
		is looking at us ... with a telescupe.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes, Tony. My theory is that he is an enemy
		agent charged with the task of keeping us under
		surveillance.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	What a confounded cheek, Control. I've a good
		mind to ring the police and have him moved on.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Steady Tony. I've got a better plan.
		
	Stephen starts dialling.
		
		I got Valerie to find out the number of that
		telephone kiosk.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Control, your plan is working. The man has picked
		up the receiver.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(Into telephone) Hello? Enemy Agent? It's Control
		here. (Pause) Very well, thank you. Please stop
		keeping us under surveillance. Thank you.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes, Control. He's going away.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Wiping his hands) There, Tony. Another small but
		significant victory for our side.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Congratulations, Control.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Now you go and fetch us a nice cup of coffee,
		and we'll pretend this whole ugly incident never
		happened.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I can go one better than that, Control.
		
	Hugh exits and enters with a cup of coffee tied up in a 
	red ribbon.
		
		Happy birthday to Control. Happy Birthday
		to Control. Happy Birthday to Control. Happy
		Birthday to Control.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh get along with you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Aren't you going to open it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Boh!
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "
	Hugh enters a psychiatrist's surgery or studio, or office 
	or whatever they call them."}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Good morning, Mr Meddlicott is it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes. You look a bit young to me. Still, I suppose
		you'll do.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well, that's nice. Now, I shall call you Arthur,
		if I may.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You may not. You'll call me Mr Meddlicott.
		Stephen raises his eyebrows.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Very well. So why are you here, Mr Meddlicott?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, why do you think? You're a psychiatrist aren't
		you? I'm not here for dancing lessons or free sex,
		I've come to be cured.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Cured of what?
