'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	For heaven's sake man, do I have to teach you
		your job? Madness of course. I'm slightly mad and
		I'd like you to cure me. "Of what?" Tt!
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You're mad?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes! Am I going to have to repeat everything twice?
		Now I'm a busy man, so if you just get on with
		it, I'd be very grateful.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Would you like to tell me why you think you're
		mad?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh what is this, some sort of game? Do you
		imagine I've got time to waste thinking I'm mad?
		I am mad. Just take my word for it, will you, and
		let's have a little less lip.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So how does this madness of yours manifest itself?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	At half past four every day I do something wierd.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Go on.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Go on what. I'm waiting for half past four,
		aren't I?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(Looks at clock) It's four thirty-three.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I can see that. I'm running four minutes late today
		on account of your incessant yakking.
		Pause.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Looks at clock) Four thirty four.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Right. For heaven's sake, watch closely.
		Hugh takes off his shoes, then removes a piece of bread from either jacket pocket and puts a piece in either shoe.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You take off your shoes. And you put a piece of
		bread in each one.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I know I do. What is your problem?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Do you leave the bread there?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Leave it there? Of course I don't leave it there.
		Are you some kind of idiot?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Please go on. What happens next?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I take the bread out of my shoes and hide it in my
		secretary's handbag. Then at four thirty-one, I take
		it out of her handbag and throw it in the bin.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	But you won't be doing that today, because your
		secretary's not here.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh, give the man a bloody medal.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	So. (Pause) That's it, is it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh, I'm sorry, it's not enough for you. You'd
		rather I wrapped myself in bacon rind and
		pretended to be Florence Nightingale, would
		you? Well I'm sorry I'm as mad as I am. But no
		madder.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Why do you think wrapping yourself in bacon rind
		would make you look like Florence Nightingale?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Wh ... I ... are you an imbecile? I don't think
		anything of the kind.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Florence Nightingale never wrapped herself in
		bacon rind.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(Angry and trying to explain) I know she bloody
		didn't. BUT-IF-I-WAS-MADDER-THAN-I-
		AM-I-WOULDN'T-KNOW-WOULD-I-YOU-
		HALF-WIT.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I see.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	So. What are you going to do about this madness
		of mine?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Nothing. I don't think you're mad at all.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You think it's perfectly usual to put bread in your
		shoes? On a daily basis. That's normal practice in
		your foul part of the world?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You're welcome to a second opinion of course, but
		I don't think you're mad. Eccentric, certainly.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	And this is what we pay our psychiatrists for, is it?
		Well let me tell you, I shall write a very stiff letter
		to the Daily Mail about this. Now, cure me of my
		madness or I won't put my shoes on. Ever.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Sharply) You write letters to the Daily Mail?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Not exclusively the Daily Mail. Sometimes the Sun or the Mirror.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And they are published?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Of course.
		
	Stephen springs to his feet and goes over to his desk,
	picks up a copy of the Sunor Mirror.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Is this one of yours? "A good way to prevent your
		money being stolen is to ..."
		Hugh joins in.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	"Keep it in a special pocket sewn into your coat."
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You're Mrs June Ellis of Stockport?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Naturally.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Reading from Mirror) What about this ... "Why
		aren't -"
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	"- bus conductors more friendly? A smile a day
		keeps the doctor away. And it's free too!"
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Chest size?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Forty-two.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Stay here. I'll get your strait-jacket.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	God the lengths you have to go to in this country
		to prove you're mad.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	A Bonnie Langford concert?
		Hmm. I think I'd rather be gang-
		raped by the House of Lords.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Close-up:'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Car radio, hand on tuning knob.'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "Stephen's hand takes file out of briefcase."}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Cut to outside of car. Stephen is putting briefcase on 
	back seat of car. Hugh approaches car, opens door.'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh settles in his seat.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Thank you for sparing the time for this.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No problem.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You admire Gary Davies?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Don't get much time for that sort of thing.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You should make time, Alan. A man should
		unwind. (Stephen turns off radio) Do you mind if I
		call you Alan?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Fine by me.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Good. Good. I just find Sally a bit awkward.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I quite understand.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Excellent. Now then Alan, I've got your record
		in front of me and it makes impressive reading.
		You've certainly knocked about the world a bit
		haven't you?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, you know ... I've knocked about the
		world a bit.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sorry. I meant to say "you've done a lot of
		travelling". You've done a lot of travelling, haven't
		you, Alan?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, you know, I've knocked about the world a
		bit.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes, you certainly have. But I'd like if I may to fill
		in one or two gaps, take a few side bearings, rough
		out some contours, OK with you?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Fine.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	OK. '65, '66, you ran guns out of Macao using a
		refitted Dutch trawler.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I can still smell those damn herring.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	'68 you popped up on the Ivory Coast smuggling
		refugees out of Nigeria. The following year there
		was that nasty caper with the Rhodesian mining
		company, and then in 1970 you became the reserve
		team coach for Oxford United. Correct?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You've done your homework.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	But then, Alan, we seem to lose you. There's a
		gap, a hole, you appear to have vanished for four
		years. Four years is a long time in our business.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You still haven't told me what that business is.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Nor yet have I. A four year gap, Alan, until we
		find you cropping up again, this time in Indonesia,
		playing both ends against the middle in their
		civil war. From then on it's a series of apparently
		unrelated appearances, working with Uruguayan
		customs, a supply teacher in Maidstone, crop-
		spraying in Rawalpindi, Home Secretary in the last
		Labour government and then a short spell as Nigel
		Pargiter in the Archers.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Someone had to do it.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh yeah, sure.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	All right. Now it's my turn, okay? I've got to tell
		you I don't like being rung up by strange people
		I've never met before and having files read out at
		me. I don't like being asked questions by men in
		grey suits, yeah? Now why don't you tell me just
		exactly what is going on and who in blazes you are?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(Chuckling at the file) Oh it's all true. Insubordinate,
		impertinent, imprisoned twice for striking
		a senior officer, a rebel, a trouble-maker, a
		loner, an independent, a conniver, a misfit, a
		maverick, a trickster, an inveigler, a shyster, a
		shuffler, a shammer, an adventurer, a cozener, a
		thimblerigger, a pettifogger, a bilker ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Get to the point.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	All right. We need a man, Alan. We need a man
		with exceptional abilities, a man with a record
		of success against all the odds, a man with the
		courage to try his hand at the impossible.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Go on.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	We want you, if you can, to sit down and watch an
		entire episode of The Krypton Factor.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You're out of your mind.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Listen to me, Alan. It's never been done. No one
		has ever watched the programme from start to
		finish, and we desperately need someone to do it.
		Sure, we've all seen bits, but no one has ever gone
		the distance.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	If I don't make it, you'll see that Judy's taken
		care of.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Of course, Alan, of course.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	See you in hell.
		
	Hugh gets out of the car.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What a man.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Good evening and welcome to Trying To Borrow
		A Fiver Off. Tonight I shall be Trying To
		Borrow A Fiver Off the conductor of the Bristol
		Philharmonic Orchestra, Neville Anderson. Good
		evening, Neville.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh for heaven's sake, call me Neville.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ha, if you insist. Neville, can I borrow a fiver off
		you till Wednesday?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Sorry, I've got nothing smaller than a twenty.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Bye bye.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	There's no doubt about it, it's an
		exciting place to live and work.
		We've even got one of those new
		edge-of-town city centres.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen addresses the camera.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Ladies and gentlemen, all the sketches we've done
		on this show have been sort of finished, in one
		way or another. They start, they go along a bit,
		then they stop. More than one critic has drawn
		the parallel between our sketches and a nylon zip.
		But what we've never done on this show are the
		sketches that simply start - they start, with one
		line, sometimes quite a promising line, and then
		go nowhere at all. We'd like to show you some of
		them now, just so that you can get a glimpse of
		what might have been ...
		
	Cut to:

		A traditional sketch shop. Stephen is behind the 
	counter. Hugh enters frequently.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Has Deborah Munnings arrived yet?
		
	Cut to:
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'd like to apply for the Royal Regiment of
		Homosexuals.
		
	Cut to:
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ah Dermot, there you are. I was sorting through
		some things in the attic this morning, and I came
		across your old legs ...
		
	Cut to:
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'd like to open a Homosexual Bank account,
		please.
		
	Cut to: 
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Your grandfather's a bit smelly, isn't he?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yeah, well that's death for you.
		
	Cut to: 
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Singing) "When somebody loves you, It's no good
		unless they love you"
		
	Cut to: 
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Has Deborah Munnings arrived yet?
		
	Cut to: 
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'd like to apply to become a homosexual.

		etc ...

	
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	And then my bereavement
		counsellor died. I didn't know
		who to turn to.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Stephen is sitting at a desk looking at a computer
	terminal. Hugh is leaning over his shoulder.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Dammit, Peter.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Thanks John.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	This is ... what can I say? This is good work.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well I kind of hoped that we might be along the
		right lines here.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Right lines? Dammit backwards into a narrow
		space, Peter, this is the best I've ever seen.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Jill reckons ten days at the most. Which means we
		could have this up and running by the 29th.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You mean ... ?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Exactly, John. The Derwent Enterprises Board
		meeting. With something like this nestling in your
		hip pocket, you could really kick some arse.
		
	Stephen starts to laugh smugly.
		
		What's up, John?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Peter, can you imagine how Marjorie is going to
		take this?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well John, at a guess I'd say that she'll be wilder
		than a hungry hellcat in a tornado.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's putting it mildly.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Is it?
		
	The both laugh creepily. The phone rings. Hugh 
	picks it up.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Hahaha ... Yes, hello? Hold on Sarah. (To 
		Stephen) It's Marjorie.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Haha. Well talk of the she-devil. Oh what the hell,
		I'll take the call.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It's not a call, John. She's outside and she wants to
		see you.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Marjorie's here?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yup.
		
	Stephen takes the phone.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Show her in, Sarah.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	John, are you out of your goddamned mind?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	We don't know what it's about, Peter.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	To hell with what it's about, John! You and I have
		broken out arses building up this health club,
		with Marjorie gunning for us every centimetre of
		the way, and now you're going to let her swan in
		here ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Now listen to me, Peter ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Listen be damned! In case you'd forgotten, John,
		that bitchfiend tried to break us in two ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Peter ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm not going to let you do it, John!
		
	They are now nose to nose across the desk. In the 
	background the door opens and Mrjorie enters. She is 
	late forties, Joan Collinsish glamour.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Marjorie', 'text': '
	Hello John.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hello Marjorie.
'}, {'speaker': 'Marjorie', 'text': '
	Peter.
		
	Hugh says nothing.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Marjorie', 'text': "
	I hope I'm not interrupting anything?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Not at all. Peter and I were just running over one
		or two things.
'}, {'speaker': 'Marjorie', 'text': '
	Are you all right, Peter? You seem a little
		uncomfortable.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yeah. Maybe I'll go outside and get a bite of air.
		The atmosphere in here seems to have got to my
		stomach.
		
	Exit Hugh. Stephen and Marjorie look at each other for 
	a while.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You look well, Marjorie. You look damned well.
		New breasts?
'}, {'speaker': 'Marjorie', 'text': '
	Swiss.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	They suit you. I like what you've done to your hair.
		Looks much better there.
"}, {'speaker': 'Marjorie', 'text': '
	Thanks John, you look pretty fit yourself.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Fit? Yeah, one of the perks of running a health
		and leisure business I guess. That is ... if I still
		do run it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Marjorie', 'text': '
	The meeting will decide, John, you know that.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(Pouring two drinks) And who will decide how
		the meeting goes, Marjorie? Dammit old man
		Ashby's in your pocket, Dexter and O'Neill will do
		whatever you damned well tell them and Tim will
		jump with the tide. Do you still like it straight up?
"}, {'speaker': 'Marjorie', 'text': '
	Two lumps of ice.
		
	Hugh has appeared at the window and is looking 
	jealously in.
	
		I do whatever I do for the boy, John. You must
		know that.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yeah, the boy. Have you taught him to hate me,
		Marjorie?
'}, {'speaker': 'Marjorie', 'text': "
	Hate you? Hate you? You'll never really know me,
		will you.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Not if I live to be a chairman.
		
	Hugh is trying to listen.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Marjorie', 'text': '
	Peter resents me.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Peter? Dammit in top gear, Marjorie, what are you
		after?????
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(Muffled, through the glass) Yeah? What are
		you after??
		
	They don't hear him.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Marjorie', 'text': "
	I just want you to know, whatever happens after
		the meeting ... that it wasn't personal, John.
		Strictly business. I still like you ... a lot.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Roughly yet somehow tenderly) Come here, you ...
		you Marjorie.
		
	They kiss deeply and erotically.

		Hugh is distraught the other side of the glass. He 
	hammers on it.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Leave him alone you bitch-cat! John don't listen to
		her. Damn you!
		
	They part, panting.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Marjorie', 'text': "
	I'll see you round the boardroom table.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yeah ... round the boardroom table.
		
	She makes to leave.	
		Oh and Marjorie ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Marjorie', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Damn you to hell you're one hell of a woman.
"}, {'speaker': 'Marjorie', 'text': '
	I know. Well ... you know where to find me.
		
	Stephen takes an Oedipal decision.

		Exit Marjorie.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Following her) Daaaaaamn!
		
	Hugh climbs in through the window in a desperate bid 
	to stop him. He trips over.
		
	
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Chris Patten? Isn't he Margaret
		Thatcher's new corporate logo?
		I'm not sure.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen is as we remember him from '}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	So, in a sense, in a sense, in a sense, Duncan, we
		are left with those two. Two. None other. Nary
		another, not one other more. We have, on the
		one side of the divide, the gulf, the chasm, the
		DIVIDING LINE, if you please, we have the
		beauty of ideas, and on the other, the other side,
		oh, I don't know, the other term of the equation
		if that's nicer, we have the idea of beauty. Am I
		sensing through? Am I connecting?
		
	Hugh glances at the camera in friendly fashion.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	We're discussing the beauty of ideas and the
		idea of beauty.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Hold a thought for me, Geoffrey, I'll give you the
		thought, hold it for me. Would you please?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm going to hold a thought, now.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	If beauty is only an idea, a form, a paradigm, a
		pattern, a template, an ideal, an idea, if you like,
		with an "l", then what is "the beautiful"? Beauty
		is unattainable, but "the beautiful" surrounds us.
		We return to language. Philip, we're back with
		language again. That's the thought you'd be ever
		so to splendid for me.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	We've made a return to language. That's the
		thought I'm holding.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Listen to me lovelet, language circumscribes
		beauty, confines it, limns, delineates, colours and
		contains. Yet what is language but a tool, a tool we
		use to dig up the beauty that we take as our only
		and absolute real?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Language is a tool.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	So I'm finding myself with some surprise and
		no little alarm hurling a paradox at you. Beauty
		is our only reality and yet it is an ideal. It is the
		surface-tension of the membrane that stretches
		between us and the vision of beauty that language
		seeks to disperse, as a detergent might dissipate or
		dissolve a droplet of oil.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm in trouble now.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Hush, tish, vibble, I'm streaking ahead. Let me
		explain, expand, expound and exposit.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Would you?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I find you beautiful. But you are not beauty.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Whoops.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Therefore you contain a property of beauty.
		Therefore the substance of which you exhibit a
		property must exist. Where is it?
		
	Hugh looks about helpfully, in case it is on the table or 
	has been left on the floor.
		
		That is language's task. Who was it who said
		"Language is the universal whore that I must make
		into a virgin?" Who was it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Kate Adie?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I think it was Karl Kraus. But it needn't have
		been. Now. Tommy, time to ask you to give back
		the thought I bade you hold for me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I was holding the thought "We've made a return to
		language."
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Correct correctington. Language pursues
		beauty, harries it, hounds it, courses it across the
		roughlands of truth and enquiry AND IN SO
		DOING CAN BE BEAUTIFUL ITSELF. Ripple
		on ripple, image with image, a wheel within a
		wheel like the circles that you find in the windmills
		of your mind.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Noel Harrison.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Noel, as you so rightly, Harrison. Language can be
		beautiful. And Madeline asleep in lap of legends
		old. Plenitude. Dishes. Martita. Breasts. Tumble.
		Emolument. Forage. Smitten. Plenum. Vulva.
		Words that have their own sonority and beauty
		that is extrinsic, extrinsic to their connotational OR
		DENOTATIONAL referends.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I think he said vulva.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	So Timothy I'll leave you with a thought, a
		breath, a fruit that drops from the boughs of my
		imaginings. Think beauty but be beautiful. Say
		beauty, but say it beautifully. Beauty is duty and
		duty beauty. So there. Goodnight. I don't feel
		quite so well now.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(To camera) I'll talk to you later. B-bye.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	The exciting thing about Chris
		Patten is that he's bold and
		imaginative.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen is coming groggily round in a hospital bed.
	Hugh as doctor, sympathetically gazes down.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oo-er.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Mr Kerniff ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Mmm.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Mr Kerniff, how are you feeling?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What happened?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You probably don't remember Mr Kerniff, but you
		were in a very serious accident.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A van.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No. An accident. You were on your bicycle, and
		you were hit ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	By a van.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Am I all right?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You're going to be fine, Mr Kerniff. Lots of drink
		and plenty of hot sleep.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Right.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	But I'm afraid you did sustain a very serious injury
		to your genitals.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	My genitals?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Holds up stainless steel tray) As you can see.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh dear.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh, as you rightly say, dear. We had no choice but
		to remove them.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh no.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh, as you didn't rightly say, yes.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	However will I manage?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hmm. Did you use them often, Mr Kerniff?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well, not really. But it was nice to know that they
		were there.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Quite. Well all is not lost, Mr Kerniff. Medical
		science has advanced a great deal. Prosthetic
		and substitute legs, arm, even noses, are now
		commonplace.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You supply substitute genitals?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Say hello to Killer, Mr Kerniff.
		
	Hugh leads on a nasty-looking Doberman.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You're not going to ... I mean, surely you can't.
		For heaven's sake, I don't want a dog's genitals!
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh what an almost amusing misunderstanding,
		Mr Kerniff. No no no. Killer will simply be your
		substitute for having genitals.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I beg your pardon?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes, I'm sure you've seen people walking round
		with Dobermans before?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well ... yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes, well for men who have no genitals, the
		ownership of a Doberman or similarly violent
		animal acts as an important psychological crutch.
		And I stress the word "important".
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Owning a Doberman is a substitute for having
		genitals?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Indeed yes, Mr Kerniff. Thousands of people
		compensate for genital inadequacy by owning
		large dogs.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	But why?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Beats me, Mr Kerniff. I'm only a doctor. In
		addition we will provide you with a diving watch,
		a year's subscription to Guns & Ammo and this
		combat jacket. And these are yours too.
		
	Hugh drops a diving watch, a gun magazine, a combat 
	jacket and a bunch of keys on Stephen's bed.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Wh ...?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Keys to your rusty white van.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	But, Doctor ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes, Mr Kerniff?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I appreciate that you're trying to help here, but
		I also happen to use my genitals for, you know,
		getting rid of my urine ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh don't worry, that's the beauty of the system.
		When people see you wearing a combat jacket and
		driving round in a white van with Killer, the piss
		will be taken out of you constantly.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I suppose in an ideal world
		I would be in bed with Philip
		Schofield right now.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	On a street somewhere. Stephen is trying to interview 
	Hugh as the eyewitness to a road accident. Hugh is a 
	fast-talking, over-eager Australian. Stephen has to keep 
	stepping in and out of shot to restrain Hugh.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(To cameraman) Are we ready?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yup. Any time. I was standing ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No, I was just talking to the cameraman.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right. Got you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	OK. So basically I'll just ask you what you saw ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well this guy came haring round the corner, must
		have been doing about fifty ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Wait a minute ... Can you wait until ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh right.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'll ask you a question about what you saw ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yeah, this guy came round that corner, I thought
		he was going to hit that wall over there ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No. Can you wait until I've asked you the
		question ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Sorry. Sorry.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Now then ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	This guy came round that corner there ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	WAIT ... a minute.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Sorry. I thought you ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No. Just wait. Brian, are you ready?
'}, {'speaker': 'Brian', 'text': '
	(Off) Ready.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	OK. This guy came haring round that corner ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Shut up!
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh yeah, right.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Please do not say anything until I've asked you a
		question.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh I get you. Right, sorry.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Good. Now Mr Travis, I believe you ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yeah that's right, and this guy came round that
		corner over there doing about fifty ...
		
	Stephen goes right up to Hugh, noses almost touching,
	and screams at him.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	WAIT ... UNTIL ... I'VE ... ASKED YOU
		... THE ... QUESTION!!
		Longish pause.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	OK.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Thank you ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	This guy came ...
		
	Stephen punches Hugh in the face incredibly hard.
		
	
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Wine tasting) Um ... the first
		one was dog the second cat. No?
		They were both cat?
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Charming old man enters bookshop, where Hugh and 
	Stephen serve.'}, {'speaker': 'Old Man', 'text': '
	Good morning. Do you have a copy of Fly Fishing
		by J.R. Hartley?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I knew it, I knew it.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I said this morning.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Would you believe it, we had a whole shopful of
		them, and now ...
		
	Camera pulls back to reveal an empty shop.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Old Man', 'text': "
	Well, that's the power of advertising I suppose
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Absolutely. Mind you ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	We do have 30,000 copies of Yellow Pages, can't
		shift 'em.
"}, {'speaker': 'Old Man', 'text': '
	Ooh. Can I order one?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well we've got them here.
"}, {'speaker': 'Old Man', 'text': '
	No, no. I have to order them you see.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well, yeah. All right then. We can order one
		for you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Old Man', 'text': "
	You can? That's marvellous. My name? Of course
		... it's Pages, L.O. Pages.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I never asked him his name, did you?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Voiceover) Good old L.O. Pages.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "
	Stephen is looking at a picture on the wall, dressed in 
	a very unControllish sort of way. Painter's smock and 
	multi-coloured scarf. Hugh comes in, and starts talking 
	before he sees Stephen."}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Morning Control. Sorry to bother you with this
		but ...
		
	He sees Control and is slightly startled by his clothes.
		
		I was wondering ... whether ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Morning.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Morning. If you'll allow me to say so, Control, you
		appear to have radically changed your appearance
		and manner of dressing.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Ah, we've got a little bit of a crossed line here, I'm
		afraid. I'm not actually Control.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You're not Control?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well now I don't know whether I'm coming
		or going.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Don't worry. I'm Control's twin brother. How do
		you do?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh I see. How do you do? You really do look
		awfully like Control, you know.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes, people have frequently remarked on the
		similarity between myself and Control, it's true.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	My name's Tony.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	My name's Control.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Sorry?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It's a bit confusing but you see my mother could
		never tell us apart right from the day we were
		born, so she decided to call us both by the same
		name. She called us both Control.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You mean Control is Control's real name?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's right. Oh dear. Have I been indiscreet?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Not at all. It's just that I always assumed that the
		name Control was just a cover for Control's real
		name, which was a closely guarded secret.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well, of course, I've always known that his name
		was Control. Just as I've always known that my
		name was Control as well.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	You could knock me down with a feather.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I expect I could if it was a large and heavy one.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes. So. Do you happen to know where Control is?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'm right here, as it happens.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh no! We're confused already!
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh, you mean my brother Control!
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	He's presently painting an erotic mural somewhere
		in Earl's Court I should imagine.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh dear. I may need a lie-down soon.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Before you go to that extreme, Mr Murchison. I
		assume you are Tony Murchison by the way ... ?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I am. Though the way things are going perhaps I
		should say "I think I am!"
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes. I like you already, Tony, if I may call you that.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Please do.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I was going to explain that I am something of the
		Black Sheep of our family. Control is a widely
		respected chief of the Secret Service and I am a
		not very respectable painter, though with a certain
		following in the louche areas of the metropolis.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	With you so far Control number two.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	And the thing of it is that Control asked if I
		wouldn't mind changing places with him: me to
		run the Secret Service for a week, he to have a stab
		at painting an erotic mural in Earl's Court.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Ah. I expect he's wanting to keep his undercover
		hand in.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Very probably. So, Mr Murchison, have you got
		any secret documents you'd like me to sign?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well Control number two, I just need your
		permission to allocate funds for the purchase of
		the new safe house in Kensington that nobody
		knows the address of. Here are the estate
		agent's details.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(Looking through) Oh, no Murchison. I can't
		possibly authorise our spending money on a house
		which has floral carpets and plain curtains.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ah.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And look at the wallpaper in the hall. Far too busy.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Right. I'll get to work on finding something more
		appropriate.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes please.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Meanwhile ... would a coffee be helpful at all?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well, I'd love a lemon tea if you can manage it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well well well! Control?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Even if I hadn't guessed earlier I'd know now that
		you aren't the real Control. Because Control?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The real Control never has lemon tea. Always
		coffee.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Voh!
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	One lemon tea coming up, though.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(Blindfolded sipping first at a glass 
		of red wine and then at a glass of 
		white) It's a trick. They're both
		red. (Taking off blindfold) Well,
		well, well. That's extraordinary.
		Ha, ha, ha. Don't show this
		will you. I'm a wine merchant, I
		shall cop frightful stick at work.
		Good Lord! Ha! (He's not that 
		amused in fact)
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen and Hugh enter with their mouths gagged with 
	tape, like anti-nuclear protestors (according to Hugh,
	who knows about these things).'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Owing to the inaudibility of the irrepressible twosome, '}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Mm ... mmm ... mmm mmm.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ng ... ng ... ng ... ng ...
		
	It is understood that the following dialogue is subtitled.
	Where it says Hugh and Stephen they will in fact 
	be mumbling. The obliques strokes indicate where a 
	seperate caption is required.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Good evening ladies and gentlemen/welcome to "A
		Bit Of Fry and Laurie".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hello.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Before we go any further, we should explain/ our
		rather unconventional appearance this evening.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes, you normally sit on the left, don't you?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Nice gag, Hugh.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Thanks, I made it myself.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(To audience) We have a problem/ with our first
		item this evening ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Only a slight one, though.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes, we've licked bigger problems that this/ eh
		Hugh?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes, there was that funny time when ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh shut up.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	We are wearing these gags as a protest
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Write on
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Our first item tonight, my sweet little
		honeyclusters/ is a searing insight into real life,/
		and perforce relies on using/ the language of
		the street.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Swearwords ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Swearwords, exactly. But we have been banned
		from using actual swearwords
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Bastards
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So we have had to make up new ones /which are
		absolutely pitiless in their detail./
		
	Hugh rips off his gag.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And nobody can stop us from using them. Here
		they are ...
		
	Stephen rips off his gag. From now on, we are out loud.
		
		"Cloff".
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	"Prunk" ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	"Shote" ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	"Cucking" ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	"Skank" ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	"Fusk" ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	"Pempslider" ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No, we said we wouldn't use that one.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Did we?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes, that's going too far.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What, "pempslider"?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Shut up.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Sorry.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And lastly, "pim-hole".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hah.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So, here it is, ladies and gentlemen, our first
		sketch ... and good luck ...
		'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Cut to '}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm afraid I was very much the
		traditionalist. I went down on
		one knee and dictated a proposal
		which my secretary faxed over
		straight away.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen is a barrister. He is questioning Hugh, a police 
	sergeant who is in the witness box. There is an elderly,
	fruity sort of Judge, Ralph, and a nasty-looking piece of 
	work in the dock.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Can you tell us, Sergeant Henderson, what the
		prisoner said to you when you made the arrest?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	If I may consult my notes, m'lud?
"}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	Certainly, certainly, certainly. By all means. Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I apprehended the accused and advised him of his
		rights. He replied "Why don't you ram it up your
		pim-hole, you fusking cloff prunker."
		
	There is a sensation in the jury box. A woman screams 
	and two men faint clean away. Judge purses his lips 
	and makes a note.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	"Why don't you ram it up your pim-hole you
		fusking ..." er, cloth-blanket was it?
		
	Another scream. The sound of a juryman being sick.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Er, I believe it was ... er ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	(Testily) Yes, yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Cloff-prunker m'lud.
		
	Sharp intakes of breath all round.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	(Bemused) I see. Forgive my ignorance
		Mr Clarkson, but what exactly is a "cloff-prunker?"
		
	Another sigh of horror. Stephen is mightily 
	embarrassed.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well m'lud it's ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	(Impatiently) Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It's ... hem ... an illicit practice whereby one
		person ... erm ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	Well?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Whereby one person frangilates another's
		slimp, m'lud.
"}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	(Staggered) He does what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	He or she gratifies the other person by ...
		smuctating them avially.
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	Good lord. How absolutely disgusting. Do people
		really do that sort of thing?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I believe so, m'lud.
"}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	In which case I dare say there are probably
		magazines devoted to this practice?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Very possibly, M'lud.
"}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	Are you planning to introduce any of these
		publications in evidence, Mr Clarkson?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I hadn't thought it wholly necessary, M'Lud.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hmm. Slapdash, Mr Clarkson. Slapdash. Well.
		Carry on, carry on.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Thank you m'lud. Now Sergeant. After arresting
		the accused, I believe you questioned him at the
		station. You have a transcript of the interrogation?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes, sir. I asked him if he could explain his
		whereabouts on the night in question. He replied
		"I was in all night, wasn't I, you pempslider."
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	Pempslider?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	A pempslider, M'Lud is ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	(Irritated) Yes thank you, Mr Clarkson, I am not
		entirely uneducated in these matters.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I beg you pardon, M'Lud.
"}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	I did go to Winchester, you know.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Quite so, m'lud. If you would continue, Sergeant.
		He called you a pempslider.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That is correct. And then ... then, he called
		me a ... I wonder if I might have a glass of
		water, m'lud?
"}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': "
	Certainly not. This isn't America.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	He said "Skank off, you cloffing cuck, you're all a
		load of shote-bag fuskers, so prunk that up your
		prime-ministering pim-hole."
		
	Complete pandemonium from all save the Judge who 
	looks at the accused sternly. A policeman behind him 
	is clutching a handkerchief to his mouth and heaving.
	Accused looks smug.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Whimpering faintly) My God.
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	And what did you say to that, Sergeant?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(Consulting notes) I told him to mind his fucking
		language, m'lud.
"}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	(Approvingly) I should think so too.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You see, it's a problem of
		discipline. Young people know
		nothing of service. They should
		all be forced to do some time
		in the army. There's muggings,
		rapings, beatings, violence, cruelty
		- fair enough, that's the army.
		But at least it teaches you how
		to serve.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen pirouettes onto what is already becoming 
	known as "the area".'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Last year I was overweight, short of breath, flabby
		and - it grieves me to say it, however sexily I
		might contrive to do so - unhappy. Since then
		a friend introduced me to Dancercises. I won't
		tell you who the friend was, but if I drop the hint
		that it was a prominent quantity surveyor, I think
		you'll guess. He put me onto "Dancercises" and
		I must say it was the finest thing he's done in his
		otherwise futile and meaningless life. The key to
		Dancercise is the rather ingenious coupling of the
		word "Dance" to the word "circumcise". The great
		disadvantage with most forms of keep-fit is that
		they are uncomfortable, unnatural and can often
		throw too much strain on the important parts of
		your family. And, let's be utterly frank, they can
		look and sound peculiar and embarrassing if
		performed in public. Dancing, or more properly,
		Dance, is natural and expressive. Let's suppose
		I'm a prominent Quantity Surveyor and Hugh
		is Geoffrey Cavendish, a client. While I work,
		you can see that it is easy to fit in toning and
		strengthening movements.
		Goes over to where Hugh is.
		Morning Geoffrey.
		Does a little dance.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hello Dennis.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Got any quantities for me to survey this morning?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I've got a quantity that I'd love for you to survey if
		you're not too busy, Dennis.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Moving and jiving freely) Yes. This quantity here?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's the fellow.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(Surveying it) Well, that's got that quantity
		surveyed? Any others?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's all for today.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Thanks, Geoffrey. You'll let me know?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh, Dennis. If there are any other quantities I
		find and I want them surveyed, you'll be the first
		to know.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	As I see it one American life
		is the same as two European
		lives, four Japanese lives, seventy
		African lives and three hundred
		Central American lives. At least
		that was at the close of business
		yesterday.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen is in the area, finishing off polishing his desk 
	with a duster and a can of Pledge.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	It is our firm belief on "A Bit Of Fry and Laurie",
		married to a passionate girl from Stockton-on-
		Tees, that there is a right way and a wrong way to
		do everything.
		
	He is walking out across the central set now towards a 
	doorway set.
	
		So I and my "partner in crime", Hugh Laurie.
		(He finds this inordinately amusing) My "partner in
		crime"!!! No, I call him that, but that's not really
		what he is. We don't really commit crimes together
		of any kind. That's just a ghastly and unacceptable
		phrase that I like to use sometimes. So, anyway,
		I and my, as I say, "partner in crime!" ... (Wipes 
		eyes) Honestly! ... are now going to demonstrate
		the right way and the wrong way to treat a couple
		of young children who have come round on
		Hallowe'en a-trick or treating.
		
	Hugh is waiting wearing something rather odd and 
	looking very excited.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's right!!! Now, we're going to play it like this.
		Firstly we're going to show you the Wrong Way,
		that's THE WRONG WAY, and then we're going
		to show you the Right Way. I'll say that again ...
		He doesn't.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Good. So all we need now is to wait for the
		doorbell to ring.
		They wait.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Nice carpet, Hugh. Tideyman's?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Who else, if you'll pardon the pun.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What pun?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh, wasn't there one? Sorry.
		
	Doorbell rings.
		
		Ah, the door.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	We'll answer it, shall we?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Sounds like a hot suggestion to me.
		
	They answer the door. Two children stand without,
	wearing Hallowe'en masks.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Child 1', 'text': '
	Trick or treat, mister.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ah!
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Toh!
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Let me see, did we prepare a little bag of jelly
		beans out back?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	We most certainly did, I'll go fetch them.
		
	Hugh is left alone with the children. He ruffles the hair 
	of one of them.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	So. You fond of football, young shaver-snapper?
'}, {'speaker': 'Child 2', 'text': '
	Yeah.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Do you fancy Arsenal this year?
'}, {'speaker': 'Child 2', 'text': '
	No way. I quite fancy my sister though.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Disconcerted) Ahmm ... er ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Coming through) There we go.
		
	He ruffles their hair.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Child 1', 'text': '
	Ta.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Bye now.
		
	Stephen shuts the door and smiles.
		That was the wrong way. THE WRONG WAY!!
		Now for the RIGHT WAY. I won't say that ever
		again. The Right Way, the RIGHT Way.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Nice pun, Hugh. Tideyman's?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Who else, if you'll pardon the carpet.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What carpet?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh wasn't there one? Sorry.
		
	Doorbell rings.
		
		Ah, the hot suggestion.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	We'll answer it, shall we?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Sounds like a door to me.
		
	They answer the door: two children stand without,
	wearing Hallowe'en masks.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Child 1', 'text': '
	Trick or treat, mister.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	WHAT did you say?
'}, {'speaker': 'Child 1', 'text': '
	Trick or treat.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Trick or treat?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Trick or treat?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Come here.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Both of you. NOW!!!
		
	The children approach. A bit scared.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Hurling child number one bodily out of the door) This
		is England, not America.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Doing the same to number two) NOT AMERICA!!
		You understand?
		
	Both children have flown out of the door.
		
		You see? A right way, and a wrong way.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	We thank you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Limply.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(With an electronic organiser) Ask
		me anything, a telephone number,
		what time it is in Adelaide. Tell
		you what, I can tell you exactly
		what I'll be doing on the third
		of August 1997, say. Hang on
		(Presses a few buttons). Nothing.
		See, it says. Nothing.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen answers the door. Hugh is standing there in 
	delivery man gear, with clipboard.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Morning. Mrs Bennett?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Pardon?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Are you Mrs Bennett?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Wait a minute. Wait a minute. Can you prove that?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Prove what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm not being rude, it's just that for all I know
		you might be a conman answering doors and
		pretending not to be Mrs Bennett. Lot of that
		goes on.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well ... will a Driving Licence do?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Not really, no. You might have stolen it, you see.
		Anything else you can show me, to prove you're
		not Mrs Bennett?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	How about Mrs Bennett?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Sorry, not with you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	If I show you Mrs Bennett, would that prove I
		wasn't her?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It's a start.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Darling!
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No, I was calling my wife. I'm Mr Bennett.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Darling!
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No, look, don't bother. If you're Mr Bennett, you
		can sign for them. Would you mind?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Certainly. What are they?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Some breasts.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Pardon?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Your wife ordered a quantity of breasts from
		us, and we promised we'd have them here by
		Wednesday.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Today's Friday.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	We had a puncture.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Wait a minute, what's she doing ordering breasts?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Search me.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I mean for heaven's sake she's already got some.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Tscch. Women. Don't start me off. They're never
		happy, are they? Just sign there for me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	"Breasts times three". Three?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Spare.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I see. Well thanks very much.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Aren't you going to check the box?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Why?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well ... make sure they're all right.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'm sure they're fine.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Mmm. We do get a lot of mix-ups.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	All right, then ... one, two, three. They look fine.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ermm ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	D'you mind if I have a look?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I beg your pardon?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Just to check.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You want to look at my wife's breasts?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You are asking me if you can look at my wife's
		breasts?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Just a peek.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Showing the box) Tssch. All right then.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Phwor. Not bad are they?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I suppose they're all right.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	All right? They're fantastic. You're a lucky feller.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Mmm. Actually, I'm a leg man myself.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Really?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Funnily enough, I've got some legs in the back of
		the van if you're interested.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Have you?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yeah. Make a nice surprise gift for your wife.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No, I shouldn't really. She's up to her waist in
		legs as it is.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	They're a bit special.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Are they?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Definitely.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen is at a desk. There is a knock at the door,
	and Hugh enters.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hello, Control.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Tony. It's you.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's right. I understand from Valerie that you
		wanted reasonably strongly to see me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Valerie is by no means leading you up the garden
		path, Tony, because I do want to see you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I find Valerie's usually right in these little matters.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ng.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Control?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes, Tony?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Did you want, I'm wondering, to speak to me
		as well, or was it just seeing me that was on
		your mind?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well now Tony, there was something I wanted to
		ask you, but it's a little bit tricky actually.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Tricky?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes, Tony. Have you ever been in the position
		where you've had to tell someone you like quite a
		lot that you've got to fire them from their job?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ah.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That didn't turn out to be too tricky a thing to ask
		me, did it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes. Thing is, Tony, I haven't quite said the really
		tricky thing yet.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ah. Would it be the kind of thing that would go
		better with a good cup of coffee, Control?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Perhaps a little later, Tony. I wouldn't want to be
		thought of as hiding behind that cup of coffee.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's just as well, Control, because the cup of
		coffee I had in mind was going to be quite small.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Tell me Tony, have you, in your position as
		subsection chief of the East German and related
		satellites desk, noticed the way the wind is blowing
		on the other side of the curtain?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It's been blowing in odd kinds of ways, hasn't it,
		Control?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	It has, Tony. Glasnost, perestroika and related
		phenomena have had their effect on the political
		map of Europe in no uncertain terms.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes, Control. Only this morning, I had to ask
		Valerie if she wouldn't mind going out and buying
		some new political maps of Europe, as ours were
		really quite out of date.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes, it's shaken all our lives up a bit, certainly. But
		Tony ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes, Control?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It's also meant that our masters in Whitehall have
		started wondering whether they need quite so
		many people involved with spying.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm not sure I fully understand, Control.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well they take the view, Tony, that nowadays, with
		the Russians simply ringing us up and telling us
		most of their secrets, we don't need to spend such
		a lot of money on finding them out.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's an astute piece of political thinking by our
		masters in Whitehall, Control.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes, Tony, it is.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	How about that coffee now, Control?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No, Tony. Not yet. Anyway, what this is all leading
		up to, Tony, if you haven't already guessed, is that
		I'm going to have to fire you from your job.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Control. I'm slightly at a loss for words.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Please don't think, Tony, that I'm getting any
		enjoyment out of this situation. This is one of the
		hardest things I've ever had to do in all my years
		of running the Secret Service.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Mmm. I certainly don't envy you, Control, having
		to pass on a bit of news like the one you've just
		passed on to me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes, it is very hard, Tony.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh well, Control. I suppose that's that, then.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes, Tony, I'm afraid it is. I really am very sorry.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	May I take this opportunity of saying how much
		I've enjoyed working with you, Control, and wish
		you the very best of luck with all your future spying.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Thank you Tony. I can honestly say that this place
		won't be the same without you.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No, I suppose it will be a bit different because I
		won't be here.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's right.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'll be somewhere else.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well goodbye, Control.
		
	They shake hands.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Goodbye, Murchison.
		
	Hugh exits. Stephen sits down again and blows his 
	nose. He picks up the phone.
		
		Valerie? Could you bring me a cup of coffee?
		(Pause) How do I like it? I like it the way Tony
		Murchison used to make it.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	If things had worked out
		differently it's strange to think I
		would now be Foreign Secretary
		and Douglas Hurd would be an
		assistant librarian. Wierd, isn't it?
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	The Robert Robinsons each have behind them a word 
	roller, like the one on '}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ah, well now yes, good evening. That much is
		certain.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Though tish ah, nay, hush and fourpence,
		Mr Dwyer.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And an extra point for being so clever!
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Would that it were, would that it were.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ah, indeed, would that it were, Mr Charteris,
		would that it were.
		
	They both ping their bells and the words "pompous" and 
	"insufferable" appear.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Here's a thing, not that pish and tish.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I have a letter from a Colin Elgood of Carshalton
		Beeches telling me he turns his carrier bags
		inside out so as not to give free advertising to
		Mr Sainsbury and men of his ilk.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Nay men of his stamp.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Of his ilk, stamp and kidney.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	You answer is better Mr Meredith, so much
		better but wrong, sadly wrong.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And an extra mark for being clever!
		
	They ping and the words "self-satisfied" and "fraudulent" 
	appear.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ah, we have a plump! Someone has plumped. Go
		on, Mr Harris, have a plump too.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hish, tusk, ah now, it only remains for me to
		declare the Twee family winners of our little game.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	An extra mark followed by this round of applause.
		
	Ping! The words "absurd" and "gasbag" appear.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ah, the pity of it, the pity. Time, our old enemy,
		comes round again.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Nish, tussock, flimp and fivepence.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	We bid you goodbye.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	We bid you farewell.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	But ah, though, flish, bish and trivvock, not
		for ever.
		
	Ping! The words "sod" and "off"
	
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(As policeman) There's method
		in my madness. Ha, ha, ha!!!!!
		(Madly)
	
"}]

[{'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Did you ... I don't know, you may have done
		... last night ... see that Horizon ... er ...
		documentary, is it? Is that what they're called?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Horizon documentary, yes, I think so. You mean,
		on the er ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Television.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Television, that's right.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes, television. I think it's a ... documentary. Did
		you see it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No. I didn't, I'm afraid. I was out last night.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh dear, you didn't record it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Record it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh I see what you mean. No, we've got one of
		those er ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Recording ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes, those machines that record ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Recording machines ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Is that what they're ...?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I think so.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes, well, we've got one, but I'm afraid neither of
		us knows how to use it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh how terribly amusing.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It is, isn't it? Amusing and eccentric.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Terribly.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes I'm just hopeless with anything mechanical ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh me too. My wife gave me an electric
		toothbrush last Christmas, and I just can't work it
		out at all ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh how amusing and eccentric.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Isn't it? Isn't it incredibly amusing and eccentric?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I can't even work an ordinary toothbrush.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Can't you?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No, I keep putting the wrong end into my mouth,
		and the toothpaste up my nose ... I'm hopeless.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Me too.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	My wife looks at me with one of those looks of
		hers that seems to say er ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	How amusing and eccentric?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Exactly.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes, there's another one of those documentaries on
		tonight, apparently.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Really? Oh well I might watch it, then. What time,
		do you know?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Half past eight, I believe.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Half past eight, yes, that's when the big hand is
		pointing ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh don't ask me. I can't deal with these
		confounded watch things ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No, neither can I. My daughter gave this to me,
		and I can't get the hang of it ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No, I'm much too amusing and eccentric to ...
		you know ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Me too. Far too amusing and eccentric.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	But I think it's at half past eight. It should be in
		the paper, anyway.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Newspapers? Haha ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hahaha ... me too.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Never know which way to turn the blasted page.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Get it upside down ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	All over the place ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I always give the paper to our young son to
		read, he's the only one who can work the
		confounded thing.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Honestly. We are amusing and eccentric aren't we?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes.
		
	Bell rings.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hello!
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Best be in the House for that debate on the
		electricity privatisation.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Absolutely.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I suppose if I'm honest I use my
		penis as a sort of car substitute.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen addresses camera. His hair is wild and 
	peculiar. He stares through thick, black-rimmed 
	spectacles.'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh is playing "I vow to thee my country" throughout 
	on the piano.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ladies and gentlemen, bear with me. Bear with
		me please. Don't stop bearing with me for a few
		moments. I have a vision, a vision of Britain. I see
		a country peopled by ... a country peopled by
		people who, who ... people it with charm, with
		grace, yes even with greatness. As they people it,
		they enhance it with their lightness, their amusing
		accents, their v-neck sweaters and their unusual
		children. This country shall be free and wide and
		pretty, and their people shall be free and wide and
		pretty. And there shall be villages and towns and
		family amusement theme heritage fun parks which
		shall smell of urine and vomit. And there shall be
		twelve water and sewage businesses and leisure
		dromes and huge edge-of-town crematoriums
		and day-glo bermuda shorts which are flecked
		with urine and vomit. I see "Impact" as a new kind
		of flexible high-yield convenient cash and care
		card for the kind of person you are today and I
		hear the sound of many thousands of miles of
		motorways, conveniently filled with many hundreds
		of thousands of cars whose seats are stained with
		children and urine and vomit. And the interior of
		the cars shall be sweaty and hot and bad-tempered
		and the queue for the exit that leads to the family
		amusement heritage theme fun park shall be
		hundreds of miles long. And there shall be shiny
		magazines out of which will fall many dozens
		of smaller shiny magazines which shall offer
		useful electronic golfing equipment and wall safes
		disguised as three pin sockets and bright security
		lamps and personal attack alarms and hand
		freshen-up absorbent pads to soak up the urine
		and the vomit. And the faces of the people who
		are peopling this Britain shall be shiny and they
		shall be flushed and pink for they shall know that
		they are forging a new Britain of fun and heritage
		and family leisure amusement and the boot of their
		car shall easily accomodate the self-assembly fun
		park that they shall erect in their bathrooms. As
		yet, it is all only a vision, a vision of family heritage
		urine and fun leisure amenity vomit. But soon,
		soon, with luck, sincerity and steadfast voting it
		may become a reality.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	My father was a Conservative and
		my mother voted Labour so by
		rights I suppose I should vote
		Liberal Democrat. But in fact
		I'm a Nazi. Funny how things
		turn out.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	We live, don't we, in an increasingly age. Where
		once the village post office, a mug of Horlicks,
		Bing Crosby songs and a Kenneth More film were
		the only things the average Britain had to fear,
		nowadays every alleyway can conceal a threat, every
		encounter a violent confrontation, every telephone
		call an erotic nightmare. Arnold.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's right. It has become increasingly and
		abundantly that unscrupulous people have traded
		on the fear that now stalks the streets. Open any
		local newspaper or give-away sheet and you can
		read advertisements for self-defence classes in
		hai-ki-doh, ken-doh, play-doh, judo and a whole
		stain of martial arts. But people who answer the
		threat of violence with real violence of their own
		often find that it is they who end up in court, not
		their assailants. Nerelle.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's right. If you live in the Boroughbridge area
		of North Yorkshire you might have read this article
		in your local copy of the Helperby and Cundall
		Advertiser.
"}, {'speaker': 'Voice-over', 'text': '
	"Discover Dr Patrick Fisher's amazing
		new key to non-violent self-defence. Repel
		mugger, rapists, attackers, insurance-salesmen,
		burglars, Christians and house-breakers without
		harm or fear of prosecution. Simply send 3.00 for
		Fisher's Guide To Non-Physical Violence." Dwoyne.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Thanks. Well, we're never one to resist a challenge
		so we duly sent off for Dr Fisher's book. Fwith.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's right. Moylinda.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The "book" turned out to be this. (Holds up flimsy 
		pamphlet) The secret method that Dr Fisher
		recommends? Well, it seems that there are two
		basic approaches.
		
	Hugh & Stephen read them alternately, starting with 
	Stephen.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	"1. The Flirty Come-on."
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	"2. The Disorientating Remark." Testina.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Thanks. So we decided to try this method out for
		ourselves. F-f-f-f.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes indeed. We went out into Chichester's
		notorious East Gate and waited for the inevitable
		assault.
"}, {'speaker': 'Caption', 'text': '
	"1. The Flirty Come-on."
		
	Hugh is loitering on a bench, an expensive-looking 
	briefcase on his lap. He is counting the money in 
	his wallet.

		A mugger sidles up next to him and whips out a knife.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Mugger', 'text': '
	(Waving it under his nose) You know what this is?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes. I do actually. Sweet of you to try and help me
		out, but I do actually know what it is.
'}, {'speaker': 'Mugger', 'text': '
	Right. Wallet.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Wall ... oh for heaven's sake you're mugging me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Mugger', 'text': "
	That's right.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh, now you've ... oh. Of all the people here ...
		you've picked on little old me. I don't know what
		to say. I think I'm going to cry.
"}, {'speaker': 'Mugger', 'text': '
	Wallet.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Of course, of course. Hold on, I'll just take the
		money and things out first, otherwise you'll have to
		lug them around all day, and there'll be no room
		for your own stuff.
"}, {'speaker': 'Mugger', 'text': '
	Look, get a move on.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh sorry, of course. You've got things to do, of
		course you have, and here's me nattering away
		twelve to the dozen.
"}, {'speaker': 'Mugger', 'text': '
	Oh forget it.
'}, {'speaker': 'Caption', 'text': '
	"2. The Disorientating Remark."
		
	Stephen is in an alleyway, he bends down to tie his 
	shoe-laces. A man comes up from behind.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Man', 'text': "
	Right. Do as I say and you won't get hurt. Lie
		down in that corner and drop 'em.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I had an Uncle Geoffrey that looked just like you.
		He wasn't so old then and tasted slightly wider.
"}, {'speaker': 'Man', 'text': '
	Did you hear what I just said?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I've got a note from matron you know.
"}, {'speaker': 'Man', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Unless you go away from here and leave me alone
		completely I'll write a poem in Lebanese and send
		it straight to Gary Lineker's doctor.
"}, {'speaker': 'Man', 'text': '
	Just get down in that corner.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Shouting) My name is an anagram of the
		Metropolitan Police and unless you stay here and
		do exactly as you tell me your breasts will become
		the property of Gerald Kaufman.
'}, {'speaker': 'Man', 'text': '
	(Pushing Stephen to the floor and unbuckling his belt) I
		said GET DOWN!
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Right-o. Fair enough. I should just mention
		though, that you can't fit quicker than a
		Kwikfit Fitter.
		
	Back to studio.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	So. A warning there. If Dr Fisher's Advertisement
		should find its way into your High Street Give-
		Away Market Trading Advertiser Sheet our advice
		is Trish.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's right. And remember. Dermidge.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	So, until. It's.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Bye.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well I was given one of those
		personal organisers, so when I
		went into work everyone said
		"You're a bit of a yuppie!!!" It
		was so funny. Because yuppies
		are those new people you know
		who are very trendy. "A bit of a
		yuppie!" Dear oh dear. That's
		probably the funniest thing that's
		ever happened to me.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh and Stephen are in a London club sort of place.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Freddy.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh, good heavens, Jack, I didn't see you there.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Good evening, Freddy.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, good evening, Jack.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Now then, Freddy you're a decent sort of chap.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, I, yes, I think so Jack, yes, I try to be a
		decent sort of chap, yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Mmmm. Can I ask you a question, Freddy?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ask away, ask-a-bloody-way.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Are you one of us?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Am I one of us?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Am I one of us?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Not entirely sure I understand your question, Jack.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Let me put it another way.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh, would you Jack, yes, well, I'd be enormously
		grateful.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Do you believe in the cause?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The cause ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	The Cause of Freedom.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, Jack I suppose, generally, yes, yes, I do. If
		anyone's passing the hat round for freedom, I'll
		bung in a quid or two, Jack, yes.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I thought so, I thought so from the first.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes, I'm one of us Jack, if you want to put it
		that way.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Excellent.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Phew, well, we got there in the end, Jack, sorted
		that one out.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	It gets a bit more complicated now.
