		BBC do not advise that you watch the unfolding of
		this dark tale if you are in any way of an erotic
		disposition.
		
		He walks towards an office set.
		
		Office life. Ha! It seems so ordinary, doesn't it?
		So mundane. What is the worst that can happen in an
		ordinary publisher's office? Susie loses the Tippex.
		Carol forgets to fax that contract to Stuttgart. The
		wrong manuscript is DHL-ed to San Francisco.
		Nothing sinister about a modern office. Is there?
		Is there? Or is there?

		Jonathan Hadey. A nice guy. One of the world's
		good scouts. Governor of his local primary school.
		Rotarian. Chief High Coven Priest of the Amersham
		and District Satanic Abuse Club. An ordinary,
		decent British guy. Every day is much like the day
		before for publisher Jonathan Hadey. Except today.
		Except April the twenty-ninth of October. Oh yes,
		except for today ...
		
	Camera has been zooming in on Hugh, and Stephen's 
	last few words are over. The telephone on Hugh's desk 
	rings.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(Over) Louise is out of the office, flirting with
		Ted from marketing while she makes Jonathan's
		mid-morning coffee. He might as well answer the
		telephone himself for once.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hello?
'}, {'speaker': 'Voice', 'text': '
	(Telephone distort) I want to speak to Jonathan Hadey.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	This is him ... he ... him. I mean ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Voice', 'text': '
	You have the Red Hat of Patferrick.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Voice', 'text': "
	Don't play games, Mr Hadey. You have just seven
		hours to return it to its rightful owner.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Shall I put you through to marketing?
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Phone click. Dialling tone.'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh stares into the phone. Puts it down slowly.'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Louise enters with a coffee.'}, {'speaker': 'Louise', 'text': '
	Sorry I took my time, Mr Hadey, but Ted
		from marketing was licking my breasts. Who was
		that?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I don't know. A wrong number probably ...
		except they asked for me. Something about a
		hat.
"}, {'speaker': 'Louise', 'text': '
	(Slightly guilty, suspicious) A hat?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes, a hat from Portmerrick or something.
'}, {'speaker': 'Louise', 'text': '
	Not ... Patferrick?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes! That's it! The hat of Patferrick.
"}, {'speaker': 'Louise', 'text': '
	(Terrified, but trying to hide it) Did they say what
		... what ... colour?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The red hat I think they said.
'}, {'speaker': 'Louise', 'text': "
	(Screams) No! Not red! Please God not red. No,
		no, no, no!
		
	She runs to the open window behind Hugh's desk 
	and throws herself out.

		Hugh rushes to the window and looks down.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	My God, Louise ... oh sweet Jesus heaven,
		Louise why ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Louise', 'text': "
	(Off) I can't explain Mr Hadey.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	But for the Lord's sake girl. Whatever it is, you
		can't stay down there.
"}, {'speaker': 'Louise', 'text': "
	If you don't mind Mr Hadey I will. For the
		time being.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	But ...
		Hugh is interrupted by a voice off behind him. It is the voice of Gerald Dandridge, his boss.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Dandridge', 'text': '
	Hadey!
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Spinning round) Mr Dandridge!
'}, {'speaker': 'Dandridge', 'text': "
	Can't have my editorial directors staring out of the
		window all day. Not got enough work to do?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No, sir it's not that ... it's ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Dandridge', 'text': '
	Well, man ... speak up.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm afraid Louise is ... behaving rather oddly.
"}, {'speaker': 'Dandridge', 'text': '
	Probably her time of the curse or whatever they
		call it. Give her the day off.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes, that's probably it. Got rather upset about
		some sort of Hat. The Pink Hat of ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Dandridge', 'text': '
	(Gasping in fright and astonishment) Pink hat?
		Did you say pink hat?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Surprised) Well ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Dandridge', 'text': '
	The hat of ... the Pink Hat of where, man?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well it was some phone call ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Dandridge', 'text': "
	(Grasping Hugh's collar) In the name of mercy,
		Jonathan! THE PINK HAT OF WHERE?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, I think he said Patferrick ... does that sound
		right?
'}, {'speaker': 'Dandridge', 'text': "
	(Instantly relieved and relaxed) Patferrick? Oh that's
		all right. The Pink Hat of Patferrick. Fine,
		my boy. Fine.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well come to think of it, it was red, the Red
		Hat of Patferrick, he said.
'}, {'speaker': 'Dandridge', 'text': '
	(Hugely loud scream) No! Oh suffering hell,
		NO!!!! The Red Hat of Patferrick!!
		
	Dandridge runs to the window and jumps out.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Sir! Mr Dandridge?
		
	Pause.
		
		Mr Dandridge? Sir?
'}, {'speaker': 'Dandridge', 'text': '
	(After a pause. Hissed whisper) Go away!
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	But what are you ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Louise', 'text': '
	Please, Mr Hadey. Just leave us alone.
'}, {'speaker': 'Dandridge', 'text': '
	Buzz off.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh. Right.
		
	Hugh backs away from the window, scratching his chin 
	and very puzzled. The telephone rings very loudly in his 
	ear.

		(Answering it) Hello? ... Police? ... Yes, what is
		it? My wife ... what kind of accident? Oh my God
		... squashed! In heaven's name, what by? A hat? A
		hat? What kind of hat? Sort of maroony, burgundy-ish
		crimson. Damn it man, you mean red. If it's red say
		so. A red hat ... from the dust on the brim it could
		only come from one place, you say? Don't tell me, I
		already know. Patferrick. My God, it was the Red
		Hat of Patferrick.
		
	He drops the telephone and buries his head in his arms.

		Louise enters with a coffee and shakes him on the shoulder.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Louise', 'text': "
	Wake up, Mr Hadey. It's your coffee.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What ... I ... the pat ... the hat ... the redferrick
		of hatpat ... I ... oh.
'}, {'speaker': 'Louise', 'text': "
	Dreaming again, Mr Hadey. I don't know.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	But it was so ... so real. (Laughing) What's the
		matter with me? I think I need a holiday.
"}, {'speaker': 'Louise', 'text': '
	Oh there's a man on his way up to see you. Says he's
		bringing "The Red Hat of ..." somewhere or other.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	NO!!! Oh my Christing hell-god no! The red
		hat of where? Speak, girl.
'}, {'speaker': 'Louise', 'text': '
	Well Pat-something, I think he said.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh God, no. The Red Hat of Patferrick! No.
		
	Hugh runs and jumps out of the window. Louise 
	clutches her cheeks and screams.

		Enter Stephen as Gelliant Gutfright. A bundle of 
	papers under his arm.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Something wrong, my dear?
'}, {'speaker': 'Louise', 'text': "
	It's Mr Hadey, he just ... twenty-three floors
		up and he just ... oh! (She shudders)
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Ah. Well. I had better take The Red Hat of Patferrick
		somewhere else, hadn't I?
"}, {'speaker': 'Louise', 'text': "
	The Red Hat ... that's why Mr Hadey jumped.
		What is it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh just a manuscript of a story my dear. A wholly
		improbable tale. It concerns a young publisher who
		has a dream about a hat, and when he awakes ...
		but it is (turns and stares into the camera) nothing
		but fancy. It could never really happen. Could it?
		Could it? Or could it? Perhaps it could. Or could
		it? Goodnight.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
		I've found that young people are no
			longer enticed into church simply
			on the promise of guitars and a
			little folk music. We have to move
			with the times. We've started
			showing leather and bondage films
			in St Barnabas's and the results
			have been very good. We were
			packed last Sunday. Mostly Young
			Conservatives, but it's a start.
		
	"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen enters a bookshop. Hugh is the assistant.
	Stephen stares at Hugh for a long time.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Help you?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Holding up a book) Did you write this?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Examining book) Jane Eyre. No, that was Charlotte
		Bronte as a matter of fact.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Right. Well I'd like to see her then please.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm afraid she's no longer with us.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh? Indeed? I can hardly say I'm surprised. Where
		can I get in touch with her?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No, no. I mean "no longer with us" in the sense
		of "dead".
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Dead?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Quite dead.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	When did she die exactly?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Um ... 1855 I believe I'm right in saying.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Let me see, 1855, that's five minutes to seven, isn't it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I'm sorry. I mean "1855" in the sense of the year
		"1855". Was there some problem?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well you'll have to do I suppose, since you sold
		me the book. I want my money back.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Do you mind me asking why?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'll tell you why. Because this book is balls, that's
		why. It is complete balls.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm afraid I really can't agree with you there.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh can't you? Well listen to this then ... (riffles 
		through book and selects a passage) "I mounted into
		the window-seat: gathering up my feet, I sat
		cross-legged, like a Turk." I mean???? It's just
		balls.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Balls in what sense?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Balls in the sense of balls. I mean "window-seat"?
		What window-seat? This is on the first page. Window
		seat. Where is this window seat, hm? What's it doing?
		And what Turk? I've never seen a Turk mount a
		window-seat. Simply balls. Nothing but balls.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well I think you're supposed to imagine it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ho? All right, then, all right then: what about
		this ... um ... chapter thirty-eight ... "Reader, I
		married him." Now if that isn't balls, kindly fax me
		an explanation of what is. "Reader"? What reader? Or
		are you supposed to imagine this reader as well?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No, that's you. It's addressed to you, the reader
		of the book.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	OH BALLS. How could she know me? You just
		told me the stupid tart died at five to seven.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well not you specifically. I mean whoever is reading it
		at the time. Jane Eyre is telling you that she married
		Mr Rochester.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Jane Eyre is a made-up character! Kyor! She
		didn't exist.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No but she writes the story. She is the "I" of the story.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	MAKE YOUR FRIGGING MIND UP. You just
		told me Charlotte Bronte wrote the story.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	She did ... but ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well you're clearly as confused as I am. It's just
		balls and you know it. Complete balls. I want my
		money back. I want to read a book that doesn't go
		on about window-seats you've never even heard of
		and then has some mad bitch who's supposed to be
		dead calling you "reader" all the time.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What about this ... proving very popular.
		
	Hugh hands Stephen a book.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	What's this?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The Invalid by Myra Penworthy Fennerweave.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Any good?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Excellent.
		
	Stephen starts to read.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	"Talbot entered the room in a feverish haste,
		bearing his precious cargo before him like a votive
		offering. Elizabeth lay back on her bed, her face pale
		and pinched. "Richard is that you?" she moaned
		plaintively." Oh this is just complete BALLS! Balls,
		balls, balls.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It's not actually. It's true. It actually happened.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh double balls and bollocks.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I just wish they hadn't called it the
		Common Market. Is that snobbish
		of me? I mean why not the Nice
		Market. It would be so much nicer.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh addresses the camera.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Ladies and gentlemen, I'm extremely lucky to have
		been born physically healthy, physically whole. I have
		two eyes, two arms, two legs, four nipples, I'm physi-
		cally normal and I give thanks for that every single
		day. However, I do have a mental problem. I suffer
		from what psychiatrists call a split personality. No I
		don't. I've had this for some time now, no I haven't,
		but recently it seems to have got worse. How could it
		get worse, if it was never there? At the suggestion of
		my psychiatrist, God what a fraud he is, I have given
		my other personality a name. I call him Anthony.
		Yes, what do you want? Now Anthony is not like
		me. You can say that again. Anthony likes different
		music, books, films, he likes double pleats on his
		trousers, where I prefer single, and if it were up to
		him he would drive a Citreon GX. They happen to be
		extremely stylish cars. But perhaps Anthony's biggest
		problem is that he suffers from a split personality. I
		bloody do not! Anthony's other half, as it were, is
		called Nathaniel, and he claims to be Welsh. What do
		you mean claim, I am Welsh, I just don't happen to
		live there at the moment.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh and Stephen in vests are sitting at a table eating 
	spaghetti, with huge napkins tied round their necks. At 
	the sink is a largish Italian mamma.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I gotta ask you something.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Go 'head.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You sleepin' with my wife?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I said are you ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I heard what you said.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So, you gonna ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What the hell kind of a question is that?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You gonna answer?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hell no.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hell no?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Hell no. It's a dumb question.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Are you sleeping with my wife is a dumb question?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You're damn right.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	So what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Are you sleeping with ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Don't ask me that. Stop asking me that dumb
		question.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	That means yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What the hell means yes? Stop asking me dumb
		questions means yes? What the hell is the matter with
		you?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You haven't answered the question. I asked you
		a question, you haven't answered it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	For Chrissake, I'm eatin' dinner. I'm sittin' here
		eatin' dinner, and you start with these dumb
		questions.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	If you're sleepin' with my wife ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What? What the hell you gonna do?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'll kill you.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You'll kill me?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yeah.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You'll kill your own brother?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yeah.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yeah, well relax. I ain't sleepin' with your wife.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You prove that?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Prove what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You prove you ain't sleepin' with my wife?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	How the hell'm I gonna prove that to you? Uh? What
		would be nice maybe is if you believe me. You know?
		You trust me when I tell you something, instead of
		askin' a lot of dumb questions.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	OK.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	OK what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I believe you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	You believe me?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I believe you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well thank you. Can I eat my dinner now?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sure.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	OK.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You sleepin' with my sister?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Are you sleepin' with ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Wait a minute, wait a minute.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You're my brother, right?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Right.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	So your sister is my sister.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Waddya mean?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Waddya mean waddya mean? You're my brother and
		so your sister is also my sister, we have the same
		sister, you and me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	So? Jesus, you're askin' me if I'm sleepin' with
		my own sister?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Are you?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Am I ... what the hell is the matter with you?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Are you sleepin' with your sister?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	What the hell am I doin', bustin' my balls, sittin'
		here listenin' to this?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You're eatin' spaghetti.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Spaghetti bullshit.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Bolognese.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I come here to eat my dinner, and I'm gettin'
		all this bullshit for what?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	For ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You shut your mouth. All right? Just shut your
		mouth. Sleepin' with my own sister, Jesus.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You sleepin' with my mother?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's it. One more word out of you ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	You know what. You and your dumb bullshit
		questions.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Whose dumb bullshit questions?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Hey, mamma. You hear him? You hear all this
		bullshit he's givin' me?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What bullshit? I ask you a question is all.
'}, {'speaker': 'Mamma', 'text': '
	(English - to camera) Both my boys just adore
		New Ragazzo Sauce.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You sleepin' with my brother?
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Allergies? Well, I'm not good on
		strawberries, come out in a bit
		of a rash. The worst one though
		is Marmite. Only got to smell the
		stuff and I start voting Conserva-
		tive.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	We are in the '}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Right ... so ... er ... right. And ... right ... so
		Simon, I think ... right ... it's your choice, I think.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Wetly) Consonant please, Carol.
		
	A piece of totty puts up a consonant and says its name.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Girl', 'text': '
	Right. Consonant. "B".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Vowel please.
'}, {'speaker': 'Girl', 'text': '
	"O".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Consonant please, Carol.
'}, {'speaker': 'Girl', 'text': '
	"L".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Another consonant please.
'}, {'speaker': 'Girl', 'text': '
	And that's "L" again.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Vowel please, Carol.
'}, {'speaker': 'Girl', 'text': '
	Another "O".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Consonant please.
'}, {'speaker': 'Girl', 'text': '
	"C".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Another consonant please.
'}, {'speaker': 'Girl', 'text': '
	"S".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And another consonant please.
'}, {'speaker': 'Girl', 'text': '
	"K".
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	All right ... right ... so ... right ... right
		... your countdown starts ... now.
		Music, clock ticking etc. as is.

		The thirty seconds are up.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Right ... so ... Simon, how did you get on.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Just four I'm afraid.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Four, just four. Right, so, Liz, how about you?
'}, {'speaker': 'Liz', 'text': '
	Four as well.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Right, four too. So four each there. Very interesting.
		Four each. What was your four Simon?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Lobs.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Lobs. So, lobs. Right. Lobs. Meaning "lobs" I
		suppose. Lobs. Right well let me "lob" it over
		to you Liz and ask you what you got for your four?
'}, {'speaker': 'Liz', 'text': '
	Look.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Look. Look. I think we can allow that. No need
		to "look that one up" in our dictionary. What did our
		guardian of the dictionary find? Anything better?
'}, {'speaker': 'Gyles', 'text': '
	(For it is he) Well now, as a celebrity rather than a
		member of the public, I naturally did rather better
		and came up with "books" for five, or "blocks" for
		six or there is an eight actually.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	An eight ... right .. an eight ... well that's very
		exciting ... an eight ... and what's your eight?
"}, {'speaker': 'Gyles', 'text': '
	Sloblock.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sloblock. Sloblock. So, sloblock. And what does
		sloblock mean, exactly?
'}, {'speaker': 'Gyles', 'text': '
	Basically, and I'm indebted to Myra Perks of East
		Hell for this jumper, by the way ... basically sloblock
		means balls, the things we keep in our scrotums, or
		by extension something that is rubbish or a pile of
		nonsense. "Oh that's a load of sloblock" you might
		say.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Right well let's hope no one thinks this programme
		is "sloblock". Now ... right ... so then ... right
		... it's time for our Conundrum. Thirty seconds
		to solve it and here it comes ... now.
		
	The conundrum appears. Clock ticks etc. The 
	conundrum is the word "pathetic".
	
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'd like to have children, but it's
		just the thought of the actual ...
		you know ... all that yucky ...
		and they say that giving birth is
		pretty horrible too.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	A garden shed: Hugh is in a cardigan trying to 
	mend a lawnmower. Stephen appears in abrupt sort of 
	blazer and stands behind him. Eventually Hugh notices 
	him and jumps.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Good heavens Jack, you gave me such a fright.
		Good Lord. There I was trying to mend the old
		lawnmower, bloody old thing, well of course it's not
		old, it's quite a new lawnmower.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hello Neddy.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well hello, Jack. Sorry. I was wittering rather just
		now. It's just that, well, you know ... lawnmower's
		bust, and ... How are you Jack?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well, thank you Neddy.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well? Oh that is good news. That's quite made my
		day. There I was thinking that the world was a
		pretty bloody sort of a place, where you can pay good
		money for a lawnmower that doesn't even work ...
		but then you tell me that you're well, and suddenly
		things seem to be not so bad after all. Sort of puts
		everything into perspective ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Neddy?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Jack.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I've a question for you.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh good.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'd be grateful if you could furnish me with an
		honest answer.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Furnish you, Jack? 'Course I'll furnish you. You
		ask away, and leave the furnishing to me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Good.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen has picked up a Stanley knife. He works 
	the blade in and out.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Ha. Clever little toy that, isn't it. Stanley knife. It's
		a sort of knife made by a feller called Stanley. First
		name or second name, I'm not sure. I could find
		out for you, Jack, if you're interested. Make some
		inquiries, as it were ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ingenious.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	D'you like it, Jack? Well for heaven's sake you
		keep it, old sport. Present from me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's very kind of you Neddy.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen puts the knife into his pocket.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Not at all, Jack. Plenty more where that came from.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Neddy ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Still here, Jack.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	How would you like to be Prime Minister?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ha.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Sort of a trick question, is it Jack?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Not at all.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Not at all. I see. How would I like to be Prime
		Minister? Hm. Fancy a cup of tea, Jack?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	When you've furnished me with an answer, Neddy,
		a cup of tea would be most agreeable, thank you.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Prime Minister. Lord. Well, I suppose it would be
		rather fun to be Prime Minister, Jack, yes. Riding
		around in big motor cars. Policemen saluting you,
		and all that. Yes, I expect it would be very interesting
		work.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You'd like to be Prime Minister?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, yes, Jack. I expect there are worse jobs
		hahahahaha.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What about your wife?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh. I wouldn't like to be my wife, Jack, no.
		I mean ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	How would your wife take to your being Prime
		Minister?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh I see. Er, well. I'll pop in and ask her, if
		you like. Won't be a sec.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I want your opinion, Neddy. As you know, I
		represent a group of people.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes, I know that, Jack. Yes, jolly fine people
		too, I've no doubt.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	People who are, shall we say, concerned about
		the direction in which this country is headed.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	We feel, as a group of concerned people, that the
		current Prime Minister won't do.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Won't do.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Won't do.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Won't do what, Jack?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Won't do, Neddy.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh I get you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Do you?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	We feel that a change is needed, if disaster is to
		be averted, and we would like you to be the next
		Prime Minister.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Crikey.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Will you do it, Neddy? For England?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Jack. Jack, old sport. Let me say first of all,
		that I really am deeply touched by the offer.
		Deeply touched. Thing is ... Jack, can I tell you
		something?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	By all means, Neddy.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Jack, when I was at school, I used to play cricket for
		the third eleven. No bloody good, of course, went in
		number eight. I was number seven once, when Proby
		had his appendix out, but otherwise well down the
		order ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Is this relevant, Neddy?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well I think so, Jack, yes. You see, there was this one
		match, we played them every year, a match against
		Trenton House. Bit of a needle match, to be honest,
		Jack, you know what boys are like. Well anyway, this
		one year, they turned up without an umpire, and the
		captain told me to get out there and call the shots as
		it were. And the thing is, Jack ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I couldn't do it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	What do you mean couldn't do it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I mean I just couldn't do it. Responsibility, you see,
		Jack. I couldn't cope with the decisions. "Howzat"
		they would scream in my face, and I just went into
		a sort of dreadful funk ... gave one chap out before
		he'd even left the pavillion. What I'm saying, Jack, is
		that I'm a follower, if you know what I mean. Not
		a leader.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Precisely, Neddy.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Precisely, yes, Jack.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You are precisely the man we need.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh lor.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well, Neddy? Will you do it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Will I do it? Good heavens, Jack, of course I'll
		do it. Yes. Anything for my old pal Jack. I just ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Excellent. Congratulations Neddy. The country is
		in safe hands, I know it.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh good. Right, so I'll start being Prime Min-
		ister ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Whenever you're ready, Neddy.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ready, Neddy, very good. Ha. One thing?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	All right with you if I just get this lawnmower
		up and running before I start? Won't take a moment.
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Cut to '}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Secret vices? I don't know. Rather
		too fond of chocolate Hob Nobs.
		My wife tells me I overdo the
		heroin. Otherwise, not really.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'A known and loved newsreader addresses the camera.'}, {'speaker': 'Newsreader', 'text': "
	The House of Commons sat in stunned silence
		as the Prime Minister, Mr John ... damn, I've
		got it here somewhere, (flicks through the pages of his 
		script) Major, that's it, Mr John Major announced
		his intention to resign, saying he wanted to spend
		more time with his collection of miniature fire
		engines. His replacement, a Mr Neddy Muldoon
		of Orchard Lane, St Neots, has been elected
		unopposed by the Parliamentary Conservative
		Party.
		
	Cut to a news conference: Hugh addressing the press.
	Stephen stands slightly to one side.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Good heavens. Not a bad turnout, eh Jack?
'}, {'speaker': 'Reporter 1', 'text': '
	Mr Muldoon?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes, over here. I'm Muldoon.
"}, {'speaker': 'Reporter 1', 'text': '
	Mr Muldoon, what is your position on Europe?
		Do you see yourself as a federalist?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh, er ... crikey. Federalist is as federalist
		does, that's always been my watchword.
"}, {'speaker': 'Reporter 1', 'text': "
	Does that mean you'll be advocating the German
		model in future discussions?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Er ... (to Stephen) Jack, a boy from Trenton
		House is screaming "Howzat" in my face ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Sotto voce) I believe very strongly in the notion
		of peace through strength.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	So do I.
'}, {'speaker': 'Reporter 1', 'text': '
	You do what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I believe in what Jack just said. Peace through
		strength.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And if it becomes necessary ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	If it should, at any time, in the future, become
		necessary ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	To protect the interests of this country ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	To protect, in a manner of speaking after a
		fashion, the interests of this country ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	We will not hesitate to invade Poland ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	We will not hesitate to invade ... excuse me for
		a moment, everyone. (To Stephen) Jack, you sure
		that's not pitching it a little strong?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It's what we agreed.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	We?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Your supporters, Neddy. We agreed.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	But Jack, I'm not altogether sure that I can ...
		
	Stephen produces the Stanley knife.
		
		Hello, I see you've still got the knife I gave
		you. Doing all right is it? Useful?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Extremely useful, Neddy, thank you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Reporter 1', 'text': '
	Mr Muldoon, did you say that you were prepared
		to invade somewhere?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No no. Crikey no. No, little misunderstanding,
		that's all. No, I've always thought that the best
		way to work these sort of things out is to sit
		round a table - although you could also sit along
		the side of a table, it doesn't have to be a round
		table - and just have a bit of an old chat and a
		head scratch.
		
	Stephen stabs Hugh: shouting and commotion. Hugh 
	falls to the ground and looks up at Stephen.
		
		Jack?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes, Neddy?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Someone's gone and stuck a knife in me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	The police are after them now, Neddy.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Jack?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes Neddy?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I want you to have my lawnmower.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
		I had a blue hat once but a dog
			ate it up, shredded it to bits he
			did. I went to him and said "Look
			here this dog has eaten my hat."
			He said, "I don't bloody care." So I
			said, "I don't like your attitude," he
			said "It's not my 'at 'e chewed, it's
			your 'at 'e chewed." My uncle used
			to tell me that in the bath before he
			was arrested.
	'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh in spectacles and bulging anorak is ringing the 
	doorbell of a prosperous-looking London house. It is 
	answered by Stephen, who is fat (yes, yes, get on 
	with it, we know that) and swathed in chinoiserie and 
	camperie. Possibly a tasselled smoking cap. As he opens 
	the door he regards Hugh with pleasure.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	My dear boy! Come in, come in, come in, come
		in, come in, come in, come in, come in!
		
	Hugh looks surprised.

		(Looking down at the floor) Don't mind Clothilda,
		she gets excited by strangers.
		
	Stephen scoops up a blue Persian cat and presses 
	against the open door to allow Hugh to pass through.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	This is 42 Cheyne Gardens?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Come through to the atelier, my dear, and let me mix
		you something devilish of my own devising. A little
		thick cream, a suspicion of parfait amour, a whisper
		of orgeat, garnished with sprig of hyssop and, of
		course, a cocktail cherry. I call it my Moroccan
		Sunrise. It has caused, in it's time, my dear, many a
		son of Morocco to rise ... oh, I must stop myself,
		really I must. Please pay me no attention; Clothilda
		here will tell you that I am no better than I should
		be, won't you Clotty dear? I don't believe I caught
		your name?
		
	They are in a Chelsea studio. It is littered with tigerskin 
	rugs, louche art, bronzes, statuettes, paintings etc.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Nigel Carter.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Nigel Carter. Nigel Carter. There's a breath of
		something fine and ripe in that name, something
		impossibly noble and yet thrillingly rotten. Sit, Nigel
		Carter. Sit, sit, sit.
		
	Stephen pushes Hugh gently on to a seat which is 
	part of a double chair.
		
		It's called a lover's seat. I picked it up in San
		Gimigniano in 1963. That and so much else besides.
		You may keep your clothes on for the moment while
		I weave my magic with the cocktail shaker. Clothilda
		shall amuse you with stories of the gorgeous east.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It's about the advertisement in this month's Model 
		Aeroplanes.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Such a stimulating read. I never miss a copy.
		You have the bluest eyes, has anyone ever told
		you that? It was for eyes of such a hyacinthine
		blue that Apollo languished long ago on sunbleached
		Delos.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Mm. Yes. (Takes out a cutting and reads) "Highest
		prices paid for all models. Apply Simbold Cleobury,
		42 Cheyne Gardens, SW3." That is you, isn't it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It is I. My parents christened me Donald, a
		name entirely without hope. Do you know, I think
		I'm going to give you two cocktail cherries? One
		for each of your blue eyes. I usually pay models
		thirty pounds a sitting. Does that seem fair, my
		dear?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I've got a Sopwith Camel, full RFC markings,
		scale one twentieth. I brought a photograph.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A camel?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It's quite old, but in very good condition.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Heavens! And where do you keep it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	In my room at home. In Greenford.
		
	Stephen drops into the other seat next to Hugh.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(Giving Hugh his cocktail) And they dare to claim,
		Nigel Carter, that the age of romance is dead. (As 
		Hugh sips) I think you will agree that it is the hyssop
		that makes all the difference. (Into Hugh's ear) I love
		hyssop, don't you?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Very tasty.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What is the name of this camel who lives with
		you in Greenford?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, Sopwith.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sopwith! Too heavenly. Perhaps I shall paint you
		astride this Sopwith, Nigel. It is not impossible.
		But first I shall have you sprawled naked on the
		tiger-skin, firelight dancing on your shivering thighs.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Erm ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Have you modelled before?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh, all my life. Well, since I was four.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Mercy, Nigel. Mercy. Since you were four?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	My grandfather started me off.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So often the way.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	We both ended up covered in glue.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Nigel, you amaze me.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	It was a Fokker.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	It sounds it, Nigel. In glue you say? You may
		fear no such extravagances from me. Perhaps a
		little light rubbing with oil to bring out your flesh
		tones, Nigel, but no more.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Would you like to see my Jumbo?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Nigel, I would like to see your Jumbo very much
		indeed.
		
	Hugh shows Stephen a photograph.

		(Looking at it) Nigel, that is a photograph of a
		large jet aeroplane.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(Staring down at photo for a moment) Oh, I'm
		sorry, I don't know how that got in there. (Rifles 
		through) Here we are.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	My, that is a jumbo, isn't it? Now then, clothes
		off and on to the tiger-skin with you.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Stripping) Righto.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It's less than a year since they
		ditched her and already she's for-
		gotten - consigned to the dustbin
		of history. She personally liberated
		all of Eastern Europe, but she's
		forgotten. That's how grateful we
		are to Margaret ... Margaret ...
		Datchett was it?
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen and Hugh are seated at a table in a restaurant,
	holding large menus. Rather bookish; spectacles, tweeds 
	etc. All four of their eyes are closed all the time, in a 
	revolting, condescending sort of a way.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	How nice. How absolutely delightful.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Charming. Quite charming. A charming restaurant.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A charming as you say restaurant.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Quite delightful.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I think one of my most favourite quite delightful
		restaurants.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I agree. I agree. I do. I really do agree.
		
	A waitress approaches.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': '
	Are you ready to order?
		
	Hugh and Stephen cock their heads.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Did you say something?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I thought I heard ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I rather think it may have been a member of
		the restaurant staff.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ah.
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen and Hugh reach into their pockets and pull out 
	pairs of half-moon spectacles, put them on, and peer at 
	the waitress.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Aahh.
'}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': '
	Are you ready to order?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I will have the melon, followed by the roast
		lamb.
'}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': '
	Melon, lamb. And you, sir?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I will have the soupe de poisson, and the roast
		lamb also.
'}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': '
	Fish soup. Lamb.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'm so sorry.
"}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What did you just say then?
'}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': '
	Fish soup, lamb.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Mmm. Perhaps I didn't make myself absolutely
		clear. I would actually like the soupe de poisson.
"}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': '
	Soupe de poisson is fish soup.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh dear.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh deary me.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Was I speaking too quickly for you?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	You seem to be a little confused.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I asked for soupe de poisson.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Soupe de poisson.
'}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': '
	Soupe de poisson is fish soup.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No. No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No no no no.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I obviously lost you. Soupe de poisson is soupe de 
		poisson.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	D'you see?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	One thing cannot be another thing. And when
		you advertise soupe de poisson, and I order soupe de 
		poisson, it means, to put it very simply, that I would
		like you to bring me soupe de poisson.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And some mineral water.
'}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': '
	Mineral water.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Thank you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Thank you very much indeed.
		
	Waitress exits. Stephen and Hugh return their spectacles 
	to their pockets, and close their eyes again.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What a charming restaurant.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Absolutely delightful.
		
	Waitress returns and puts a bottle of mineral water 
	on the table.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': '
	Mineral water.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh dear.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh waitress?
		
	Stephen and Hugh don their spectacles again.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Waitress?
'}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Can you remember what it was that I asked for?
		I think I saw you write it down, did you write it
		down?
'}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': '
	Yes, Mineral water.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Bravo.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Excellent, well done.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	But you have brought us a bottle of mineral water.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Do you see? (Pointing to the bottle) These are
		called bottles.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	We asked for mineral water.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Mineral water. Just as you carefully wrote down
		on your small pad.
'}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': '
	How much mineral water?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Some.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Some mineral water is how much we asked for
		I believe.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Some.
'}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': '
	Some?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	But we can check precisely what it was we asked
		for. We always tape our conversations against just such
		a contingency.
		
	Stephen rewinds a cassette.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Tape', 'text': '
	"Man: Get out the pair of you, you snotty 
		wankers ..."
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ah, no. That was the restaurant we were in yesterday.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	A delightful restaurant it was too.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Quite delightful. Here we are.
		
	Fast forwards.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Tape', 'text': '
	"Hugh: And some mineral water.
		Waitress: Mineral water?"
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	You see?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Some.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No mention of bottles.
'}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': '
	Shall I bring it in a jug?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	My suggestion is that you should bring us mineral
		water in a jug when we have asked for mineral water
		in a jug, until then, perhaps you would be so kind as
		to bring us some mineral water.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	All right?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Thank you.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Exit waitress.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What a delightful restaurant.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Quite delightful.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Waitress enters with a pipette. She carefully squeezes
	a drop in front of each of them.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Thank you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Delightful.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I wonder, my dear, is there a gents' nearby. I'm
		rather desperate for a pee.
"}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': "
	Well ... there is one, but it was out of order
		earlier on. I'll just check.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Waitress disappears.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Charming waitress, do you see?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	This is right. Simply charming.
		
	Waitress enters with a small green pea, which she 
	places in front of Hugh.
		
		Um ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Er ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	You really must excuse my stupidity, but ...
		
	Waitress takes tape recorder.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Waitress', 'text': '
	You asked for it. Listen.
'}, {'speaker': 'Tape', 'text': '
	"Hugh: I'm rather desperate for a pee ..."
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ah ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Err ...
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
		(As policeman) People often ask 
			what we keep under our helmets. 
			Well, I'll show you. (Takes off his 
			helmet and looks very pleased with 
			himself - puts his hand on top of his 
			head and feels around) Hold up, some 
			bastard's nicked it.
	"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Music and titles. Typical cookery programme. Beautifully 
	presented. Stephen is dressed as Elizabeth Martin, a 
	television cook.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Good morning, I'm Elizabeth Martin and welcome
		to this week's Tahitian Kitchen. Last week if you can
		be bothered to remember, we looked at presentation
		and garnishing of main dishes, Tahitian style. We cov-
		ered the range of exotic and tasty herbs and spices
		that characterise this all too bloody often neglected
		cuisine. This week, I'm thinking particularly of those
		who might be on a tighter budget and who would like
		to prepare Tahitian dishes without stretching their
		sodding pockets too much. So I'm going to show
		you what you can do with some of the rarer off-cuts
		of meat, lights and offal, which while they may not
		sound appetising are, when properly prepared, as
		tempting, nutritious and arsingly well worth eating
		as any of the dearer cuts.
		
	We see on her chopping board a number of bowls with 
	heaps of spices and so on. There are also some parcels of 
	meat wrapped in greaseproof paper.
		
		Now I know a lot of people are funny about
		eating ears, eyes, brains, noses and so on, but with
		a little care I think you'll find out that they can be
		worth the trouble. I have two young ears here, for
		instance, which I have salted slightly and marinaded
		overnight.
		
	She pulls out two human ears.
		
		It is important that they are young, these are
		taken from an Anglia television journalist,
		whom I slaughtered two days ago. Freshness is
		the most important factor with ears. What I'm going
		to do is combine them with the sweetbreads, or
		testicles (she produces them) and the fingers (brings 
		up the fingers) in a provencal sauce of tomato and
		garlic.
		
	She blends them together.
		
		If you want to add feet and toes I would urge you
		to remember that smaller is tastier. These are from
		a Welsh articled clerk, Welsh feet are preferable if you
		can find them at this time of year. It's a good idea to
		hang the carcass upside-down for at least five hours
		just after killing. The toes are ideal as finger-treats
		or appetising dips.
		
	She shows a bowl of toes, lightly grilled.
		
		Care to have a try, Michael?
		
	Hugh comes on from another part of the set.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm game for anything, Elizabeth!
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(Rather violently) Don't I know it. There you are,
		this is a simple barbecue sauce.
		
	Hugh dips the toe into a sauce.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I must say. Rather delicious.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	And they won't break the bank either.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(To camera. In announcer mode) And talking of
		breaking the bank, Sue has been investigating ...
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Gary Davies introduces "The Bishop & The Warlord".'}, {'speaker': 'Gary', 'text': "
	Woo! Get seriously down to that. Well now it's time to
		crank it up and tune it in, with some back to back
		fat beat, and have ourselves a rocking good time and
		no messing with the Bishop and the Warlord! Give me
		at least five!
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'The Bishop & The Warlord'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	"The Bishop & The Warlord" in performance. Stephen 
	is dressed as a bishop, but with one leather cut-off glove.
	Hugh is fairly standard heavy metallurgist. Long hair,
	leather waistcoat, chain etc. Stephen sings from a pulpit,
	Hugh accompanies.'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': "
		She's got ruby red lips
		And legs down to the floor
		She walks just like a wildcat
		And she sings just like a dream
		She's the greatest thing
		That you've ever seen
		Yes I need the heat of your loving, baby
		You've got to burn with your desire
		Start smoking at the edges
		Set yourself on fire
		You're mine mine mine mine mine
		My baby is mine
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Courtroom Scene'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	A TV monitor showing the last few bars of the song 
	as played on Top of the Pops. Pull out to see that we 
	are in an American courtroom. Stephen is in the dock,
	as the bishop. Hugh is the prosecuting attorney. Clerks,
	stenographer etc. scattered around. Seated next to Hugh 
	is a woman covered in bandages. Hugh switches off the 
	monitor and addresses the court.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	"Set yourself on fire". Four words, your honour.
		Four innocent words. Every bit as common in our
		language as "freedom" or "vitamin-enriched". But play
		those words backwards, and what do you have? "Erif
		no flesruoy tes". But that isn't enough. These people
		are smarter than that, because if you play "Erif no
		flesruoy tes" backwards, you have "Set yourself on
		fire". A clear, explicit and unambigualistical
		instruction to my client, which she obeyed, to pour
		a can of gasoline over herself, and set light to it,
		causing untold physical and mental traumatisation.
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': "
	Let's get this straight, Mr Sanchez. Your client
		listened to the song ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	"Grease My Gristle, Blow My Whistle".
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	Hm. Catchy title. And as a result, she set fire
		to herself?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Precisely, your honour.
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	I see. And as a matter of interest, did she also grease
		her gristle and blow her whistle?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	She certainly did, your Honour, causing herself
		grievous internal bruisality. That case comes to
		trial next month.
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	I see. Any other cases pending?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes, your Honour. We have a suit of seven hundred
		million dollars against the group Queen, who caused
		my client to suffer a broken jaw, by urging her to
		become "champion of the world".
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	In what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Light middleweight boxing. Four hundred mil-
		lion against Frankie Goes To Hollywood, for
		instructioning her to Relax And Not Do It.
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	Relax and not do what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Relax and not apply the brakes of her automobile
		at a T-junction. And finally, nine hundred million
		against Jason Donovan.
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	For what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	We haven't decided yet, your Honour.
"}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': "
	I see. Three billion dollars. That's a pretty
		substantial figure, Counsellor.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, to be honest, my wife and I are hoping to buy
		a little place down South, for weekends, space for
		the kids, you know?
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': "
	Really. What's it called?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Paraguay.
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': "
	That's nice. Now, do you have any witnesses?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I call the defendant, the self-styled clergyman of
		cool, the Bishop of Attleboro.
		
	Stephen as the bishop takes the stand.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	Take the book in your right hand and say after
		me. I have no objection ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I have no objection ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	... to this trial being televised ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	... to this trial being televised ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	... and subsequently being made ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	... and subsequently being made ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	... into a motion picture, book, or stage musical
		so help me God.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	... into a motion picture, book, or stage musical
		so help me God.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What is your name, sir?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	My name is William ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Just answer the question yes or no, please. What
		is your name?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes..
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	That is your real name?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No is your real name?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No is not your real name?
'}, {'speaker': 'Defence', 'text': '
	Objection your Honour. Counsel is badgering the
		witness.
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	Hmm. Are you badgering the witness, Mr Sanchez?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Certainly not, your Honour.
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	Good.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I am, possibly, weazelling the witness, and I certainly
		hope to squirrel him with my next question, but I am
		not badgering him.
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': "
	Mr Sanchez you're dicking me around.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No sir.
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	Good. Proceed.
'}, {'speaker': 'Defence', 'text': '
	But ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	Your objection is overstained, Counsellor.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Now then, Mr Yes, you are the lead singer of the
		Heavy Metal band The Bishop And The Warlord?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	That is substantially correct.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Substantially?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well of course, being a bishop, I also have a great
		deal of work to do within my own diocese, as well
		as attending the Council of Synod meetings, which
		means that I can only devote limited time to the
		band, but in essence you are correct.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	In essence I am correct, I see. And when you look
		upon the poor, wretched figure of my client now, Mr
		Yes, an innocent victim of your handiwork, how do
		you feel?
'}, {'speaker': 'Defence', 'text': '
	Your honour, I really must stand up and make
		some pretence of earning my fee.
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	Nice work, Counsellor.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I say again, how do you feel?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well I'm most awfully sorry.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Awfully sorry?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well it simply never crossed my mind that people
		could be told what to do so easily. I mean on my
		second album we wrote a song called "Bake Me A
		Love Souffle" ... if I thought that people would
		actually ...
		
	Hugh's client whispers to Hugh. Hugh produces a cake.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	One love souffle, baked by my client sadly not
		at any personal injury to herself.
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	Mr Yes, in the face of this evidence, I really
		have no choice but to find for the plaintiff. Have
		you anything to say before I name the figure?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well, perhaps just one thing, your honour ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Perhaps I might put it this way. One two three ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Objection!
		
	Stephen starts to sing.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Woman! (Crashing chords)
		Get out of my face!
		Woman!
		Woman drop your case.
		Don't press those charges
		Pay all my legal costs
		You know that this case
		Is as good as lost.
		
		Forget the whole thing ever happened
		And get yourself out of my life
		Woman woman woman
		Get out of my face.
		
	Pause: woman in bandages whispers to Hugh.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Your honour, it appears my client no longer wishes to
		proceed with her claim against Mr Yes, she wishes to
		pay all legal costs, to drop the case, and (she whispers 
		again) she would also like permission to get out of
		his face.
'}, {'speaker': 'Judge', 'text': '
	Such permission is so engranted, Mr Sanchez.
		Case dismissulated. Now, what next.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The state would like to call Mr Tony Inchpractice.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen is at his horrible house, answering the door.
	He wears a cardigan with leather patches. He smokes a 
	pipe which has a stitched leather bowl holder. He opens 
	the door. Hugh stands without. He is dressed in similar 
	fashion. These are people with whom John Major would 
	have a great deal in common. Hugh is holding a hosepipe 
	reel.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	John!
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Afternoon, John. I'm returning the hosepipe you
		so kindly lent me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Decent. Very decent. In you come, for heaven's sake.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Thankee.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I was just rearranging my collection. I don't know
		if you've ever seen it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Collection? Now there's a thing. What do you collect
		exactly?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well, it ain't stamps.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It ain't stamps. Coins, perhaps?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It ain't coins.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	You find me intrigued, John.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "
	They are walking into John's den."}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Follow me into the rumpus den, John and all
		will be revealed.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Lead on, lead on.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Inside the rumpus den there is a large collection 
	of plates with woodland creatures painted on them. 
	There are statuettes called "Spirit of the Dance" and 
	glass figurines of robins. You have never seen such a 
	disgusting collection in all your life. It is spotlit and the 
	joy of Stephen's life.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	My word, John. My word, my heavens, my goodness.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	The plates are mostly the work of the artist Elizabeth
		Bridwell, ARA; one of the leading artists of today.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Examining a plate) I can see that she is one
		of the leading artists of today at a glance, John.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	She captures the spirit of woodland creatures in a
		variety of heritage series that you will want to keep
		for ever as a lasting joy and investment.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Investment, John?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	For surely sure investment, John. Only a very
		limited edition of these is produced; ensuring rarity
		and individuality.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Holding a saucer) I am bound to say, John "what
		a marvellous thing to possess".
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	The mischievious expression on that hedgehog's
		busy, enquiring little face as he snouts for black-
		berries is beautifully rendered and brings vividly to
		life the atmosphere of our heritage native woodlands.
		I bought a hundred of those.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	A hundred, John? I am gobsmacked. Simply
		gobsmacked.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I instantly destroyed ninety-nine. In this way I
		have increased the rarity of this beautiful object
		considerably. Only forty-nine others exist.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And where are they?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	In the hands of other connoisseurs, I must assume.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Connoisseurs who also read the Mail on Sunday?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	In a nutshell.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	John, if you could track down these other tasteful
		readers of the Mail on Sunday and offer to acquire
		their saucers of the busy enquiring mischievous ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(Correcting him) Mischievious ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Mischievious, I do beg your pardon. If, as I
		say, you could acquire the remainder of these
		heirloom heritage pieces you would be sitting
		on the only mischievious hedgehog left in the
		world.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Such is my ambition, John. Who knows what
		this saucer would be worth should that be the
		case?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	When you think, John, of the amounts fetched by
		painting by Picasso which do not have a tithe of
		the character, saucy mischieviousness and enquiring
		business of this little heritage hedgehog ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	It's quite a thought, John. And that is just one
		saucer. There is a series of statuettes here in frosted
		glass entitled "Spirit of the Dance" by John Petty
		C.R.A.P.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	John, they seem to crystallise in lovingly ground
		glass the movement, grace and gossamer freedom
		of a great ballerina.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	That they do, John. In spades. I bought two
		hundred of each in the series and ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Destroyed one hundred and ninety-nine of them?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Precisely.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(Very serious) John.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I do hope you are properly insured. There are
		international art thieves around who ... if they
		got so much as a whisper of what a trove you
		have in this rumpus den ... well ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I know, John. Believe me I know. I'm well protected,
		believe you I.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I do believe you I, John. I do. Tell me a thing.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Gladdingly.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What does Joanie make of these. She paints, I believe?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ah now. Now. Joanie is rendered speechless. I
		sometimes find her in here staring at these objets
		with her arm sort of flung up in front of her face.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	As if unable to comprehend such talent.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Exactly. I think she comes in to draw inspiration.
		Sometimes though she can't bring herself to look
		at them at all.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	As if dazzled.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	As if dazzled. I'll call her in. (Calling off) Oh Joanie.
"}, {'speaker': 'Joan', 'text': '
	(Off) What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Could you come in a second, my love?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Is she at work at the moment?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	She is, yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Enter Joanie. She is still holding her palette and is 
	obviously still at work. She enters the room sideways,
	as if trying to avert her gaze from the collection. Stephen 
	and Hugh catch each other's eyes and mouth the word 
	"dazzled" to each other with triumphant confirmation.'}, {'speaker': 'Joan', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You remember John, don't you Joanie?
"}, {'speaker': 'Joan', 'text': '
	Oh. Hello.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	We were talking about the collection.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Joan emits a little squeak.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You're a painter yourself, of course, Joanie. You
		must marvel at this kind of artistry.
		
	Joan starts to make little retching noises.
		
		All the more so when you consider the rarity
		of these pieces.
"}, {'speaker': 'Joan', 'text': '
	Yes. (An idea begins to dawn) As a matter of fact
		John, I was going to tell you ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Joan', 'text': '
	I tracked down a man in Carshalton who has
		a collection exactly the same as yours.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No!
'}, {'speaker': 'Joan', 'text': '
	Yup. Piece for piece.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	If only he would sell ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Joan', 'text': "
	He will! I've ordered the whole collection: it's
		on its way here.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Marvellous. That is marvellous.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh, congratulations.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	All I have to do is destroy it and this will be
		worth even more.
'}, {'speaker': 'Joan', 'text': '
	Or of course ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Joan', 'text': "
	(Trying to be casual) You could destroy this lot
		and keep the one that's on its way.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	True.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well, there's no need. These are in place.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Be fun though wouldn't it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Joan', 'text': '
	(Almost hysterical) Yes! Think what fun it would be.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	All right. Let's do it.
		
	Joan, like a savage animal, unleashes herself on the 
	collection. Hugh joins in. Stephen too, slightly puzzled by 
	the incredible ferocity of Joan and Hugh's attack. Soon it 
	is all in pieces. Joan is frenzied with joy.

		(A little doubtful) Well. There we are. Can't wait
		for the new set to arrive.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Congratulations.
'}, {'speaker': 'Joan', 'text': '
	Thank you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	This calls for a drink I think. Fancy a gin and
		ton, John?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hoo, why not?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Coming up.
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Exit Stephen.'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "Joan waits for him to go and then falls into Hugh's arms."}, {'speaker': 'Joan', 'text': '
	Thank you, John. Thank you a million times over.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Think nothing of it. Sometimes a public duty can
		be a private pleasure. But for God's sake cancel that
		subscription to the Mail on Sunday.
"}, {'speaker': 'Joan', 'text': '
	I have.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Used to be this chap at my school
		called Richard Braine. You'll never
		guess our nickname for him. We
		used to call him Rick Brain. Oh
		no, that can't be right.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh and Stephen are standing in front of a light 
	aeroplane.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hello and welcome to "Flying a Light Aeroplane
		Without Having Had Any Formal Instruction
		With ...". Today I'm going to be Flying A Light
		Aeroplane Without Having Had Any Formal
		Instruction With Sir Peter Winstanton, former
		Chairman of the National Trust, and now Maitre
		De Dense at the Galliard Ballet Company. Hello
		Sir Peter.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Good afternoon Johnny.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Mmm. My name isn't Johnny.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Never said it was.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Right now, Sir Peter, you've never flown an
		aeroplane before?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Never flown in my life, Johnny, no.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	And you've never had any lessons?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh I've had lessons, maths, geography ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	But not in flying?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	And I've never flown before. Is this something
		you've always wanted to do?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Not particularly. So when you rang up I just
		leapt at the chance.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right.
		
	Hugh and Stephen start to climb into the aeroplane.
		
		Now can I begin, Sir Peter, by asking you about
		your early influences. Your parents died when you
		were very young, and you were brought up by your
		aunt in a boarding house on the South Coast.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's right, Johnny, yes. Did a lot of shrimping
		as a kid.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Shrimping?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You know, roll up your trousers, get out there with
		a net and a box of sandwiches, got to watch the tide
		though.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Have you?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Not now. When you're shrimping. Got to make sure
		you don't get caught out by the tide, because Johnny?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	It waits for no man ... hahahahaha.
		
	Stephen is now fiddling with the controls of the aeroplane.
		
		Now what do we do here?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm afraid I haven't the faintest idea.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh well, let's see.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Pushes and pulls at various levers.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	So yours must have been rather a lonely upbringing.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh good heavens no.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Good heavens no?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Good heavens no. Very happy time. Got to know
		lots of people. It was a brothel, you see.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What was?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	The boarding house that my aunt ran was, in
		fact, a brothel.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Really?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Lots of people coming in and out all hours
		of the day and night. It really was ...
		
	The engine suddenly fires and the propellor turns.
		
		Hello. That was a bit of luck.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well done.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ha. Something had to happen eventually.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	But presumably you can't have got to know many
		people of your own age through the brothel?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well no, but I became very friendly with members
		of the local council. The deputy chairman taught
		me to play bridge, as a matter of fact. He was a
		county player himself, and a marvellous teacher.
		
	He lets the brakes off and the aeroplane trundles forwards.
		
		Huh. Look out. Seems like we're off.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I really am very impressed by the way you're
		managing. Were you mechanically minded as a child?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Good God no. Couldn't open a tin of beans
		without an instruction book.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(Shouting back to camera) Next week, I shall be in
		an Intensive Care Unit With ... Peter Trenton, star
		of Home And Away. B'bye.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well they said Enoch Powell was
		mad, of course ... Oh look,
		there's John the Baptist floating
		upside down past Dewhurst's.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh and Stephen address the camera at the end of 
	the show. They are in black tie and Hugh is sitting at 
	the piano.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well that's just about it for this week.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's right. The clock has once again ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh be quiet. So it's goodnight from me ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	And it's goodnight from me ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And it's goodnight from me. We're going to leave
		you with tonight's recipe. This is for "A Mug Of
		Horlicks". You'll need some Horlicks, some milk, a
		teaspoon and a mug.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Huh, will I do?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I meant mug in the sense of a drinking vessel.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You will also need an idiot to hit on the head
		with your teaspoon.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Huh, will I do?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Admirably. (Hits Hugh on the head with teaspoon)
		And one two three, kick. Hit it Mr Laurie, if you'd
		be so very kind.
		
	Hugh strikes up a jazzy sort of riff while Stephen 
	footles around with a pan of milk and a camping gas 
	stove. Credits, if there are any.
	
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Stephen is at a desk, reciting.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	"Crate, a normil nighman
		Hane a freethy stipe
		You veen where musse is Simon
		Critch botty trees a wipe."
		
		I first wrote the poem from which that verse was
		an extract when my dear wife Enemy died. I wrote
		it again in 1978 after hearing of the death of rock
		music. I'd like with your kind indulgence to write
		it once more. Thank you.
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Stephen sits and writes.'}]

[{'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hugh, my old china serving bowl, it seems that we're pretty
		much in the position of having to say "Here we are again."
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Stephen, my old styrofoam cushion whose wedge-shape guarantees
		relief from the misery of lower back pain, you've never said a
		truer word.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	We sit here, do we not, like coiled springs, gazing down the
		comedy tunnel ahead of us, settling our spikes into the
		starting blocks and cocking our ears to the starter's pistol.
		Before us, the hurdles and water-jumps of three and a half
		hours' worth of comedy material, the first forty minutes to be
		run in lanes - ecstasy, pain, triumph, disaster, who knows what
		awaits at the further end?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	My hope is that, win or lose, at least there'll be a steaming
		mug of hot Lucozade, and maybe one of those aluminium blankets
		of the sort that help prevent athletes from not wearing
		aluminium blankets.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hugh, as always, your words fill me with a ferocious desire to
		be somewhere else.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, violent reader, as I'm by way of being the person to the
		left of the dealer, it falls to me to welcome you to this book
		or ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	... this book or ...
		
	Hugh thinks for a moment, tilting his head to the light in a way that 
	might remind the casual onlooker of a young Arthur Mullard.
		
		There's no other word for "book", really, is there?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Not one that need detain us for more than the fewest of
		moments, Hugh, no.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	So welcome to this book. And let me begin by saying, don't read
		it straight away.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A strange piece of advice, old friend, and yet ...
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen pauses, tilting his head to the light in a way that might 
	remind a young Arthur Mullard of an old Trevor Francis.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And yet?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	And yet I've ridden too far with you, known you too long, been
		at your side in too many tight corners not to doubt that you
		have your reasons.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	My reasons are almost painfully simple.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I suspected they might be.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	This book is more than it appears.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You mean less, surely?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I mean more, dammit. Much, much more. It contains traps,
		conceits, windows on to other worlds, and almost no crosswords.
		I advise you to lay it on its side in the middle of your
		living-room and walk around it , sniffing, probing, prodding.
		But whatever you do ... NEVER TURN YOUR BACK ON IT.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Even for a second.
