'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Even, as you rightly point out, for a second.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'd like to add something at this point.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Let me suggest seventeen and twelve.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(after some thought) Twenty-nine.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Good. But to return to the matter in hand. Books, I always like
		to shout, can be divided into two categ ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I don't do dividing.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ng ... into two categories. Books for reading and books for
		skimming, dipping and grazing.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's beautiful. That is actually beautiful.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I think it fair to say that this book, our book, falls heavily
		and with a sickening thud, jarring the table and spilling some
		of that very nice medium dry sherry, into the second category.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Correct.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	And we're proud of that. That's not to take anything away from
		the first categ ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I don't do taking away either.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Hng ... I suppose what I'm trying to say is this ... here, let
		me show you ...
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh mimes what he is driving at ... rather well.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Exactly! That's absolutely right. That, above all, is the point
		we wanted to drive home, snog briefly in the porch and then
		take upstairs for a quick round of banal sex.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Banal sex?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Bexactly.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh and Stephen break off for a moment, tilting a pair of Arthur 
	Mullards towards the light in a way that reminds them of what has to be 
	said next.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I've got it. There's the old warning song, isn't there?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Of course! That's it! How could you have been so stupid?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I don't know. I really don't.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well get on with it. The ladies and gentlemen are waiting ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	It goes like this. One afternoon while I was out brushing my
		teeth, I met a man called Palfrey, who claimed to be our legal
		adviser from the legal department, specifically the section
		that deals with legal matters and issues pertaining to the
		whole business of the law. He legally advised me that I should
		advise you, the reader, if that is what you are, that the
		public performance of any of the material herewithcontained
		without the written permission of the authors or their duly
		appointed agents, shall not be deemed ...
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "
	There is a pause. Not so long as to arouse comment, but let's face it,
	we've all known shorter ones."}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Not be deemed?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I don't know. I don't suppose I shall ever know what it will
		not be deemed.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You mean ... ?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Exactly. At that moment, a white Nissan Sunny, its tyres
		howling in protest, rounded the corner and careered towards
		Palfrey. I made to shout a warning, but, for some reasons I
		will never understand, the words froze in my throat. I could
		only stand and watch in horror as the bonnet of the car struck
		Palfrey behind the knees, sending the little lawyer's body
		arching through the air in a bizarre arabesque of death.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Did you call Nick Ross?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Of course. But for Palfrey, it was a lifetime too late.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What a ghastly story.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I know.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And so badly told.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You're quite right.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well heigh ho. The time has come for us to take up a bottle of
		Sainsbury's cooking champagne and smash it over the bows of
		this book ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	... then watch in triumph as it slithers down the ramp into the
		oily waters of the reader's shopping bag ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Or back on to the shelf, as the case may be ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Allowing them to maunder along to another of the million or so
		comedy books currently on sale ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	In whichever category you place yourself, may you find whatever
		it is you're looking for ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And may it come up to expectations when you do ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	We love you ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	... love you ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	... love you ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	... love you ...
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen and Hugh grow fainter and fainter, until they have to sit down.'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh is sitting at his desk in his office. Stephen, his boss, comes in.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ah, Douglas, those reports were supposed to be on my desk
		yester ...
		
	He notices that Hugh is looking signally depressed.
		
		... you all right, Douglas?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm sorry sir, I just ... it's just ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Come on, old fellow, spit it out. Whatever it is, it can't be
		that bad.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I've got this feeling that my life is grey and hopeless.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Grey and hopeless? Grey and hopeless? Oh now, come on. What are
		you talking about?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I look into the future and what do I see?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I don't know, what do you see?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Just the blank rolling of the years, one after another, like
		grey, hopless waves beating against my brains till the blood
		runs out of my ears.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Now come on. You've got a wife and two children, a very
		pleasant house, three loving goldfish ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I know, but what does it mean? We live in a doomed world.
		Doomed.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh nonsense, what do you mean doomed?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Nobody likes anybody any more, nobody cares about anybody or
		anything. People go around hitting and stabbing and stealing
		and insulting. The countryside's a poisonous mess, the cities
		are unbreathable, you can get beaten up by a twelve-year-old
		and ripped off by your neighbour.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well, I grant you things aren't ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	There are no certainties, only battle-lines. No pleasure any
		more except in getting drunk or high on dangerous drugs that
		are supplied by maniacs with machine guns.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes, it's a grim old world alright, but surely it's always
		been ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Films and music are crap. Books are crap. The streets are so
		full you can't walk in a town without being pushed off the
		pavement, the roads are unusable, the trains are a joke, the
		politicians are so feeble-minded and gutless you can't even
		hate them.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Even sport isn't fun any more, really, is it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You smile at someone in the street, you're either knifed in the
		kidneys or in court for rape.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Opening a newspaper's like opening a fold of used lavatory
		paper.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Turn on the television and you're sprayed in coloured vomit.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It's frigging useless, isn't it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	We're done for.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Shagged. We're bloody shagged. Oh, Jesus.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Grey and hopeless.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Grey and hopeless.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Just a nightmare of cold despair.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No future, no point, no prospect, no pleasure, nothing. Just
		grey, hopeless hell.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Christ.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh Christ Jesus.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	We're dead.
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Pause: an incredibly long one. Then they turn to the camera.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well, first of all, m'colleague and I would like to welcome you
		to this brand new spanking series of A Bit Of Fry & Laurie, the
		show that tries to bring a little jolliness into the darker
		corners of modern Britain, but doesn't.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I'd like to add my own individual welcome on a more personal
		note, seperate and distinct from m'colleague's joint welcome,
		which I always think is a bit stiff, a bit formal. My welcome
		is just a bit of an old "Hi". That's all. Just "Hi."
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Jesus. So a choice of welcomes on BBC television. It's either
		good evening, ladies and gentlemen, or it's ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hi.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, you see, you take away the Queen, I mean, it's all very
		well to say, get rid of the Royal Family, but - who the hell
		are you going to put on the stamps? Hm? Desmond Lynam? Mike
		Smith? I mean, I'm not going to turn Mike Smith over and give
		him a licking every time I want to send a letter, am I? People
		just don't think these things through.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I haven't enjoyed sexual relations with my wife now for seven
		or eight years. We still make love every night, it's just that
		I don't enjoy it. Well, that's not good enough, so I decided to
		do something about it.
		
	He walks down a corridor.
		
		After all, how much do we really know about love-making? We all
		think we know, don't we? Well, perhaps you'd be surprised. Dr
		Hedges Evan is a sex therapist. He also, I'm told, makes the
		best cup of coffee in North London. Let's find out.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	We're now outside a door. "Dr Hedges Evan".
	Cut to interior of office. Hugh is Hedges Evan.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	The first thing I always say is this. Don't be afraid to
		experiment and above all don't be afraid to talk things
		through. To do it well takes time. If you're using the drip
		method, then make sure that everything is properly wiped down
		first.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(sipping from a cup) Well the results speak for themselves.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You're very tall.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No, no. I mean it.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, thank you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Would you say that most couples would benefit from sex therapy,
		Dr Evan?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I have a handy little memory-aid to help describe the problems
		that confront most couples. They are the enemies of good sex
		and I refer to them as the two F's, the I, the N, the T and the
		other F. The two F's are Fear and Inhibition, the I is Myth and
		Fallacy, the T is Silence and the other F is Worry.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Right ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	And the most important of those F's is Ignorance. For instance
		most people are surprisingly ill-informed about the absolute
		basics, the one, B, C's of sex, if you like.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Now that's a very interesting point, Doctor.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Thanks.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What are some of the most common mistakes, would you say?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, I'll give you a for-instance. I had a couple in here not
		so very long ago, a news-reader and his wife as it happens,
		although it could just as easily have been a wife and her news-
		reader, and they had come to me complaining that their love
		life wasn't really working out. And do you know what the poor
		man had been trying to do?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Of course I don't.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I mean, I hear some pretty hair-raising stories in this office,
		as you can imagine, but that absolutely took the biscuit. He'd
		been trying to push his penis into his wife's vagina.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	And that's bad, is it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, I mean the idea is grotesque. I can't afford to be
		moralistic or a prude in my job, but I can tell you, I very
		nearly threw up.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Mm ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ignorance, you see. With a capital W.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So what did you do?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I sat them down, first of all.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	They'd been standing up through all of this?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No, I had sat them down to begin with, but then they stood up
		to show me a couple of things ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Gotcha.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And I turned round to them, and I said ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You turned round to them, so you were facing ... ?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	That wall there.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I have a clear picture now.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And I talked for nearly twenty minutes ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Did you check your watch?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I don't wear a watch. I find it makes me rash.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I see.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No, I went by the clock above the main entrance.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	So while you were talking, you weren't actually in the room
		with them?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I find it works for me.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And what was the result of all this? Satisfied customers?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	They are now happily divorced, I'm pleased to say.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Both of them?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Both of them, indeed. The news-reader's career seems to go from
		strength to strength, and his wife is now the President of
		France.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh good. No chance of another cup, is there?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Every chance in Cristendom.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen talks. John is at his side.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	We see things. We touch things. We hear things. We taste
		things. But never forget that we also smell.
		
	Huge caption: "SMELL - THE FORGOTTEN SENSE?" 
		
		John, my spies tell me, and I should point out that they're not
		actually spies in the sense of having hidden cameras and false
		bottoms, they're just people who tell me things - my spies tell
		me that, in your spare time, you're Vice-Professor of Smell at
		De Montfort University - reserve your seat of learning - do you
		think we've forgotten smell?
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': '
	I think we have forgotten smell. I think we neglect smell. I
		think smell is the one sense that seems to have got left behind
		in the mad rush for profit and cheap housing.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Can you give us some examples?
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': '
	Of what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Anything.
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': "
	Alright. First leg qualifier against Holland. Libby Purves.
		Beethoven's Violin Concerto.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	They being examples of ...?
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': '
	Of the glaring deficiencies of the long ball game, a Radio Four
		presenter, and a violin concerto by Beethoven.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	But to get back to this wretched business of smell ...
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': "
	Well now, I have to pick you up on that. I can't let that go
		unchallenged.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen waits, but there is no more.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Fair enough. I believe you've actually brought some smells with
		you, to give us some idea of the kind of thing YOU say, and I
		stress the you, when I say YOU say, that we're missing.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	John rummages at his feet and brings out some bottles.'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': "
	That's right. Have a go at this one, and tell me what you
		think.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen takes the bottle and sniffs.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hmm. Pretty nasty. What is that?
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': '
	That one is ...
		
	He looks at the label.
		
		... Michael Portillo getting out of a Rover 200 after quite a
		long journey.
		
	He hands over another bottle.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Ah now, that's rather nice.
"}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': "
	'Tis, isn't it? That's the inside of a slaughterhouse in Kent.
		Fresh, tangy, but full of character.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Another bottle.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hello, I think I recognise this one.
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': '
	You should do.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What is it?
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': '
	Have a guess.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well I don't know ...
"}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': '
	Go on.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	The lavatories at Earl's Court during the Royal Tournament?
"}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': "
	No. That's actually your right knee.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Is it?
		
	Stephen smells his own knee.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Good heavens, so it is.
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': '
	There you are, you see.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And you say, you say, that a lot of ordinary people are missing
		out on this sense.
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': "
	I say that. I say that. And I think that's a shame.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So do I.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No I love this country. I do, I love it. Only trouble is
		there's nowhere to park, is there?
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Jane gets back home. She comes into the sitting-room, and screams. Pan 
	across to find Hugh with a blood-soaked knife, standing over the bodies 
	of an elderly couple.'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': "
	Oh my God ... what's happened? Victor ...?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I am bloody furious, Jennifer, I don't mind telling you.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': "
	The blood ... what's happened?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	What's happened? I've killed your parents, that's basically
		what's happened.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Stabbed them both to death.
'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	What ...?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I could not be more furious.
'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	Stabbed ... but why?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Exactly. Why? It was so unnecessary. That's why I'm so bloody
		annoyed.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Your father was being a bit ratty, complained that the tonic
		water was a bit flat, and suddenly I was stabbing him in the
		neck with a knife. I mean, what is going on here?
'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	You killed him?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yeah, alright, don't go on about it. I mean how do you think I
		feel?
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': "
	I don't know, Victor ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Bloody annoyed, that's how.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	Annoyed?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Somebody should have stopped this ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	But I had to go out ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No, no, I'm not blaming you, darling. Somebody. Police, social
		services. Somebody should have seen that this was a tragedy
		waiting to happen and done something about it. I really am
		livid.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	What about mother?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, she got in the way, tried to defend him, and suddenly she
		was lying there, dead, the victim of bureaucratic inefficiency.
		It just won't do.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	Have you called the police?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, no. I thought I'd write, actually. I think it would have
		more weight.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': "
	No, I mean, have you told them what you've done?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	What I've done?
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	Yes ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	What I've done. Oh that's nice. That's really charming. I stab
		your parents to death with a bread knife, and suddenly it's my
		fault, is it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	But Victor, darling, you did it. You said so yourself ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	My hand did it, Jennifer. My hand and the knife did it, yes.
		But what made my hand do it? That's what you should be asking
		yourself.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	Well, you...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No. Absolutely not. It's the system. I loved your parents,
		Jennifer. You know that. Your father sometimes smelt a bit, but
		they were lovely people, and now they're dead. All because the
		system failed. Again.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': "
	You're right. I shouldn't have left you alone. It's all my
		fault.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, that was my first reaction, I must admit. Bloody
		Jennifer, I thought, left me in a right pickle, but it's not
		you, darling. There are people paid to make sure this doesn't
		happen, and those people simply didn't do their job.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': "
	But if I'd been here ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	But you weren't, my angel. The system failed you, just like it
		failed me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	What are we going to do now?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, I've got a good mind to kill you, to be honest.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	Me?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Teach the bloody social services a lesson. See if they can talk
		their way out of three dead bodies. I'd like to see them try...
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': "
	Well, I'd rather you didn't.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, of course I'd rather I didn't. But my hand, Jennifer.
		What is making my hand do these things?
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	The system.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	The doorbell goes. Jane goes to answer it.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Thank you. The bloody system. These people, with their fat
		bloody salaries, sitting in their cosy little office while your
		parents, Jennifer, good people, honest, decent people, are
		being slaughtered. What is this country coming to?
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Jane comes back in with John.'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': '
	Mr Hammond?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': '
	Derek Broome, Social Services.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh, well, there you go. Hurrah for the bloody cavalry. I hope
		you're satisfied ...
"}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': "
	I'm sorry?
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': "
	Victor's killed my parents. Stabbed them with a knife.
"}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': '
	Oh damn.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh damn, yes, well, that's not a lot of use, is it? What have
		you got to say for yourself?
"}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': '
	Well you were down on my list, Mr Hammond, of tragedies waiting
		to happen, but I got held up.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	You hear that, Jennifer? Mr Broome "got held up". Jesus.
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': "
	If you'd accept my department's apologies, Mr Hammond, for the
		inconvenience this has caused you and your wife, and I'll see
		if I can't arrange a complimentary food hamper to be delivered
		here without delay.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, that's something.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': "
	It's not much good to my parents, though, is it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well said, Jennifer. Bloody well said.
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': "
	Well, how about this? These vouchers (hands over some slips of 
		paper) entitle you to dinner for two at the Laudanum Hotel,
		plus five years' bereavement counselling absolutely free.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	Hmm.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well. That's more like it.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Memory can play the wierdest tricks on you. It really can. I
		remembered something the other day, just as I was leaving the
		house, I turned round to lock the back door, and I remembered
		that I'd been violently abused as a child for nearly twelve
		years. Just came from nowhere. Amazing. I'm suing my parents
		for five million quid, as it happens. Course they died some
		years back, so I've got to sue myself as next of kin, but I
		think the principle's important.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Stephen addresses the camera.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes. Quite funny. But only quite.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(off) Thanks very much.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	But what can you do about it? Until recently, nothing. But
		ladies, and in a broader sense, gentlemen, m'colleague and I,
		concerned as ever with a relentless drive for higher standards,
		have decided to institute a Charter. A Charter that guarantees
		you the very highest standard of comic service.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh has joined Stephen.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The Charter, or Charter, that we are proposing contains a raft
		of key points, a key basket of top proposals and a top key
		package of key top measures, to ensure that you, the viewer ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	The customer ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The client ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	The punter or puntress ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The John or Jane Doe ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	The Fred or Frederica Bloggs ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The man ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Or ladygirl ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	The man or ladygirl who would have been on the Clapham omnibus,
		but discovered after waiting for two hours that it's been
		cancelled and replaced by a bright yellow transit van that only
		runs at peak times ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	... whenever the bleeding hell they are ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	To ensure that you have the right, the muscle, the arse-
		widening power, to MAKE A DIFFERENCE.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	There are two main prongs ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	By which we mean two main sticky-out bits at the end.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	There is quality and there is delivery.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Any joke which fails to come up to the normally high, rigorous,
		ruthless standards you would expect of A Bit Of Fry & Laurie  can be reported to the Charter Commission where it will be
		inspected by a top team of key experts, who will then pass it
		on to a key team of top experts.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	If your complaint is upheld the joke will be humanely
		destroyed.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Which brings us to our other sticky-out bit. Delivery.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Prong two. Delivery. In a modern society, jokes must be
		delivered on time: if you experience any delivery where the
		timing is too ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	... slow.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Or if the ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(interrupting) Quick.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	... timing should be ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Or if the joke simply never even ...
		
	Pause.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	The Commision will be only too happy to look into it. The
		Comedy Charter: peace of mind. Audience power. Your guarantee
		of service and quality ... without dripping.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Anyway. On with the ruthless subversion of family values.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You know that Kevin Major? Well I'd have to say that he's one
		of the most consistently impressive, dignified, articulate and
		rousing speakers I've ever heard.
		
	Stephen's voice off.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Thank you very much. And now could you give us an example of
		sarcasm?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well it's almost the same, isn't it?
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	An advertisement: the kind we get for didi-seven that they show in the 
	afternoons.'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': ' Stephen is lounging in a chair watching television. Newman and Baddiel comes on, so he decides to change channels. He looks around the sofa for his channel changer.'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': "
	(voice-over) Can't find that channel changer?
		
	Stephen digs a hand behind the sofa.
		
		Where did I put it last? Is this always happening to you?
		Sometimes actually have to get up to find it?
		
	Stephen raises his massive wobbling bulk off the sofa and looks under a 
	pile of satellite magazines.
		
		All those channels available in authentic cinema sound, plus
		laserdisc, CD-I, game gear, video, satellite, home-shopping ...
		but no use without a channel changer.
		
	Stephen really irritated.
		
		But who wants to get up and find it? Now there's the amazing
		Wristchanger.
		
	Stephen sits in front of TV, slumped in chair holding a Wristchanger.
		
		Available in a choice of one arresting colours and fabrics, the
		Wristchanger simply locks on to your wrist ...
		
	Stephen snaps it on to his wrist.
		
		... and need never be lost again. No more digging behind sofas,
		no more unnecessary and unpleasant standing up. Change channels
		with maximum comfort to all muscle groups.
		
	Stephen happily sorts through thousands of channels.
		
		But that isn't all. As an introductory offer to the
		Wristchanger, we're offering two more items designed to enhance
		viewer comfort.
		
	Stephen's knee begins to jog up and down.
		
		You know that feeling. You're settled in to your favourite
		American wrestling programme and suddenly ... Ow! Nature calls.
		
	Stephen reaches for an old milk bottle.
		
		Well now you can say goodbye to old milk bottles or the more
		distressing effort associated with standing up. Introducing
		Comfipee.
		
	Cutaway to strange item that might well be used by astronauts.
		
		Plumbed into your home, Comfipee allows you to expel those
		wastes that build up in the bladder after a hard afternoon's
		drinking of your favourite diet cola or isotonic drink (because
		sure, fitness is important) without having to leave the action.
		
	Stephen, watching, and obviously enjoying a good pee at the same time.
	A warm smile spreads over his face as he releases.
		
		But it doesn't stop there, because Comfipee comes with a
		completely free companion ... Comfipoo.
		
	Cutaway to an even stranger contraption.
		
		We know what those pizzas turn into inside your tummy. Before,
		you used to have to get up to do something about it. No longer.
		Comfipoo to the rescue.
		
	Stephen, watching TV and clearly enjoying a good crap.
		
		Comfipoo's built-in wiper, moist-wipe and talcum module gives
		you total freshness. Comfipee and Comfipoo ... real
		convenience. Remember, Wristchanger, Comfipee and Comfipoo are
		not available in the shops. Have your credit card handy while
		we tell you about the total eat, sleep, shop system you can
		enjoy. The Cradle To Grave In-Sofa Stayathome System.
		
	Stephen, with food dispenser attached to him.
		
		With the total viewing Stayathome System you need never get up
		out of that chair again ... guaranteed! You order your food and
		your new decoders and videos through home shopping, you enjoy
		them all in-sofa. From cradle to grave, a world of
		entertainment just for you.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	John is at a kitchen counter in the studio. Stephen is at his side.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	But less of that earlier. John, you've been looking forward to
		the summer salad season, I believe.
"}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': "
	I certainly have, Chris. A lot of supermarkets these days
		package fresh herbs. I'm particularly fond of this one here.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Lifts a pinch of some green dried herb from a small bowl.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Delicious, I must say. Dill?
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': "
	Well, no and that's the point.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	It is?
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': "
	It is. But I've found this very handy way of preparing it. The
		usual problem is one of wet lips rotting away the paper.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hello.
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': '
	But if you take an ordinary Rizzla packet like this.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Brings out Rizzla packet.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Woah.
'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': '
	You can simply tear the strip off here and use it to form a
		protective cardboard roach. That way the herb ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(hastily) Let's see what Jane and Frank are up to over there.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Cut to Hugh and Jane.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, here we are, with Jane's blind taste test. Ready, Jane?
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Jane has a blindfold on.'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': "
	As I'll ever be.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh screams with laughter.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	As I'll ever be, dear oh dear ...
		
	Jane sips at a glass of red wine.
		
		Any thoughts at all, Jane?
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	Wine?
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Huge applause.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Incredible. Can you name the colour?
'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	White.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh ... Very nearly. Very nearly indeed. Have another go ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	Well ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Go on, one more go. I'm sure you'll get it this time ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	Blue?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Nggg ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': "
	I know! It's red. Definitely red.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Huge applause.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Jane, that is remarkable. Have a go at this one.
		
	Hands her another glass - she sips.
		
		Thoughts?
'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	Oh I know this one. Its a Pomerol.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': "
	... late growth '89, Manon des Haut Louvarges ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Extraordinary.
'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	... from the north side of the hill ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	North it is ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	... 8.85 ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	... yes ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	... opened with an air-injection cork pull ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	... yes ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	... poured out by a middle-aged man with cream-coloured
		trousers, who lives in Putney ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(calls) Tony?
'}, {'speaker': 'Voice off', 'text': '
	Mortlake.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Mortlake, but near enough. Anything else?
'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	... thirty-three to one outsider Saffron Lad will win the
		National by eight lengths, there will be a mild earthquake in
		Mexico City at the end of August, the Liberal Democrats will
		take South Molesley with a thirty per cent swing, and Frank ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Still here, my darling ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	You should beware of anyone called Rupert ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Will do ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Jane', 'text': '
	And electric fans.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Rupert and electric fans, gotcha.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Rolling violins. Hugh is standing at a bridge in the snow, red-eyed,
	hopeless waves of despair rolling and breaking over him. He is unshaven 
	and a trail of blood comes from his lip. He stares into the swirling 
	waters below, shaking his head. He has an Australian accent.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It's over. It's all over. Just end it. The whole bloody thing's
		gone, finished, over with. Face it, the world would be a better
		place without you. I should never have been born. Oh, Jesus.
		
	He bites his knuckle in despair. Stephen approaches him in the 
	background. Hugh climbs over the bridge.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Don't do it, son. Oh my.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Splosh! Hugh has jumped in. Stephen sighs and jumps in after him.
	   Cut to: Cabin. John, as a hugely double-taking old man is staring 
	and gulping and starting in the background.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Who? What? I ... what the? I ... who? But ... I never ... oh
		God ... what the ... how many?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	There now, there now. Take it easy.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	But I ... I should be dead. How the hell did I ... ? Who are
		you?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Me? Clarence Cosy, angel, second class. And your name is
		Rupert.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	How did you know that?
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "
	John's goggling takes and double-takes propel him backwards. He looks 
	at his tea-pot and shakes his head."}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I've granted your wish. You've never been born.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh Jesus. That's all I need. Hey!
		
	He rubs his chin and is amazed to discover that he is no longer 
	unshaven and he no longer has a cut coming from his lip.
		
		Well shag me twice.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	What's that?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Water must have healed my cut.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	What cut? There's never been any cut. You were never born.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Look, angel, do us a favour, will you? Fly away, for
		Chrissakes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Can't. Haven't got my wings yet.
"}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': '
	(goggling) Doh!
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm getting out of here.
		
	Hugh runs out into the street. Hugh looks with amazement at an empty 
	parking space.
		
		Oh great. That's all I need. Now some cockwit has stolen my
		sodding car.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(coming up behind) But you haven't got a car. You were never
		born, Rupert.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Look, I don't know who you are, and I don't know under what law
		you have been released into the community, but just frig off
		will you?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Angels don't frig, Rupert. We don't have the training.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Look. Get this, tiny Tim. I own the largest conglomeration of
		newspaper and satellite television companies in the world, and
		right now I have better things to do than stand here talking to
		a chocolate cake like you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh dear. Don't you understand? I am your guardian angel. I'm
		going to show you what this town would have been like if you
		hadn't been born. That way I'll show you that your life is
		worth living after all. The countless differences you've made
		to people's lives, the joy you've spread, the difference you've
		made.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm going home. Where's a bloody mini-cab?
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	A black London taxi cab pulls up and John, the cheery driver, pulls 
	down the window.'}, {'speaker': 'John', 'text': '
	Where to, guv?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Wapping High Street ... wait a minute ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	See? What a difference you made?
		
	Inside the cab.
		
		If you'd never been born, there would still be black cabs like
		this, with drivers who actually know where they're going. But
		you came along and told everyone that black cabs were a wicked
		monopoly, and that everyone had better use mini cabs belonging
		to the company that you own. Knackered old Datsuns with no
		brakes and drivers who've just escaped from Pentonville.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I did that?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Exactly. You see? You made a difference.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	The cab pulls up and Stephen and Hugh get out. Stephen pays off the 
	driver, who departs with a cheery wave. Hugh looks round the street.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Wait an arsing second here. Where the hell are all the
		satellite dishes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	There aren't any.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What the ... ?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You haven't been born, I keep telling you. People don't have
		satellite television, they don't have the chance to watch World 
		Wrestling and Wheel of Fortune and Video Bloopers twenty-four
		hours a day. They're still forced to sit and watch BBC and ITV,
		with all those drama and sport and news programmes. You did
		away with all that.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I did?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Swept it away. You pretended it was to give people more choice,
		but it was actually just to make you fabulously rich.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Wow.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Come on.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Inside a pub. Black and white patrons, standing shoulder to shoulder.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Steady on. Not my kind of place.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What do you mean?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Black people.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Don't you like black people?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, I mean, I don't think they're gonna like me much ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No, no, no. I keep telling you. Because you've never been born,
		the Sun newspaper has never been able to tell anyone to hate
		their neighbour because they're black, or gay, or left-wing.
		Without you, people might have grown up liking each other. And
		liking this country. They might even like you.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh is leafing through a tabloid paper, while Stephen orders a couple 
	of drinks.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Jesus mothering arse! Where the hell are the tits?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	They're on the front of women's chests. I think the editor
		probably thought it wasn't much of a news story.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yeah, but you've got to have tits to sell a paper ...
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	The barman brings the drinks.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well apparently not. Apparently, without the Sun debasing
		people's view of the world with every sentence it produces,
		people turn out to be interested in all sorts of other things.
		Strange, isn't it?
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "
	The drinks arrive and Hugh pushes aside Stephen's offer to pay."}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'll get these.
		
	He brings out some coins and stops.
		
		Bloody hell. Who's this?
		
	He holds up a coin showing the Queen's head.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It's the Queen. They still have one, you see.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	People start singing a carol in the background.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Christ, get me the cock out of here.
		
	Stephen and Hugh walk through the street back towards the bridge.

		(looking over the bridge) It's brilliant. Totally bloody
		brilliant. Big red buses, free hospitals, an amusing royal
		family, proper taxis, decent newspapers, best television in the
		world. People getting on with each other ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You like it? You really like it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It's fantastic. It's paradise. Help me Clarence, please, I want
		to live again. Jeez.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well, Rupert, this is marvellous news I must say.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Just think of the money I could make in a world like this. I
		could introduce big tits, I could break up the broadcasting
		monopolies, I could destroy The Times, the BBC, the Royal
		Family, I could make a bloody fortu-
		
	Stephen pushes him over the side and watches him fall.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Twat.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	My wife was pulled down the other day and rebuilt just north of
		Leicester. Damn shame.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh is striding about in the middle of a disgusting mall. He is rather 
	pukka and excitedly leading the camera hither and thither.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It's extraordinary. I should say the house was exactly here.
		The front door must have been there, round about where that
		branch of Next is. Of course all around this area was our
		garden. When my dog Hamper died, border collie with the
		loveliest laugh, it was the saddest day of my life. Couldn't
		believe Hamper was really dead, but my father insisted he was.
		Harsh lesson. Learnt young. Anyway, part of the process of
		grieving is burial, so I buried him, I should think round about
		here, under this paving stone it must have been.
		
	Hugh kicks the paving stone and it comes loose.
		
		Whoops ... so much for 1990s build quality, eh?
		
	The whole slab comes off and a border collie climbs out.
		
		Good Lord, Hamper! I was right all along. Come along then,
		you'll be hungry.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(female) You can't even trust professionals these days. I went
		to see a masseur, you know for a massage. Disgusting. He
		couldn't keep his hands off me..
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'A fuzzy, amateurish-looking video shot of Stephen and Hugh in some kind of office. Record of an official interview. Hugh speaks softly and caringly.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Where did he touch you, can you remember?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Er ... on the hand, I suppose.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	On the hand, I see. Which hand, do you remember?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Er ... right, usually.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right usually, I see. Was it violent?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well ... firm.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Firm. Firm. Alright. Now, I've got a doll here. Can you show me
		with the doll exactly what he used to do?
		
	Hugh brings out an Action Man and hands it to Stephen.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	He didn't use a doll.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No, no. Pretend the doll is you, and show me what he used to
		do.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Right, well ... he would take my hand like this, and he would
		move it up and down a few times like this.
		
	Stephen shakes hands with the Action Man.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And this happened every day, you say?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Every day, when he left for work. Except weekends. He stayed at
		home at weekends, so there was no need for him to shake my
		hand, I suppose.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right. And did he threaten you? Make you promise to keep this
		little secret of yours?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You don't remember.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No, I do remember. He didn't threaten me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, let's say that you don't remember not remembering.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No, I do remember remembering, because I remember thinking - I
		must remember this.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You're in denial.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'm sorry.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Denial, is what we call the state that you are currently in.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Denial, as everyone knows, is in Egypt.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Stephen, in drag, is in a box at a concert hall, a packed house behind him and an orchestra tuning up.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Hello and three dozen welcomes to the Harrowgate Young Tory of 
		the Year, here at the Daily Mail Hall, Horrorgate, in front of
		an invited audience of local businessmen and their slightly
		awkward teenage children in pony-tails and annoying ties. With
		me is one of the judges, Brent Wheeler, and he'll be giving
		expert advice and telling us what to look out for. Good evening
		Brent.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Quite right.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Brent, the standard last year was incredibly high, do you think
		we can look for something similar this year?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, Susan, I think we probably can. I've been a judge for
		some of the local heats and I can tell you the talent this year
		is as awesome as ever it's been.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	This being the night of the finals, the competitors will be
		concentrating on keynote speeches and displays of general
		prejudice and ignorance, is that right?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	More or less. There is a new round this year, however, a
		Getting Shiny-faced in a T-shirt round.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	T-shirt? That sounds very ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, this is the way modern Young Toryism is being developed.
		T-shirts show that it isn't just an art for the middle classes,
		but has general American street fashion-wise appeal for the
		young and hip-trendy.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Right, well. The lights are going down behind me as you can
		probably hear, and our first competitor, Andrew Tredgold is
		ready to go on.
		
	Hugh, as a Young Tory, Andrew Tredgold, steps on to the stage with a 
	speech. There is a blue cyclorama behind him with a Union Jack-Arrow 
	logo and the slogan "Forward with into Britain tomorrow right step".

		(hushed voice) Andrew is in his second year at Exeter reading
		Human Bigotry and Libertarian Nonsense. He counts amongst his
		inspirations the "Family Values" theme by Kevin Patten, the
		"Further Cuts in Public Expenditure" suite by Kenneth Clarke,
		arranged Portillo, and the "Endless Variations in J. Major".
		So, Andrew Tredgold, South West regional winner.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh stands in front of those perspex autocue screens and clears his 
	throat. Stephen is the conductor, a la Simon Rattle. The orchestra 
	plays "I Vow to Thee my Country" underneath. Andrew watches nervously 
	as Stephen gives him a reassuring smile and then cues him.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(as Andrew: becoming INCREDIBLY fast) Conference. Core values,
		real punishment for offenders, family standards, opportunity
		for individual enterprise, roll back the frontiers of the
		state, Michael's bold and imaginative initiative, and yes, why
		not corporal punishment, really crack down, young offenders,
		rules of law, and yes I make no apology, respect for ordinary
		decent vast majority, welfare spongers, as Norman said so
		clearly, individual enterprise culture, opportunity attack on
		trendy liberal educational wishy-washy to pick up on Kevin's
		wonderfully forceful point, sloppy thinking, sixties, in
		Michael's bold and imaginative values, standards, decency,
		family, law, yes. I make no apology and why not even perhaps,
		God and pride in country, decent ordinary sloppy people, vast
		majority of bold new initiatives, decent, family standards,
		core values, return to fifties, reponsibility, individual,
		respect, standard, values, and yes, why not, values, respect,
		standards, ordinary, decent apology, I make no standards, vast
		family law, and why not sloppy corporal God punishment
		individual decent spongers wishy-washy trendy family crime
		Michael values. Thank you.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Huge applause.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well, the audience absolutely loving Andrew's performance
		there. But what will the judges make of it, I wonder? Brent.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, it was wonderfully confident and assured, wasn't it?
		Original, though. I'm not sure how much the judges will like
		that. Did you notice in one of the earlier passages he opted
		for "family standards" instead of the more classically correct
		"family values"? But the technique was astonishing for one his
		age: he was every bit as insulting as a Tory twice his age.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Any actual mistakes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Not real mistakes, no.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I thought at one point that he was going to say something that
		made sense.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	He just managed to avoid that, didn't he? A tense moment. But,
		no. Very assured, very ghastly: completely sucked dry of youth,
		energy, ideals, imagination, love, passion or intelligence.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well, while the audience vomit we'll return you to the shop
		where we bought you.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen, as a solicitor, sits at a table in a police interview room,
	next to Kevin, his client. Hugh sits opposite with Fiona, a WPC, next 
	to him. Kevin is upset.'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Yes, yes I admi ...
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh holds up a hand to silence Kevin.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(switching on recorder: speaking in routine monotone) Wednesday
		4th April 1994, 18.32 hours. Detective Sergeant Carter
		interviewing Jonathan Dumayne, Mr William Ponce, solicitor and
		WPC ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And commissioner for oaths ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And commissioner for oaths, and WPC Helen Thompson are also in
		attendance. Mr Parker has been advised of his rights.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh appears to have finished.'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	I ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	This interview is being conducted in accordance with the Police
		and Criminal Evidence Act 1987, Section 17, Interview
		Procedure, and is being recorded on chromium dioxide tape, with
		Dolby C noise reduction engaged, delivering magnetic tape
		registration through twin direct drive spindle-heads tracking
		at 57 revolutions per minute outputting 200 watts per channel.
		The unit is powered by alternating current at 240 volts with a
		maximum of 7.5 amps.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Again Hugh seems to have shot his bolt.'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': "
	I don't really know why I ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Mr Parker is wearing a light grey worsted wool jacket with
		slashed pockets and double vent with a configuration of three
		buttons, at present unfastened. His shirt is a woollen cotton
		mix of the type commonly known as Vyella. No tie. His
		trousers ...
		
	Hugh looks under the table.
		
		... are a dark blue drill cotton, in the diagonal weave often
		referred to as chino. Odd socks and a pair of Air Wear shoes,
		known as DMs, short for Doctor Marten, the inventor of this
		brand of cushioned rubber sole which is acid splash resistant,
		hardy, comfortable and pleasantly styled. The prisoner is
		currently refreshing himself with a cup of tea and a biscuit
		brought by the duty sergeant. He has chosen an English
		breakfast blend taken with semi-skimmed milk and a half
		teaspoonful of the low calorie aspartame sweetener Candarel
		Spoonful which can help reduce weight only as part of a calorie
		controlled diet. Of the range of quality biscuits on offer he
		selected a McVitie's Boaster. The prisoner is aware that this
		interview is being recorded.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "
	Hugh has apparently shot his bolt. Kevin is doubtful. He opens his 
	mouth, finds that Hugh isn't going to speak, so starts himself."}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	I suppose I just ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Mr Ponce has opted for a suit of slate grey herring-bone, from
		the Marks & Spencer Elegance range, teamed with a two-fold
		poplin short ... collar stiffeners?
		
	Stephen nods.
		
		Mr Ponce has indicated that collar stiffeners are inserted.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	In the collars.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	WPC Thompson is wearing regulation Metropolitan Police white
		blouse ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	Blouson.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I beg your pardon, blouson with ... what colour would you call
		that skirt?
'}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	Navy.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	... navy skirt with chequered tie-thing.
'}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	Stock.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	... with chequered stock. I note the application of a coral
		lipstick and an amber foundation cream of the colouring known
		as Gay Whisper.
		
	Fiona nods that this is correct.
		
		Her hair is attractively arranged with a delightful cow-lick
		reminiscent of the 1960s model Jean Shrimpton and the styling
		techniques of the then fashionable Vidal Sassoon. A light day-
		time fragrance has been applied to her pulse-points. The citrus
		top-notes with a deep bass of vetiver and wood-bark tells me
		that the favoured scent is Diorella, by Christian Dior of
		Paris, New York and London.
'}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	Dioressence.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Damn.
'}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	Very close ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Dioressence, by Christian Dior of the previously mentioned
		cities. Right, Mr Dumayne ...
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh has stopped. After a couple of false starts Kevin realises his 
	moment has come.'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	I am extremely happy to tell you the full facts of the ...
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	There is a loud clunk. They all look at the machine. Then at the 
	camera. A trumpet goes: MWA MWA MWA ...'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	As I travel round the country, giving speeches and replacing
		lengths of guttering in high buildings, I have become
		increasingly distressed at the ignorance and prejudice that
		seems to surround the whole business of sucking. This used to
		be a dynamic nation; a nation of skill and know-how, of
		determination and vision. The rest of the world used to look to
		us for a lead on sucking, and we were happy, proud I should
		say, to give it. Now, well you can ask the average Briton to
		suck something for you in the street, even something quite
		small, like a hedge, and like as not he'll just shrug his
		shoulders and move on. That's sad. Terribly, terribly sad.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Fiona grins nervously at the camera.'}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': "
	Hello.
		
	Pause.
		
		Doesn't seem to be anybody here. I expect one of them'll turn
		up in a minute.
		
	Pause.
		
		But for the time being, it rather looks as if I'm sort of ...
		on my own ...
		
	Stephen's voice booms out from nowhere, lots of echo.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's right, my dear. You are quite, quite alone.
"}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': "
	Who's that?
		
	Fiona looks round the studio. The camera zooms into odd things like 
	lamps and coffee cups. Lily Marlene starts playing, cracklingly.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	The fog has settled on the moor, and may not lift for days.
'}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	Show yourself. Who are you?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Come, my dear, don't say that you've forgotten?
"}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	Forgotten who? What ...?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Welwyn Garden City. 1974. Debenhams car park.
'}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	Max?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I waited, Fiona. I waited a long, long time. But you never
		came. Why didn't you come, Fiona? I waited ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': "
	The traffic ... I had a flat headache ... my wife turned up ...
		the fire burnt down ... oh what's the use ... oh Max, Max,
		Max ...
		
	Fiona collapses on to the sofa, sobbing. When she looks up, Stephen is 
	standing over her.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I have waited a long time for this moment.
'}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': "
	Max, I'm sorry.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sorry? Sorry? You think you can leave me with three bags of
		quite heavy shopping, run off to Paris with your lover-dancing-
		boy-laughter, and then say "sorry"?
'}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': "
	Max, you don't understand ... I was young, I was in love ...
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh comes on.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Hello. Fiona? M'colleague. What's going on.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Fiona and Stephen assume airs of complete innocence.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Nothing.
'}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	Nothing at all.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	We were just chatting.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Fiona. You look fabulous like that. Alive. Feline. Arousing.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No ... (pointing to Fiona) ... THAT'S Fiona.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Big ones, small ones, thin ones, fat ones, stiff ones, floppy
		ones, ones that hang to the left, ones that hang to the right.
		I'm talking of course, about penises. What are they for? They
		expel waste fluids from the male bladder, they serve as a
		conduit in the process of insemination, but what else? You
		can't drive them. You can't live in them. You can't wear them.
		You can't borrow money from them at any rates, never mind
		favourable ones, so all in all, what good are they? I wrote to
		the Duchess of Kent to find out. I haven't received an answer
		yet.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh is Henry Kelly. Stephen is Colin. Beside him are Kevin and Fiona.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Hello and welcome to English People Appear to be the Most 
		Ignorant in Europe. I shall be asking questions of our three
		likely contestants, Dieter Schomer, who is a dental technician
		from Hamburg, Andrea Larsen who is a dental technician from
		Oslo, and Colin Mint, who is a dental technician from Tunbridge
		Wells in Kent. Let's go straight into the first round. Dieter,
		your question. I am a female journalist who came to fame in the
		1960s, presenting Blue Peter...
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Valerie Singleton.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Correct. Andrea. I am an underground station on London's
		Northern Line, situated between Warren Street and Tottenham
		Court ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	Goodge Street ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Correct. Colin. Ich bin ein geflunsigge sturmfische, betolden
		lemhausen feuneubische, stem hamburg von ledentrader masch
		fenvarsentleiter und grobbische.
		
	Stephen looks vacant.
		
		Have a guess ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Mary Queen of Scots.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	The answer I was looking for, Colin, was William Waldegrave.
		Bad luck. (To camera.) Ladies and gentlemen, we're thrilled to
		be able to present this next item. Dame Victoria Bennett stars
		in Alan Wood's acclaimed prestige dramatic monologue Well I 
		Never Did.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Beautifully shot in video, like the '}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh, yes ... yes ... well, I'll never forget this one. That was
		before they pulled down the gasworks and built that Netto
		Superstore. Oh, he looks good in his Littlewood's Keynote
		cardie, does our Alan. I said at the time, I said "Alan, if you
		want to get on in the world, you'd be wise to write down
		everything I say, because it's gold, is what I say. And don't
		hog the Peak Freenes, lad. Pass them round." Lovely boy he was.
		Teeth weren't his strong feature, of course, and his hair
		wasn't what you'd call Leslie Howard, but I always say, "Teeth
		is teeth, what does it matter so long as you've got your
		wealth?" He said, "I can't wait to get out of here, Auntie Ivy,
		and make my fortune down south." I said to him, straight, I
		said, "Alan," I said, "I may not be as cabbage looking as my
		tongue is a fisherman's doiley, but what's London got that you
		won't find in the Arndale Centre in Todmodern?" Well, he was
		stuck for a reply. I said, "You want sophistication, you stick
		with us up here, love." He knew I was right, bless him. I mean
		we've got a Body Shop in the parade now and you can't move for
		Volvo's in the autumn months. But then he's always had his head
		in the clouds has our Alan. Caught him trying to scour a milk
		pan with a tea bag once. I said "It's all very well knowing
		long words, but if you can't tell the difference between a box
		of brillo pad and a packet of Typhoo One-Cup, you'll never get
		on." I'll go to the back of our fridge.
		   He did leave, though. Got a scholarship to Oxford. I said,
		"You make sure as there's somewhere as you can buy Kendall Mint
		Cake, and a good bar of Wright's coal tar soap, because they've
		no idea, down there." Well, I mean fancy ideas and tropical mix
		croutons are all very well, but they don't get the Vimto
		buttered, do they? For all your fine Italian red lettuce, which
		to my mind tastes as bitter as a Skipton wind. He said "Auntie
		Ivy, I'll be fine." Well of course I didn't know him when he
		came back. Green corduroy jacket and duffle coat, horn-rimmed
		spectacles you could eat parsley out of and a head crammed with
		I don't know what. And books, you've never seen so many. Some
		of them that dirty I blushed to the roots of my Playtex. I
		said, "Alan," I said, "those books are going straight into the
		Hotpoint and no buts." Came up lovely they did. Amazing what a
		bit of Lenor can do if you've a mind. No, but that Oxford and
		his smart friends, they've changed him. Ideas, that's what it
		is. I said, "What use is ideas when you've a capon to baste and
		the tally-man's due any minute? Name an idea," I said, "that
		can get the front steps scrubbed, the sausages pricked and the
		navel oranges squeezed in time for a meat tea and finger
		buffet." Well, he didn't know which way to look. These Oxford
		types, they're all apricot facial scrub and yesterday's suet
		turnover: to look at them you'd think a packet of Bachelor's
		Savoury Rice wouldn't melt in their Vosene Medicated, but
		they've no savvy. I could take a Black and Decker nose drill to
		the pack of them and still have change left over for a bag of
		peanut brittle.
		  Left home of course, got involved with the BBC, all party
		eggs and tomato chutney. Next thing I know he's got a damehood
		and a brand new hostess trolley to show for it. They'll fall
		for anything them Londoners. Well, I'm off down to Morrison's
		for a jar of melon lip balm and a four-pack of interuterine
		devices. Got that Pat Routledge round for elocution lessons at
		twelve. Tarra.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Okay, so the woman was mad. She was mad, she was paranoid, she
		was megalomaniac and she was completely deluded. But somehow
		when she was in charge, you know, Blue Peter was Blue Peter.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh sits on the edge of a desk and talks to camera, in front of a
	portrait of Adolf Hitler, and assorted swastika-like symbols.
		'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You know, there's been a lot in the news recently, about the
		rise of fascism. It's the next big thing, they say, but what
		exactly is it? What kind of music do fascists listen to? What
		do they wear? Are there clubs you can go to? Kevin, you're an
		old fascist from way back, what's it all about?
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Well, what first got me hooked was the uniform ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Do you have your uniform with you at all?
'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': "
	Well, I'm wearing it now.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh that's it, is it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': "
	Yeah. It's very comfortable, hard-wearing, and I just ... I
		don't know ... I think I look good in it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You do Kevin, you look marvellous. If I was homosexual, I'd
		want to buy you a drink at the very least.
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': "
	Thanks. If I was homosexual, I'd have a pint of lager.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	As it is, I like birds.
'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Me too.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Now Kevin. Music. What sort of music do you listen to? What's
		your thing? What's your bag? What's your ... I suppose what I'm
		trying to say is, what sort of music do you listen to?
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Oh all sorts. Military bands, bit of Wagner ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Because Hitler liked a bit of all that, didn't he?
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	He certainly did ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Now, for the people watching, it's worth pointing out that
		Hitler was quite a big name in the Fascism business ... what,
		back in the seventies ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Even earlier than that ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Earlier than the seventies, wow. Right in there at the
		beginning. Like a sort of Elvis figure.
'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Yeah ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Now tell me about Hitler. There's been a lot of stuff written
		about him, magazine profiles and all that ... what do you think
		he was really like?
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	He was a wild guy.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's what I'd heard. I'd heard he liked to live on the
		edge ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Absolutely.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Wow, that's really interesting. Did he have a philosophy, at
		all? I mean, was he a Kevin Lennon kind of guy?
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	The supremacy of the Aryan race was his sort of inspiration, I
		suppose.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yeah, and a sort of segregationy thing, I suppose?
'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Yeah. Racial purity ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Racial purity, all that stuff ... But of course, tragically, he
		died, didn't he?
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': "
	That's right.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Drugs, was it? I think ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	He shot himself ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh that's really sad. I guess he must have been depressed, or
		something.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(as woman: holds up a Body-Form Ultra) It's ever so thin. Much
		thinner than conventional towels. That's an advantage. The
		disadvantage is that you need about twelve just to dry your
		hair. Conventional towels have the edge there, I feel.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "
	Kevin is in a patient's bed in a hospital room. Fiona, his devoted 
	wife, sits at his side. Stephen is examining him, be-white coated. He 
	has a stethoscope to Kevin's chest.
	   Hugh suddenly enters, dressed as a nurse, and speaks with 
	unaccustomed ferocity to the camera."}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes, alright, it's a sketch in a hospital ward. I'm so sorry.
		I'm so sorry that we're not breaking moulds and deconstructing
		forms and pushing envelopes and drinking strange new types of
		lager in underground bars with tight hipster jeans hanging from
		our earlobes. I'm sorry we haven't "raised interesting
		questions" about the nature of gender assignment, or peeled
		back the veneer of cultural denial. I am so nose-blowingly
		sorry.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You're not at all.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You're damn bloody right I'm not. It's a hospital room, he's a
		doctor, he's a patient. Oh dear. Oh arsing dear, what a
		disappointment. Where are the challenged perceptions there, I
		don't wonder for a single hair-gelled bloody minute?
		
	Hugh goes.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Say "ah".
'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Ah.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Say "twim".
'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Twim.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Twim.
'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Twim.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Fadabberhaweeeeee.
'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Fadabberhaweeeeee.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Twim.
'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Twim.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh comes back in, really angry.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	They do still exist, you know. Hospitals. Just because a lot of
		twats in leather waistcoats and black polo-necks fart their way
		through the Late Show talking about "tapping into the dark
		underbelly of British social repression", doesn't mean that
		hospitals don't exist, or that people don't go to them when
		they're ill.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hugh?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Get out.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh goes.'}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	Well, Doctor?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well, Doctor, yes. Hmm. Alright, situation is this. We have a
		heart, standing by, ready to go. Nice little heart, too. Red,
		which is the only colour, really, for hearts, I always think.
		Pump pump pump. That side of things is all fine.
'}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	Oh thank God ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	But, and this is a pretty fat but, you ... are a smoker, are
		you not, Mr Spiers?
'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	I occasionally ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You occasionally smoke cigarettes, yes, I thought so.
'}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	Is that a problem?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It is, rather, I'm afraid. Puts us in a hell of a position. Mr
		Twovey doesn't smoke, you see?
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': "
	Who's Mr Twovey?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Nice chap, two rooms down. Came in just after you, also hoping
		for a heart. Never smoked in his life. Or smoked once, rather,
		but didn't inhale. So he says.
"}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': "
	You mean ... you're going to give it to him? The one heart
		you've got, you're going to give it to Mr Twovey?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Not necessarily. As I say, he's a nice enough chap, but by God,
		you should see him eating soup.
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Soup?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Revolting sight. Slurping and sucking, spilling it all over the
		place ... quite revolting.
'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Now I've watched you eating soup, Mr Spiers, and it's rather an
		attractive sight. You hold the spoon properly, tilt the bowl
		away from you, suck out of the side of the spoon rather than
		the end, and you're very neat about it. Very neat indeed.
"}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	So ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	So, you're more or less level on that score. You don't dress as
		well as he does ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': "
	Don't I?
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen opens the cupboard next to the bed.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Look at this. Ghastly Viyella check shirt, simply doesn't go
		with this jacket ... whereas Mr Twovey came in in a very
		elegant two-button dark grey flannel suit.
"}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	I told you to wear the blue shirt. I said, wear the blue
		shirt ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	But at least you don't bite your finger nails, that's
		something.
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': "
	No, that's right. I don't. Or I may have done once, but I
		didn't inhale ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Twovey's a real chewer. Revolting, stumpy little fingernails.
		Makes me sick to look at them. No, this really is a tricky
		one ...
		
	Stephen deliberates. Kevin and Fiona look at each other in desperation.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	He does a lot of work in the community ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'm sorry?
"}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	Gerald is very active within the community ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Hmm. I've never quite understood what that means ... I mean,
		burglars are very active within the community ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	But Gerald does a lot of good work ... and his family are very
		fond of him ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Mr Twovey's family are devoted to him ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	Does ever such as lot for Children in Need and Comic Relief.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Mr Twovey once spent a whole day in women's clothes for the ITV
		Telethon.
"}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': '
	Gerald once met Esther Rantzen.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Did you indeed?
'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': "
	Yes, but I didn't inhale.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Mm. Eeny, meeny, miney ... yes, Nurse, what is it?
		
	Hugh has entered. He whispers into Stephen's ear. On his way out he 
	flicks a V at the camera.
		
		Well, there's a relief. We do now have another heart in, so we
		can service you both.
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': '
	Never!
'}, {'speaker': 'Fiona', 'text': "
	Oh, Doctor that's ... can I kiss you?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	If I can punch you violently in the throat, yes. Now. Since I'm
		here I might as well give you first choice. The first heart
		comes from a young squash-player, twenty-five, from Aberdeen,
		and this new one's from a sixty-five-year-old Tory Cabinet
		Minister.
"}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': "
	Oh I'll take the Cabinet Minister's, definitely.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Why?
'}, {'speaker': 'Kevin', 'text': "
	Because it's never been used.
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen, Kevin and Fiona all turn to the camera and smile winningly.
	Hugh comes on and glares.'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Stephen and Hugh address the nation.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You know, we've had a whole armpitful of letters from a viewer
		recently, asking whether she can join the Fry & Laurie Fan
		Club, and I'm afraid, Giselle of Nuneaton, the answer is no,
		because there isn't one.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Wasn't one.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's right. There also wasn't one, as well as there being an
		isn't one.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What a magical weaver of words you are, Hugh.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Cheers.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	What I mean is, there wasn't one, but there is one now.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hello?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Or rather there are two.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	We've got one each? Shrewd. Very shrewd.
