"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No, our legs have got one each.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Sorry?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	One club is called the Fry & Laurie Left Leg Club, and the
		other is called ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Don't tell me ... no, actually you'd better tell me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	They Fry & Laurie Right Leg Club. For the frighteningly
		reasonable sum of 450 a month, you will be entitled to a
		yearly newsletter, containing articles, profiles, photographs,
		competitions, crosswords, and in-depth interviews with our
		right legs.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What extraordinarily good value this offer seems to represent.
		And does membership of the Right Leg Club give you automatic
		membership of the Left Leg Club?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Sadly no, Hugh. We may be generous, but we're not nice.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Gotcha.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Membership of the Left Leg Club however is slightly cheaper, at
		390 a month.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Now why would that be, I wonder?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I don't know. Marketing boys came up with it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Interesting. Couldn't we get any grown-ups to do our marketing?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	But if you join both clubs at once, you will be entitled to
		this T-shirt ...
		
	Stephen holds up a plain white T-shirt.
		
		... with our famous catchphrase on it. We will also send you a
		fully automatic Frank Windsor as part of this once-in-a-
		lifetime introductory offer.
		
	Picture of Frank Windsor flashes up on the screen.
		
		Anyway, that's enough merchandising news. Until the same time
		next week, eat plenty of hot meals and take heaps of exercise.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh and ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Shut up.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I get this terrible reaction, when I eat chocolate. I get awful
		rashes all over my body, and this odd, greeny-blue pus starts
		to leak out from my armpits, revolting smell, and I get these
		terrible pains up and down my legs, I sometimes just scream for
		hours with the agony of it, and then my liver fails altogether
		and I usually have to be rushed into casualty and have a drip
		put in my arm, and all the time I've got these headaches that
		make me think my brain is going to explode, and I'm covered in
		pus, my liver gone, legs burning pain and I say to myself, I
		couldn't half murder a Twix.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Aerial shot of a large stately home. Grand music.
	   Stephen is standing in his study, stroking a labrador. Hugh, in a 
	dress, is sitting on a sofa, petting a spaniel.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I suppose in a way we are very lucky. A lot of people would
		consider us very privileged. Actually, you see, I don't own
		Hartington Castle. It doesn't actually belong to me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Voice off', 'text': '
	Yes it does.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes. It does. It does. In that sense it does. I do own it. But
		I think, I always think, that actually I've simply borrowed it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Voice', 'text': '
	Who from?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	From my children.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(softly) That's lovely.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It's a trust. I'm just the bloody caretaker, you know? Just the
		bloody old caretaker.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	We don't really use this room, do we?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's right. My grandfather used this room. They say Lloyd
		George vomited in that awful silver bucket thing over there.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	We rather hate that, don't we?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Can't stand the sight of it. Now this is rather fun ...
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen takes a small metal object from a display case.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Great fun ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Have a guess at what that might be.
		
	Close up of the object.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Voice', 'text': '
	Oyster knife?
		
	Stephen chuckles richly. So does Hugh.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	A lot of people say that. Actually it's not an oyster knife.
		Have another guess.
		
	Interviewer says something we can't quite hear.
		
		Not that. I don't even know what an interuterine device is,
		actually. Have another guess. (Pause.) No? I'll tell you. It's
		just a knife. An ordinary knife. We keep it here. Can't sell
		the bloody thing of course. Costs a fortune just to keep it
		heated. But it's rather fun and it's a heck of a thought that
		my great grandchildren will take it out some time next century.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Such fun.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(putting it back carefully) Great fun.
		
	Cut to garden. Hugh is pruning roses in the background and doing 
	something rather silly with them. Stephen stands by a fountain.
		
		That's the challenge of course. You know. One's descendants. If
		my bloody ancestors ... mostly a gang of old crooks actually...
		if they could keep this damned thing going, without the
		advantage of mains shopping and what have you, then ... you
		know, as I say. This (pointing at flower bed) is rather
		interesting, actually. The third Duke, I think it was, had
		these beds planted out, very much the thing then, of course.
		
	Hugh falls over in the background.
		
		And apparently the soil that existed in the beds was completely
		wrong, so what do you think he did? They thought big in those
		days, of course. Well, he had over four hundredweight of the
		right soil transported from all the way over there.
		
	Points to a place about three yards away.
		
		Got assorted locals to help ... whole village turned out ...
		stood them all cider and badger cakes afterwards, that sort of
		thing. But I tell you ... that sort of vision, you know? If I
		tried to do that sort of thing now they'd say I was crackers,
		have me locked up and sewing potatoes soon as look at me, I
		expect.
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Cut to Hugh in another part of the garden. There is a gardener.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(to interviewer) The summer can be pretty ghastly. Open days
		and lots of coaches filing in and gawping and peering and so on
		with their muddy tyres everywhere. (To gardener.) I don't like
		the look of those aphids at all, Godfrey.
"}, {'speaker': 'Gardener', 'text': '
	I could spray them tomorrow, your Grace.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(tartly) No, thank you. I shan't want them sprayed tomorrow, I
		don't think. I've never been much of a one for having things
		sprayed tomorrow. (Back to interviewer.) Actually people can be
		rather fun. I remember one enormous lady in pink who was
		staring at this rather ugly and impossible lacquered cabinet in
		the Chinese room and she turned to her husband, who was a very
		funny little man in tight trousers, you know the sort of thing,
		and she said, "'Ere, Bert ... we could do with one of them in
		our front lounge parlour." Rather priceless. Great fun.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	The gardener has been considering.'}, {'speaker': 'Gardener', 'text': '
	I could spray them this afternoon.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I don't think so. I rather hate things being sprayed in the
		afternoon. (Walking away.) No. Not that, thank you.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen is in his study.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	A certain amount of pressure is brought to bear, obviously, in
		the matter of children. Got to provide an heir to take over
		this when I'm dead and gone and buried and no longer alive.
		Mary does most of the work there. It's something of a tradition
		in our family that the wife actually carries the child in her
		stomach before it's born. I let her look after all that side of
		things. Absolutely wonderful at it too. Can't stand most of the
		children, great ugly things, take up a huge amount of room and
		the devil to keep them heated and free of damp. But you know,
		that's all part of the job.
		"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Cut to wonderful dining-room. Hugh is sitting reading the '}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Sound of Hugh and Stephen discussing the day.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And we absolutely must decide on the May Day Claimings.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh and Stephen begin to discuss names of villagers. They talk about 
	Martha, young Lucy, Tabetha and so on.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(over) One rather charming local custom around here in the
		local neighbourhood that surrounds the immediate environs of
		the nearby area locally is the May Day Claimings, so called.
		Mary and I feel a great responsibility to keep up with those
		things. Otherwise one can lose touch.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(over) When I married Charles he warned me that what he calls
		his "job" does entail a lot of public responsibility and duty
		and I'm very keen to share that where possible.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	The point of the Claimings is that I have to choose a young
		girl to lead the May Day procession in the village. She must
		be no older than sixteen and no younger than fourteen. She is
		queen of the May for the day and I have to crown her and, after
		the maypole dancing and all that sort of palaver, I take her to
		the dungeons in the old part of the castle and privately
		violate her.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	We always have great fun choosing the girls. It's one of those
		very silly English customs whose point is lost in the mists of
		which there are plenty around here. But it would be such a pity
		to lost the connection with history.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It derives, I think, from some time in the seventies when my
		father thought that violating a village maiden would be rather
		a good idea. I think that's the origin, though some people
		claim it goes back as far as 1968. Great fun, though. I always
		throw myself completely into the spirit of the thing and enjoy
		it thoroughly.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I found this absolutely hilarious misprint in last week's
		edition of the Peterborough Echo. It says ... listen to this:
		"The Prime Minister, Mr John Major is a dignified and
		impressive leader." Isn't that priceless?
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Clive and Imelda are sitting in a waiting-room. Clive is reading a '}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	See that cartoon?
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	What does it mean?
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Imelda looks at it for a while.'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Beats me.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	The door opens and Hugh pops his head out.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Mr and Mrs Dont?
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': "
	That's right.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Do come in.
		
	They all move through into Hugh's surgery.
		
		Now then. In vitro fertilisation was your thing, I believe.
"}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': "
	That's right.
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	We found your name pasted up in a phone box on the Finchley
		Road, and we thought, well, why not?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Why not indeed? Free country. You've tried getting pregnant in
		the normal way, I assume?
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Well ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': "
	Oh yes. We both eat bananas first thing in the morning, and
		we've drunk out of the same tea-cup more than once, I can tell
		you.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Really?
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Did it in the back of a car, once.
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	(embarrassed) Phil ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': "
	Well ... he's a doctor, isn't he?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right. Good. OK, so what would you like?
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	Well, ideally, we'd like a baby.
"}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Ideally ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	A baby what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': "
	I'm sorry?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Dog, cat, parrot, giraffe, what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Well ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Human, we thought ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Human, yes, fine, if you like. I've got some brochures here.
		Basically we can do anything you want. We can take foetuses
		from surrogate mothers, we can take them from dead mothers, we
		can take dead foetuses, we can take sperm from just about
		anywhere, it's up to you. You know. Black babies, white babies,
		short babies, tall babies. Musical babies, athletic babies,
		menthol-flavoured babies, you name it ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	Well I think we'd like just ... a baby, really.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Bog standard baby.
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Please.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right. No distinguishing characteristics at all?
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Well, we would like it to be born in the sign of Gemini.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yeah?
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Yes, that way we reckon he or she is less likely to grow up
		believing in astrology.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Fair enough. And you're sure you want a human baby, are you?
		Only it's a bit of a growth sector, animals.
"}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Really?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Definitely. Mrs Willis will be having a kangaroo in a couple of
		months.
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Good heavens.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Seems strange to us, but believe me, to our children it will be
		the most natural thing in the world. Well, everything seems
		natural to my children, because they're actually otters. And
		otters, as you know, take things pretty much in their stride.
		But you understand my point.
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	We didn't realise there was such a range available.
"}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': "
	It's amazing.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Animals make wonderful children, as a matter of fact. What sort
		of house do you live in? Large? Small?
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Large-ish ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	A bungalow?
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, I wouldn't advise your giving birth to badgers then.
		Badgers hate stairs. How wet is this house of yours?
"}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Wet?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Wet. How wet?
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Well ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': "
	Averagely wet, I'd say.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You'd say averagely wet. Averagely wet. I'd probably decide
		against sea-lions. Wonderful offspring, but they do like a more
		than averagely wet house. Your best bet is mammal, furry and
		reasonably friendly. I have a wonderful strain of weasel at the
		moment.
"}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Weasel.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Weasel. Shiny whiskers, only two weeks in the womb and they
		wash themselves ... more than you can say for human children,
		eh?
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Suppose ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Mm?
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Suppose we had a human child and a weasel child.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, it's up to you, but to be honest with you, Mr Dont, human
		children take a long time to gestate in the womb and cause the
		mother a lot of pain, unlike a weasel which pops out quick as
		anything.
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Hence "pop goes the weasel".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right. No, the easiest thing if you want a human child, is to
		buy one, ready-born, from a pet shop.
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	I'll do it then. I'll give birth to a weasel and we'll buy a
		human child to keep it company.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Fine. Any other questions?
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Just one.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Fire away.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Clive holds up the New Yorker.'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Can you explain that cartoon?
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh looks at it for a while, puzzled.'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Road-widening scheme, I said. Road-widening scheme? Country-
		narrowing scheme more like. Yeah. Think about it. Country-
		narrowing scheme. Hm? Hmm?
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Stephen addresses the camera.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Ladies and gentlemen, if you've been wearing your listening
		trousers at all over the last few time frames, it's not
		impossible that you will have heard the phrase Virtual Reality.
		You may have thought to yourself I virtually don't understand what that is, and even if I did, I virtually couldn't give a
		dalmatian's nephew. That's a shame. Because Virtual Reality
		represents a colossal leap forward in the field of computer
		generated images. But we here on A Bit of Fry & Laurie,
		anxious as ever to bring you only the very ripest, tenderest
		young happening grooves, have looked ahead to the even more
		exciting field ...
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh shouts, off camera.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And it is a field ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	... and as m'colleague has so loudly pointed out, it is a
		field - the field of Real Reality. Hugh, what is it?
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh is wearing a brightly coloured tie. He sports it for the camera.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It's very exciting, that's what it is. This little beauty I'm
		wearing is a Real Reality tie.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen shouts across.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Cripes. What does that do?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	What this does is enable me to stand here and experience
		everything around me exactly, but exactly, as if it was real. I
		can see people and lights and cameras, and m'colleague Stephen,
		all utterly indistinguishable from the real thing. I actually
		tried it out at home yesterday morning, and drank a cup of tea
		wearing this tie, and ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Did it taste just like a cup of tea?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Stephen, I swear I couldn't have told the difference. Then I
		went to Morocco, and crossed the Atlas mountains without ropes
		of any kind, and it really was pretty scary. It had me fooled,
		anyway.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Have you had sex while wearing it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Very briefly, yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Identical, then?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No difference at all. I suppose the only criticism I have is
		that when you're wearing the tie, you're vaguely concious of
		wearing a tie. Apart from that, it's as good as perfect.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	But what about the cost, Hugh? Surely that must be a worry?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	'Fraid so. This tie will set you back 475,000. But the
		manufacturers are hoping to produce a budget version sometime
		next year.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Mmm. Can't wait. What are you going to do now, Hugh?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm going to wear this tie in the next sketch.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I am on the point of orgasm.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(as woman) The local pizza delivery boy came round and I took
		one look and I said, never mind the super supreme, I'll take
		you, just as you are ... thin and crispy. That's how we met.
		You could have knocked me down with a court order when I
		discovered he was my son.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen is a barman. Hugh is leaning against the bar. He drains a
	glass.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'll have another one please, barman.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Are you sure?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(aggressively) What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No offence, but this'll be your seventh.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Just keep 'em coming.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	OK, OK - your funeral.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen takes out a glass, fills it with Ribena and adds water.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Bitch.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Come again?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	My wife.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ah, right.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	She doesn't understand me. She's never understood me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What, Polish or something is she?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Have you ever been trapped in a loveless marriage with a woman
		you despised?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hoo, not since I was nine. Do you like it straight up, sir?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Huh?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Or with ice?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ice.
		
	Stephen pushes drink to Hugh.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Cocktail onion?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No thanks. She takes no interest in my friends, she laughs at
		my ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Peanuts?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	... hobbies. No thanks. She doesn't even value my ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Crinkle-cut Cheesy Wotsit?
		
	Stephen pushes a bowl of crinkle-cut Cheesy Wotsits towards Hugh, who 
	takes one and chews it absent-mindedly.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	... career. Thanks. You know, I mean it's just so depressing.
		Alright so other men have got larger ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Plums?
		
	Hugh waves away a bowl of plums. Stephen comes round to Hugh's side to 
	do some wiping down and arranging of the bar-stools.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	... salaries and other men have got better cars and better
		prospects and more can boast a healthier ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Stool?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	... lifestyle ... ta ...
		
	Hugh sits, Stephen goes round.
		
		... alright, so I don't have that much cash lying around. But
		why complain? Others are worse off. I've got a job. I've got
		two sweet rosy ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Nibbles?
		
	A bowl of crisps is handed forward.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	... children. But she's always going on and on at me about my
		appearance. It's not as if she's an oil painting. I mean
		frankly she's ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(pointing at the crisps) Plain and prawn flavoured.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	... not as young as she used to be herself. I don't know why I
		bother with women. I'd be better off being a ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Fruit?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	... monk or a hermit or something. At least if I was a ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Fag?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	... monk I wouldn't have to put up with women who can talk the
		back legs off a ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Camel?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Donkey. Of course the trouble is I couldn't live without women.
		In a monastery the best you can hope for is a bit of ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Chocolate hob nob?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	... bit of spirituality and peace. And let's face it, we
		haven't slept together for years. I'm lucky if I get a bit
		of ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Savoury finger?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	... a cuddle at Christmas. And naturally she won't let me give
		her so much as a ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(looking over his shoulder) Good juicy tongue in the back
		passage.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	... peck on the cheek. The trouble with that woman is, she's
		just a ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Rather disgusting-looking tart that should have been disposed
		of ages ago?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	... complainer.
		
	Bangs his empty glass down.
		
		... One more for the road I think, barman.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Anything to go with it?
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Long pause.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	A bag of oral sex, if you've got one.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen and Hugh are in a sort of limbo area, wearing stupid wigs.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Hello. On the show tonight, I'm joined by a complex network of
		muscle tissue and tendons, controlled by my central nervous
		system. But I'm lucky enough to have as a guest Mr Philip
		Follip, who I believe has a remarkable invention. Hello,
		Philip.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hello, Riversdale.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Alan.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh. I'm sorry.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I know it's spelt Riversdale, but it's actually pronounced
		"Alan".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Alan it is then.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Tell us about your invention, Philip, taking care not to be
		dull for a single moment.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, basically, I looked at the karaoke machine, that's been
		such a popular hit over the last few years, and thought to
		myself how could I improve on it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Conclusions, Philip? You must have reached some, surely?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, I thought the trouble with the karaoke machine is that it
		only allows you to sing along with it.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Right, and you thought "Hello, there's a window of opportunity,
		let's heave a brick through it." Am I warm?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Warm enough.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That's all I ask.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	So I thought, what about a machine that would not only allow
		you to sing along with it, but would allow you to play along
		with it as well?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'm beginning to see how your mind works.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And I came up with this.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Holds up a little black box with a button on it.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I don't know if our cameras can see that ... If they can't, I
		suggest we take them back to the shop and get a fucking refund.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	If I just press this button here, then what happens is this ...
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	He presses the button and there is silence.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Complete silence.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Which now allows me and my orchestra to play and sing along.
		One, two, three, four ...
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Cut wide to see full band: Hugh sings.'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Course, it's well known that Shakespeare didn't really exist.
		And that if he did, he was lots of people. And they were all
		women, and that all his plays were written by Alan Bleasdale.
		And that Shakespeare shot Kennedy, and that Lee Harvey Oswald
		was nothing but a pansy. They don't put that on Newsnight,
		though, do they?
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh strums a piano.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I wear sophisticated clothes,
		I say sophisticated things,
		Everything about me,
		Say's I'm a sophistication king,
		But when I'm with you,
		I can't seem to find my cool,
		Yeah when I'm with you,
		I just sit there and drool,
		
		I got sophisticated hands,
		I got sophisticated feet,
		A sophisticated car,
		Parked on sophistication street,
		But when I'm with you,
		I can't seem to find my cool,
		Yeah when I'm with you,
		I'm just a dribblin' fool,
		
		And when you look at me,
		And you start to flirt,
		I have to wipe the dribble,
		Off the front of my shirt,
		And when you ask me,
		What's on my mind,
		All I can think to answer is ...
		blubblybubbylyfawaah,
		
		I eat sophisticated food,
		I breathe sophisticated air,
		Use a sophisticated comb
		On my sophisticated hair,
		But when I'm with you,
		I can't seem to find my cool,
		Yes when I'm with you,
		I just fall off my ...
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Amazingly enough, Hugh falls off his stool.'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen addresses the camera while making, tossing and dressing a 
	salad. For some reason he is very angry, as if always suspecting that 
	everyone is laughing at him.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I was at the theatre two nights ago. The National ... OUR
		National theat ... our Royal National Theatre. I saw a play,
		yes alright it was only a play. Oh brilliant, so now I'm to be
		judged and whipped and mocked and scorned because it was only a
		play. Great. Thanks very much indeed. Alright, yes it was only
		a sod-buggering play. No, MacEnroe wasn't in it, nor Lendl or
		Noah or any of the big stars. So it wasn't stuffed with top
		names. Christ, what do you want from me? Hm? Hm? Hm? My God, I
		go, I at least bloody bother to get off my fat, wobbling,
		lardy, smelly, huge, festering carpet and actually go to the
		theatre and suddenly I'm Adolf Eichmann. Well I'm bloody sorry
		but ... WHY WON'T THIS FRIGGING TOMATO SETTLE BLOODY DOWN!!!
		(He is having trouble slicing a tomato.) God! What is the
		earthly use of trying, just for once in your life, to make an
		honest salad, just trying, without help, without any other
		motive than love and an honest desire without the CRUDDING
		ARSING thing falling apart in your bloody hands. God! Anyway, I
		saw a play there, by Shakespeare as it happens. And I started
		thinking. Thinking about Shakespeare ...
		   O damn and BLAST this cucumber ... why does it have to be
		like this ...
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I walked into a shop the other day. Bloody hurt, I can tell
		you.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "A Jermyn Street tobacconist's. Stephen is behind the counter, Hugh isn't."}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Good morning.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I beg your pardon?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I said good morning.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh sir. You've not heard?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Heard what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh sir.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sir, I think I am a generous man, and I will happily bear many
		things. Burdens, architectural down-loads, even perhaps on fine
		summer days, your children. But bad tidings, sir ... bad
		tidings are too much for an inelastic old fool, such as you are
		currently experiencing, even to bear.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Bad tidings?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Suffice to say he's expected to make a full recovery.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Who is?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Call Nick Ross.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Call Nick Ross is doing as well as can be expected.
		Meanwhiletime, a nation can only hold its breath in silent
		prayer and reflect in its quieter moments that flu can be a
		horrible and a very beastly thing.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Nick Ross has got flu?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Call Nick Ross is, according to sources close to Call Nick
		Ross, ill with the flu, sir, yes. How callous and casually
		violent your airy description of the goodness of the morning
		now sounds in your ears.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Right. I'd like to buy a box of cigars, please.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Cigars, of course. For smoking?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well, yes. Well, yes. Did two finer words in our language ever
		join hands and creep nervously down the aisle of utterance than
		"well, yes"? If they did, it was without the help of a
		reputable catering firm, of that I am absolutely tall.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What else would I use cigars for?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sir, the thought flitted across my knees that you might be
		thinking of using cigars as a means of personal transport
		around the crowded streets of our city. They are small,
		manoeuvrable, easy to park, and use almost no petrol.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	But they don't move.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sir is quick and alive to the single disadvantage of cigars in
		this respect. They do not, as Winston Churchill himself would
		not have been ashamed to say, move.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, no, I want to smoke them.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sir wants to smoke cigars. He wants to take them out of the
		box, singly or in threes, put them in his mouth lengthways and
		apply a flame to the furthest end. Do I misjudge my man so
		terribly? I think not.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No, that's right.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Does sir imagine that he will be in a dressed state of affairs
		when the mood of ensmokement descends?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I beg your pardon?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Will sir be sheathed in habiliments, I am in the rapidly-
		expanding business of wondering, or will he be allowing the
		breath of God to caress his flinty flanks unhindered by layers
		of silk and, oblique stroke or, corduroy?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I will be dressed, yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sir will be dressed. Will he, in this consummately dressed
		state, be in the company of four young walls and ceiling, or
		will he be starkly alone?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Outside?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I believe that the young Francis Bacon coined the term
		"outside" to describe just such a state of exteriority as I
		have been fumbling to express.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I doubt I'll be smoking outside.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Let me reach down into my word bag once again and feel for
		fitting shapes and textures to pull out and surprise you with.
		Ah, my word-fingers close around "dressed" and they sense the
		smooth outlines of "inside". Sir will be experiencing the fumal
		joys of his cigaroid pleasure-cocks while "dressed" and while
		"inside". I HARDLY THINK I CAN PUT IT MORE PLAINLY THAN THAT.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Forgive me for asking, but what on earth has it got to do with
		anything whether or not I'm inside or outside, nude or clothed?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	NUDE! "Nude!" he said, smiting his brow with the back of his
		mind. Nude was the very word I could have used earlier. It
		would have saved us an hundred syllables of pointless and
		unutterably tedious exchange earlier on. Why did I not simply
		say, "Will sir be nude?" My aunt and my cousin (a cinema
		projectionist in Hove, as was) will never forgive me.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You haven't answered my question.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I am now busy until the end of the month wondering if sir will
		allow me to answer his simple, manly question with one of my
		own?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh, very well.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You are kindness herself.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sir?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What is your question?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Stand back to admire it, sir, because though I say so without
		an interpreter, it's the best question asked since man first
		arose from out the primordial cup-a-soup and asked "What is the
		word for that tiny sleeve of plastic at the end of a shoe-
		lace?" My question is this and it comes without sponsorship of
		any kind: "What are you doing here?"
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, I think I'm trying to buy some cigars.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Some? Some cigars? Oh sir, that is the most vest-dampening
		attitude I have heard since Peter Lilley was in here, trying to
		buy my ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Trying to buy your?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	My silence, sir. You tell me you are trying to buy "some
		cigars". This is not a shop that sells "some cigars", this is a
		shop that sells only the very finest cigars that sexual favours
		can buy. Cigars that think, that feel: cigars that adjust
		themselves to your mood and your state of arousal.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Are you saying that you sell different cigars for indoor and
		outdoor use and different cigars for being clothed or
		unclothed?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No sir. I am emphatically not saying that. But I could. By God,
		with a fair following wind, a sip of Aqua Libra, a week's
		rehearsal and a nod from you, I could say exactly that.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I like a nice bit of fresh sleep. Not like that tinned stuff.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen is a genial afternoon game show host. He is flanked by Hugh 
	and Clive.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Hello, and welcome to Don't be Dirty, the show that shows you
		don't have to be dirty. With us is Tony, three times semi-
		finalist, and Clive, keen to be clean, who got through
		unexpectedly when last week's winner, Mr Nottingham, died in a
		canoe. Tony, you to start. Will you please describe for us the
		act of fellatio, Tony - the act of fellatio - without, Tony,
		without, and I'm sure you must know the rules by now, without
		being dirty. Your time starts five seconds ago.
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '"Fellatio" flashes up on the screen.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	This is an act, an act that takes place between two people,
		possibly of opposite sexes, but possibly not ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oooh, careful, Tony ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	... whereby one of the participants takes a part of the other
		participant's person into the place where they might more
		commonly keep bubble gum, say, and proceeds to masticate ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oooh, Tony, I thought you'd gone there. You're playing with
		fire, man ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	... until the other participant arrives at a state of
		pleasurable relaxation. The second participant then gives the
		first participant ten quid and goes back home.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'A gong sounds.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Unbelievable. Can no one beat the big man from Hunstanton?
		Clive, it's up to you. Your topic is the preservation of hard
		woods, and your time starts ... then.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '"The Preservation of Hard Woods" flashes up.'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Well, this is a very necessary business ...
		
	A buzzer sounds.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Tony's challenged.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Business.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Business, yes, you did say it, Clive. Little bit dirty, there,
		one point away, but plenty of time to go.
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	... operation that has to be carried out if developers are not
		to rase your hard woods to the grounds and ...
		
	Hugh buzzes again.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Another challenge from our reigning champion. The nature of
		your challenge, Tony, please.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	He said "rase".
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	He did say "rase", Tony.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Rase is an anagram of arse.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Clive is furious with himself.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Rase is an anagram of arse, it is, it is, it is. So sorry
		Clive, but we do have to lose you. You were Keen to be Clean,
		but you came up against a man very much on the top of his form.
		We say goodbye.
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Oh, piss.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Now, Tony, you've been in this position before. You keep the
		Don't be Dirty Sweatshop and Neck, you keep the 800 pounds in
		weight. They're yours to keep. No one can take them away from
		you, AS OF RIGHT, they are yours and yours alone. If anyone
		touches them or tries to appropriate them you would be
		justified in taking extreme and violent measures of self-
		protection. But, I'm offering you 600 more pounds or a chance
		to go into another Don't be Dirty Daily Double with a chance to
		win ten pounds.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'll go for the daily double.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I knew you'd say that, Tony. You're a sport, quite a sport. But
		do remember you KEEP the prizes you've already won. They're
		yours. No one else's. Yours. You're clear on that?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm clear, Bradley.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Alright. So long as that's clear. They're yours to keep. Yours.
		Now. Can we have our Don't be Dirty Daily Double categories on
		the board, please? Your three categories are (as they come up 
		on the big board) "rimming", "genital torture" and "David
		Vine".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ooh.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Remember it is a Daily Double, so twosubjects. I must hurry
		you as you take your time. Just take your time, very quickly.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hard. It's very hard. I think "genital torture" and "David
		Vine" please.
		
	Lights go down. Stephen suddenly gets very quiet and serious.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Tony. You have thirty earth seconds in which to talk about
		genital torture and David Vine without being dirty and your
		thirty seconds start ...
		
	Stephen looks at his wristwatch.
		
		... damn - missed that one - coming up. Coming up. Your thirty
		seconds start - now! 
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	A certain class of person exists who derives some kind of
		undefined pleasure in inflicting quite excruciating pain upon
		the parts of their bodies which are designed to be hidden
		inside pants and vest. To this end nipple-clamps and scrotal
		compressors are deployed, as well as a variety of serrated
		needles which can be inserted down the channels and pipe-work
		which constitute the organs of generation. Presenting various
		sporting events, most especially the world snooker finals from
		the Crucible Theatre, Sheffield, David Vine combines relaxed
		and informative presentational skills with a clear expertise on
		the game. He ...
		Claxon sounds.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh Tony. Tony. Tony. Tony. "On the game"! You said "on the
		game". You were dirty, Tony, and that's a pity.
		
	Hugh hits his head.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I was dirty. I was dirty. Shite-arsed damn.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Only four seconds left and you were dirty. Well, David Vine was
		obviously going to be a category which could trip up even a
		seasoned Don't be Dirty finalist like yourself. I'm afraid you
		lose the prizes you've won this week, and everything from the
		weeks before. You repay to us your travel expenses and you go
		away empty-headed. You knew the risks.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I did. I did.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	But Tony, tell me. Did you enjoy yourself? Has it been a
		pleasure?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It's been a huge one, a really big one. I've pleasured myself a
		great deal.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'm glad to hear it. Until next week, ladies and gentlemen. And
		remember.
"}, {'speaker': 'Both', 'text': "
	Don't be dirty!
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "
	Imelda is washing up at a kitchen sink. Stephen comes in. It's a little
	bit EastEnders and a little bit The Archers and little bit other things
	too."}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Julie ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	Hello, Frank. Kettle's on.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Thanks, love. Julie, there's something I wanted to tell you ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	Can't it wait? Only I've got to pick Rebecca up at four.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well no, it can't really ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Make it quick.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'm trying ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	Only I've got to pick Rebecca up at four.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well it's not easy. Thing is ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	Blimey, it's nearly four now. I've got to pick Rebecca up in a
		minute.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hold on. This is important ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Important?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yeah, you see ...
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	The door opens and Clive comes in.'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Bill ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Sorry, am I ...?
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	No, it's alright. Frank was just going to tell me something
		important, but I've got to pick Rebecca up at four, so ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': "
	I'll pick Rebecca up, if you like.
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Are you sure?
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Yeah, no problem. What time?
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Four ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': "
	Blimey, it's nearly four now ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	I know ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': "
	I'll go and pick her up, then.
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	Kettle's on ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': "
	No, it's alright. Better get a move on if I'm going to make it
		by four ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Thanks.
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	See ya.
		
	Clive goes out.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	Now then. What's so important?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Well ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	Kettle's on, by the way ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No thanks.
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	Sure? Won't take a minute.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No, really ... Julie, you and I ...
		
	Clive comes back in.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Sorry ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	What's wrong? Is Rebecca alright?
"}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Fine, fine ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	Tell me what's happened ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': "
	Nothing's happened. It's just ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Where am I picking her up from?
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Rebecca?
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': '
	Yeah ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	Tony's.
"}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': "
	Tony's, right. What time?
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Well I said four ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Clive', 'text': "
	Blimey, I'd better get a move on ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Thanks.
		
	Clive goes out again.
		
		Now then. What about that tea?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No thanks.
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	Sure? Kettle's on ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No. Look, Julie ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Two seconds. Warm the pot, couple of tea bags ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Julie ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Thanks, I'd love a cup.
		
	Imelda pours some tea.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	So this big important thing that can't wait ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yeah, well. I don't know how to put this ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Just say it.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It's not easy. The thing is ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Sugar?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Two, please. Julie, you and I have known each other a long 
		time, yeah?
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Yeah.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I s'pose, what I'm trying to say is ...
		
	The door opens and Hugh enters.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Have either of you seen Bill?
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Bill?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yeah. He was supposed to be giving me a lift ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	He's gone to fetch Rebecca ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What time?
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Five.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Five?
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	No, wait a minute, four.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Four?
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': '
	Four.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Sure?
'}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	Sure. He'll be back in a minute.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh, I'll hang on then. You haven't got the kettle on, have you?
"}, {'speaker': 'Imelda', 'text': "
	No, kettle's off.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Damnedest thing. I was in this hardware shop the other day,
		buying a thirty gallon drum of car wax for my daughter-in-law,
		when the door bursts open, thirty coppers come lumbering in,
		and arrest everyone. Place turned out to be a brothel. Quite
		unbelievable. I mean it said Brothel outside it, but I just
		thought that was a joke.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen in sheepskin coat, standing on the edge of a football pitch,
	addresses the camera.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You're a parent. You have children. You want those children to
		become Premier League footballers. Well, this is the place for
		you. The Dave Wilson School in Ipswich, in the heart of
		London's East End.
		
	A line of ten-year-old boys are doing physical jerks. A track-suited 
	Hugh gives instructions as Stephen's voice continues.
		
		The name of Dave Wilson will be familiar to anyone who knows
		him. And also to those who followed the fortunes of Reading
		Town reserves during the dark days of the seventies.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Close-up on Hugh.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	They were very dark days, yes. Very dark. Hmm. I hadn't thought
		of them as dark, but now you mention it ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Dave played a total of two games for the side before a
		cartilege snapped in his head. Dave. What was it like, to be
		thrown out on the scrap-heap at such a young age? Did you feel
		bitter?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ooh no. Worse if anything.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No, bitter.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh. Yeah. Bitter. Bitter ... and dark ... days.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Cut to Hugh leading some stretching exercises. Stephen in voice-over.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Following the injury, Dave tried his hand at many things.
		Nightclub owner, astrologer, interior designer, Shadow Home
		Secretary, the jobs came and went, but nothing seemed to stick.
		Until Dave turned up one day to watch his nephew playing in the
		school side.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I wanted to get involved. That's it, really. You know, football
		has been good to me, and I suppose I saw the chance to put
		something back into the game.
		
	Cut to boys listening as Hugh lectures them.
		
		Football is a very simple game. What is it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Boys', 'text': '
	A very simple game.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What is the object of the game of football?
'}, {'speaker': 'Boys', 'text': '
	Run into the box and fall over.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Run into the box and fall over. Right. Ricky, off you go.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	The boys form a line and one by one they run to the penalty area and 
	dive spectacularly to the ground, clutching their shins. Cut to 
	interview.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm trying to teach fundamental footballing skills at the
		earliest possible age. I've started teaching my eight-month-old
		son to fall over, and I've got to say, the lad's a natural.
		Falls over like a diamond.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You think he might follow in his father's footsteps?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes. For a while. But then, with a bit of luck, he'll fall
		over.
		
	Hugh demonstrates technique.
		
		Got to get your head back. As you go. Keep the neck loose, as
		you approach the box, then ...
		
	Hugh throws himself down.
		
		Got it? Right. Limping. Two lengths of the pitch. Go.
		
	The boys set off in massively exaggerated limps. Hugh approaches 
	Stephen.
		
		See that lad there?
		
	Close-up on a boy, limping spectacularly.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Kid's got a future. No doubt about it. We've had a couple of
		London clubs down to look at him already. Falls like a dream,
		and he can limp as well with either foot.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Shouting at the referee?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Let's have a look. Daniel?
		
	The boy turns.
		
		I'm the ref.
"}, {'speaker': 'Boy', 'text': "
	Oh, but I've already ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You want to make it to the top or don't you?
		
	Daniel shambles over and starts yelling at Hugh, nose to nose. Hugh 
	turns to Stephen.
		
		He's something, isn't he?
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Another boy approaches Stephen and Hugh carrying a football.'}, {'speaker': 'Boy', 'text': '
	Mr Wilson?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Martin.
'}, {'speaker': 'Boy', 'text': '
	Found this in the changing-room.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh yeah?
'}, {'speaker': 'Boy', 'text': '
	What is it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Never you mind about that.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh takes the ball and shouts to all the boys.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Right, listen! Martin found this in the changing-room. Now I'm
		going to say this once. I don't want any of you wasting your
		time with these things. Any of you see one of these, you tell
		me or Mr Collins immediately. You want to make it to the
		League, then you think about training. No one ever got to the
		top of the game mucking around with these things, alright?
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh makes to punt the ball away, but misses.
	   Cut to Stephen standing in front of a sign reading "The Dave Wilson 
	Falling Over School".'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hope for the future, then.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I grew up in what would now be considered a rather stern
		family, I suppose. My father wouldn't have a television in the
		house, so we used to gather round every night and watch it on
		the lawn.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh and Caroline are at a table, having tea with their son Terry, ten years old.'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	Something wrong, dear?
'}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': '
	Nah.
'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': "
	You're not eating your tea.
"}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': '
	Not hungry.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Watch it.
'}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Not hungry. Jesus.
'}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': "
	Can't I have an apple?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No you can't.
"}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': '
	But ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	But? But? No buts in this house, my lad. In this house, we
		leave our buts outside, where they belong. Alright?
'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': "
	Eat some of your Pepsi-flavoured chocolate crisps, dear, and
		then we'll see about some apples ...
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'The door bell goes. Caroline gets up and goes out.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Not hungry.
'}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': "
	Well I'm not ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'll decide whether you're hungry or not, thank you very much
		for cleaning my car.
		The door opens and Caroline comes in with Patrick.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	Mr Furkiss, father.
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	Hello.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I see, I see. Can he state his business, this Mr Furkiss, or is
		he going to stand there all night like an over-filled bin-
		liner?
'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	Father ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I speak as I find, Mr Furkiss. You'll realise that, as you get
		to know me. Now then. What's on your mind you wide-arsed git?
"}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	At least let the man sit down, father.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Mr Furkiss can do his talking standing up, mother. We had to,
		at his age.
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	Well now, I'm glad that Terry's here for this ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well where else would he be, eh? Tea-time on a Wednesday. Ram-
		raiding old ladies in the High Street, is that what you think?
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	Not at all ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I should think not at all ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': "
	Mr Furkiss is from the school, father. He teaches Terry's form.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'A pause and then Hugh jumps to his feet.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Mr Furkiss, for goodness' sake sit down. Will you take some tea
		with us? Mother, freshen this tea-pot up with fresh tea, will
		you? Mr Furkiss teaches at Terry's school ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	No tea, thank you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Pepsi-flavoured chocolate crisp?
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	Well perhaps a little one ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Mother, fetch up the littlest crisp you can find, and some of
		our smallest cutlery to go with it.
		
	Caroline busies herself.
		
		Now then, Mr Furkiss, will you take a pipe of rough shag with
		me over here by the radiator?
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	Thank you, no. I really came to discuss Terry's progress at
		school.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	He's not been making progress, has he? The little bugger. That
		lad'll feel the rough end of my watch strap before the day is
		over, Mr Furkiss, you have my word on it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	Well no, actually, he's not been making any progress. That's
		why I'm here.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hello? Mother, this sounds like bad news ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': "
	Just tell us, Mr Furkiss. Terry's no angel, we realise that. If
		he's done wrong, we'd like to know about it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	The truth is, Terry has been falling further and further behind
		with his golf.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Golf?
'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	Golf?
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	As you know, he's got exams coming up at the end of this year,
		and I fear that Terry is going to fail his golf unless he bucks
		his ideas up pretty smartly.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I don't believe it ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	I'm afraid it's true.
"}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	But golf was always his strongest subject. He came top in golf
		last year ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	Exactly. That's why I wanted to come here, have a little chat,
		see if I couldn't find out what's been happening.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I don't understand it. We thought ...
		Patrick produces some cards.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	These are the scores from his last three rounds, Mr Furkiss. As
		you can see, he shot an eighty-four last Wednesday, and a
		ninety this morning.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh examines the cards.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Bloody Nora. An eight on the fourteenth? Eight? That's
		pathetic.
"}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	It is disappointing, I agree.
'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	The fourteenth is the one ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	It's the dog-leg par four. Couple of sand traps, but well out
		of harm's way.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Two hundred and twelve yards from the medal tee. It's a piece
		of cake.
"}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	The rest of the form managed a six or better, and so you can
		imagine why I was concerned ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Terry, you little bugger ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': "
	Don't shout at him, father ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I shout as I find, as you well know, mother.
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	Terry? What's happening? Is there something bothering you?
"}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	Are you sure? Nothing you'd like to tell me about?
"}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Answer Mr Furkiss, Terry. He's come a long way on a dark
		afternoon for your benefit ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': "
	There's nothing wrong.
"}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	Well then why, Terry? Why an eight on the fourteenth.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	He did it to spite us, can't you see? All the sacrifices we
		made, and he's throwing it back in our faces. He's an evil
		little bastard, that's what he is.
"}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': "
	I'm not. I just ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	You just what, Terry?
'}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': '
	Nothing.
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	You're slicing the ball much more than you used to. Why is
		that? Left hand too far over?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Cocks his wrists too early. I've always said it ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	Hush, father ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well he does, no getting round it ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': '
	I just ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': "
	I just don't see the point, that's all.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Don't see the point? Don't see the point of what?
"}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': '
	Of golf.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Don't see the ... that's nice, isn't it? Your mother and I have
		sweated and sweated and sweated for you. We've sweated so much
		it's disgusting. Tell him, mother. Tell him how much you've
		sweated. Show him the stains on your blouse.
"}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	(pointing) There.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You'd better start pulling your ideas up, my boy. What are you
		going to do with your life if you fail golf, hm? What kind of
		prospects do you think there are out there for people who cock
		their wrists too early?
"}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': "
	I came top in French, didn't I?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	French? French? I'll French you, young man.
"}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': "
	No you won't, Father.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	French, indeed.
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	The national curriculum is about the real world, Terry.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(examining reports) Bottom in golf. Bottom in Sonic Two. Bottom
		in Lemmings. Bottom in Disney studies. But when it comes to
		something cushy and of no practical use whatever ...
		mathematics, French, English ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	Oh Terry ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	So. A new regime for you, young man. It's the driving range and
		practice greens with every hour of daylight God sends. And in
		the evenings you will practice your Sonic Two and your Lemmings
		and you will study your Disney videos.
"}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': '
	But ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Uh ... what did I tell you about buts? We do not bring our buts
		into the tea-lounge.
'}, {'speaker': 'Terry', 'text': '
	Mum promised I could go to the library this evening.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, you should have thought of that before you started
		slicing the ball off the tee and shanking your approaches,
		shouldn't you? Now. Go inside and watch Bedknobs and 
		Broomsticks.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Hugh looks as Terry slouches off.'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': "
	Don't you worry, Mr Furkiss, we'll keep an eye on him.
"}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	Oh good. He's a nice lad, Terry, be nice to see him get on in
		life.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Now then. What about that rough shag?
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen is at home in his bathroom, bent over a sink, washing his hair.
	He hums and washes. He spots the camera.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Hello. If you're anything like me then you probably wash your
		hair quite often and probably use a shampoo. You're pretty
		tall, you're called Stephen and you haven't got much time for
		gardening. Well, I may have just the answer for you, Stephen.
		It came to me yesterday, when I was standing here bent over the
		wash hair basin. Here's a thing we do a couple of times a week
		(though if it's more than that I urge you to consider the
		benefits of a specially formulated frequency shampoo) and
		which utilises the very same key nutrients and minerals that
		any gardener will tell you are essential for healthy plants and
		gums. So, Stephen, I've come up with this new five-minute
		addition to my hair grooming and facial scrub programme. If
		you're anything like me you'll probably like to rinse after
		your second wash and you'll have a friend called Hugh who plays
		with an Etch-a-Sketch in your airing cupboard.
		
	Stephen opens the airing cupboard where Hugh is sitting and Etch-a- 
	Sketching.
		Hugh, come on out and help me explain my new break-through in
		hair.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right-o.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I was explaining to the viewing several that after the second
		wash I like to have a thorough rinse.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No harm in that, if it's done sensibly.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Exactly my point. And it's at this stage when my new
		development comes in. Here, in my freshly-watered, protein-
		enriched hair are the ideal conditions - neutral balance Ph,
		active liposomes and gentle cleansing agents - for a small, but
		attractive town-garden. Hugh.
		
	Hugh takes a packet of seeds and starts to plop them in Stephen's hair.
		
		What have you chosen, Hugh?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	A mix of begonias, dog-roses and clematis.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No vegetables?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I thought perhaps I could sow one or two potatoes just behind
		the crown here.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So a general utility garden.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Pretty much.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well. Now I have to blow-dry with my Pifco tress-matic on its
		lowest setting and let nature do its work.
		
	Time has passed. Stephen now has a towel over his head.
		
		Well, let's see how it's fared.
		
	Hugh removes towel to show spectacular garden. Flowers, patch of lawn,
	rockery ... the works.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I think that's come out rather well.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Simple, cheap, effective. Well done Hugh, my head gardener.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's amusing.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(to camera) Of course your own hair garden needn't be confined
		to this limited range of plants. The sky's very much the limit.
		Climbing wistarias, alpines, runner beans, you name it. And if
		you have dandruff problems you might consider a traditional
		Japanese snow garden.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	If you're anything like me, you'll be keen to experiment and
		you will enjoy wearing lycra one-pieces alone in your bedroom.
		
	Stephen goes and stands oddly, looking at a wall.
		
		What are you doing Stephen?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I'm south-facing.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(picking up Etch-a-Sketch) Ah, well it's back to the airing
		cupboard for me.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	See you next wash day.
'}, {'speaker': 'Both', 'text': '
	Ber-bye.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I think the Queen does a ruddy marvellous job. Ruddy
		marvellous. I opened Parliament myself a couple of times in the
		seventies, and believe you me, it's not as easy as it looks.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'In the street, Stephen addresses the camera.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It's red, it's shiny, it's instantly desirable and it's
		remarkably cheap. One drawback. It doesn't exist yet. We
		wondered why not. Douglas Hurd has been foreign secretary for a
		record five years. If anyone knows it'll be Gordon Wade of
		Market Soundings plc.
		
	Hugh is there as Gordon.
		
		Gordon. It's red, it's shiny - everyone wants one, it needn't
		cost a fortune and it isn't tested on animals. Yet it doesn't
		exist. What's going on?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I don't know. We're very sorry. It should exist, I know that.
		Believe me we're working on it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Have you thought of a name for it yet?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Not as of yet, no. The project has a working title ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I've just got time to ask you, what is it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The name at this moment is Mark Bannister.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Mark Bannister. Price?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	We're hoping it'll be round about three pounds fifty, but it
		may go as high as ninety thousand.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ninety thousand?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Rather depends on what it does, you see. And how much it costs
		to make it. But these are details ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Exactly. The basic message is, you're going ahead, and we might
		expect to see Mark Bannisters in our shops soon? Fair answer.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh enters a shop. There are pianos about the place. Stephen is ready.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Hello.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	It does seem to be, sir, yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Seem to be what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Rather hello.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Sorry?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I opened my television last night only to find that nice
		gentleman with the legs advancing the prediction that it might
		be rather "good evening" today, but looking out through the
		window that the previous owners thoughtfully installed for the
		purpose, I find that it has, as you athletically observed,
		turned out to be rather "hello".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Mmm. Nice weather.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	And a very nice weather to you too, sir. (Calling off.) We have
		a customer, Mr Dalliard! It's pleasantly spoken but with a loud
		taste in vests. I'm talking to it now. (To Hugh.) Sir. How can
		I make your life more attractively-styled?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well now, it is my god-daughter's birthday next week, and she's
		very keen to have a piano.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I understand, absolutely, sir. I have god-daughters of my own.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes, well ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You would like me to bundle her into a large trunk and
		transport her to the continent of Africa, where she might join
		the slave trade and become a lasting credit to you and your
		collection of hand-painted Chinese rugs?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well ... no.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	No in the sense of "Yes, and is it alright if I pay by cheque?"
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No, no in the sense of "no".
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hmm. I fear that being with you is one of the accomplishments I
		have yet to master in my short, but interestingly shaped life.
		(Calling off.) Things are turning frosty, Mr Dalliard.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'd like to buy a piano.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	For your god-daughter?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	For my god-daughter.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	With what end in view?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	So that she can learn to play it.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	With what end of the piano in view, you blithering customer.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Er ... both ends, I think ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A double-ended piano?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(calling) Mr Dalliard! A situation is developing! (To Hugh.)
		How old is this so-called god-daughter of yours?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Seventeen.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Mr Dalliard! Stop your ears, the talk is becoming loose.
		Seventeen and you want to buy her a piano.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	For your god-daughter?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Is there a problem?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I wouldn't go so far as Reading, sir. Although they tell me
		that it's in Berkshire at this time of year.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Look. I came in here ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	So far, sir, I am in complete agreement with you. You came in
		here. You bloody ... well ... came ... in ... here. You did. If
		you hadn't come in here, I would have noticed, and called the
		Church of England immediately. But you did come in here, and
		here you stand, proud, slightly lopsided, the finest full-page
		advertisement for the Anglo-Saxon race I've seen since
		yesterday's edition of Brookside.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I want to buy a piano.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	We all want to buy pianos, sir.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Do we?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Leaving aside the vast majority of human beings who don't want
		to buy pianos, yes sir.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	So?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Mr Dalliard! Start your ears again. This is getting exciting.
		(To Hugh.) Sir, you are, you have been, you were, you are, you
		did, you always will be, the master of that sixty-foot gaff-
		rigged schooner that plies the oceans of the world in the name
		of "Your Destiny", but might I recommend that you take at least
		one shagging moment to think about this?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	God-daughters are not horses, sir.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Neither are they commercial aircraft, nor streets of terraced
		housing in what used to be called Hull.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	They are not quantities of tepid water that collect in the
		bottom of up-turned tea-cups during the wash cycle, no more are
		they hard-boiled sparrows.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Your point being?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I have no point sir. I am, to all in tents and caravans,
		pointless.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right. One piano please.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Very well, sir. I have strained every groin I have to dissuade
		you from your chosen course of action. You will realise that I
		am too proud to beg, and too tall to sit comfortably in a Lotus
		Seven. If, as I surmise, sir has the bit between his teeth well
		and truly between his teeth, there is nothing more I can do
		without using Venn diagrams and multi-coloured flow charts.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	One ... piano ... please.
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Stephen reaches beneath the counter and produces a vibrator.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That'll be twenty-nine of your earth pounds and ninety-five
		pence please Bob.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's a vibrator.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sir?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	That is a vibrator.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I realise that, sir. I am not entirely French.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I don't want a vibrator.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You've changed your mind? (Calling.) Mr Dalliard! Unpack the
		suitcases at once. The young git has changed his mind ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No, I haven't changed my mind. I never wanted a vibrator, I
		wanted a piano.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Perhaps you are not a native of these shores, sir.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	What's that got to do with it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Or perhaps you merely thought, the grouse and the partridge
		being out of season, you could derive some sport from this
		humble shopkeeper, a man who palpably lives in Putney and grows
		other people's vegetables? Is that how your mind works?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Look ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	If that is what you thought, then I feel sorry for me. I may
		not be a duke or an ambassador's wife, but I know the price of
		a pound's worth of lard, and can recite the days of the week
		from memory.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I just want a piano. Not a vibrator. A piano. For my god-
		daughter. For her birthday. So that she can play it. That's all
		I want. Alright? Will you sell me one, or will I have to go
		elsewhere?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	This time, sir, the dice has fallen in my favour. The worm has
		turned and the little man has his chance. Elsewhere will be
		closed.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Closed?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Closed. So now, your scheme is blown, shattered, it lies in
		pieces at your feet in a grotesque, mocking parody of local
		news broadcasts. You are a spent force, Mr Customer,
		yesterday's man, a speck on the pages of our island history.
		You are like a shoe-lace, looking for a nest. You are, in
		short, long.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I don't know why, but I'm going to give you one last chance.
		Sell ... me ... a ... frigging ... piano.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(rapidly) Upright, grand, boudoir grand, baby grand, concert
		grand?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's more like it. Upright.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Cordless? With or without clitoral exciter?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(ominously) What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ivory-white, flesh-pink, fluted or unfluted?
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh grabs Stephen by the lapels.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Now, listen ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Mr Dalliard! Step out at once, never mind your hat, and take an
		intensive course in self-defence. Come back when you have
		attained your fourth dan and give Mr Customer a thorough
		spanking.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I don't want a vibrator. I'm not interested in vibrators. I
		want a piano. Do you understand?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I read you, Mr Sir. I read you like a heart-warming tale of
		human courage and star-crossed love serialised in weekly
		instalments by the author of "Danielle Steele's Emeralds".
