		Piano. One. God-daughter. Seventeen. For the use of.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh lets go.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Right. Now. Show me what you've got.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Mr Dalliard! Ignore my previous instructions. The UN-inspired
		truce is holding. Sir and I are singing from the same song-
		sheet. Resume your carving. (To Hugh: pointing at piano.) May I
		urge the merits of this particular instrument upon you, sir? It
		is the Toyota Previa of pianos, the Radion Ultra of keyboards.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh looks at it.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Don't be ridiculous. It would never fit her.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	My father's advice, I'll never forget it - neither a borrower,
		nor a git be.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen sits in a leather armchair and addresses the camera, spookily 
	and fast.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Between imagination and desire, between reality and ambition,
		between what is known and what is feared, between purpose and
		despair, between sense and shite, between the visible world and
		the inner world that straddles the curtain hung between what we
		know and what we think we suspect is a dark veil that waves
		gently between the beckoning finger drawing us into the world
		of what could be and what never couldn't be impossible to
		dread. OR DO THEY? Perhaps it isn't. Maybe we were only
		dreaming? Perhaps the answers can be found in that other realm
		that lies between the foundry of the heart and the sweating
		laundry-room of the imagination where the only rhythms are the
		smiles of a forgotten winter and the incessant beating of the
		frightened human thigh that we call "Fear". Or is it? I'm
		Gelliant Gutfright and tonight's tale must give us pause. It is
		called "Flowers For Wendy" but might it rather have been called
		"You Have Been Warned"? No, it might not.
		
	The picture starts to fade.
		
		Andrew Beckett is on his way home from work. A nice young man
		is Andrew Beckett. A kind word for everyone and liked by all
		who come into contact with him.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	We see a smiley Hugh walking along the street. He passes a flower 
	stall, manned by a sinister looking Patrick, with dark glasses and 
	white stick.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(now off) Another hard day's work. Another quiet evening in.
		Perhaps a little television, the crossword. Maybe he'll finally
		get around to cataloguing those ... wait!
		
	Hugh stops and clicks his fingers as he remembers something.
		
		What is he thinking of? Not just another evening, after all.
		It's Wendy's birthday! Dinner at Mario's! But first he
		should ...
		
	Hugh turns and sees the flower stall.
		
		Strange! He's never noticed that stall before. Yet he comes
		home this way every evening ... providential.
		
	Hugh walks towards the flower stall.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	Good evening, Mr Beckett.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(amazed) But that's extraordinary! How on earth do you know
		what time of day it is? You aren't wearing a watch.
"}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	I know many things, Mr Beckett. Would you like to buy some
		flowers for your wife's birthday?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	This is uncanny! Flowers are exactly what I want. How could you
		possibly have known?
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Patrick smiles creepily.'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	How about some roses? All the ladies love a rose.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh looks around. He sees some yellow things.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What are these?
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	Ah. You don't want those, Mr Beckett. Those are special blooms.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	They're rather fine. What are they called?
"}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	Ranunculus pugnans.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	(picking the bunch up) Ranunc ... what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	Commonly known, sir, as Old Man's Wrinkle or the Fighting
		Buttercup.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, I think they're lovely. The smell is ...
		
	Hugh sniffs deeply.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	They didn't get that name by accident, Mr Beckett.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What name?
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	The Fighting Buttercup. They say that the bouquet of this bloom
		will bring out all the anger in a person.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh what nonsense.
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	That's what they say.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Superstitious hooey.
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	No doubt you're right, sir.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Arse-clap.
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	As you say, sir.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Rhino-bollocks. How much are they?
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	Five pounds, sir. But I ...
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh gives him a fiver and stalks off. Patrick watches him go. Hugh 
	knocks over an old woman in the street as he goes.
	   Cut to Hugh tutting as he tries to let himself into the flat. He 
	mutters at the recalcitrance of the key.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(voice-over) Poor Andrew. Poor Wendy. A kind thought for a
		birthday and a simple bunch of flowers. But when your life is a
		perilous yoyo, eaten by Destiny's right hand: when Fate lights
		the cigarette: when Chance plays the trumpet not very well and
		Hazard deals the cards from the bottom of your aunt, then you
		must expect ... the unexpected.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh gives up and smashes the door down.
	   Wendy, played by Caroline, appears worriedly in the hallway.'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	Darling! What ...?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Jesus suffering ARSE! That bloody door.
'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': "
	I don't understand.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Don't understand? Don't understand? What's to understand, you
		hopeless saucer of pus? It's a frig-mothering door and it keeps
		getting vomiting stuck. That's all there is to understand. It's
		not differential calculus.
"}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	Andrew!
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh heaves a colossal punch at her and sends her flying through the 
	banisters which collapse satisfactorily. She lies in a dizzy heap.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Now look what you've done, you pointless tart. You've broken
		the snotting bannisters.
"}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	Andrew ... is something wrong?
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh tuts violently and drops the flowers on her.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm going to get myself a drink. Happy birthday, you saggy old
		bitch.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	He storms off. Caroline looks at the flowers that have dropped on to 
	her chest.'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': "
	They're lovely, darling. Thank you. And they ... (inhaling 
		deeply) ... they smell gorgeous.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	She takes another sniff. Cut to Hugh in the drawing room, pouring 
	himself a drink. The lid on the whisky bottle is tight. This narks 
	Hugh.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Oh, come on. OPEN, you scrotuming dribble of faeces.
		
	The lid opens.
		
		That's better. (Drinks) Oh, that's much better.
		
	Hugh looks at the drink and starts to smile.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Only a door, after all. Not the end of the world. Silly to get
		annoyed about ...
		
	His thoughts are cut off. Wendy suddenly throws an enormous punch at 
	him, sending him miles across the room.
		
		What the ...?
'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	Sorry.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Sorry?
'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': "
	Yes. Sorry I didn't hit you with a sockful of gravel, you
		flabby, drivelling, waste of clothes.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Wendy, darling ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	"Wendy, darling". I'll darling your arse with a rusty lawn-
		sprinkler ...
		
	She punches Hugh again. He gets up, holding his nose.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	What ... what's happened?
"}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': "
	Happened? Nothing's happened that a Swiss Army penknife can't
		sort out. Now why don't you take these bottom-wipingly ugly
		flowers and stick them into your lungs?
		
	Caroline tosses the flowers at Hugh, who looks at them.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	The flowers ... flowers, that's it ... Wendy, listen ... I
		think I know what's happened. What this is all about.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "
	Hugh starts to talk as Stephen's voice comes over. During this, Hugh 
	gets up and starts drawing diagrams on a blackboard to explain his 
	tale."}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	And so, Wendy Beckett sat at her husband's knees and listened
		to a story. A fantastic story. A tale that danced along the
		crumbling brim of credibility, yet never once lost its footing.
		A tale of walking home, and pavements, and forgettings of
		birthdays, and rememberings, and wantings to buy flowerings,
		and discoverings of a flower-stall just at the right
		momentings. And when he was finished, Andrew Beckett took his
		young wife's face in his hands ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Now do you understand, Wendy? Do you see what this is all
		about?
'}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	Oh Andy. I feel such a fool.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I think we've both been a little mad, Wendy. It's not a
		question of blame. What matters now is us. The future.
"}, {'speaker': 'Caroline', 'text': '
	Oh Andy ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh Wendy ...
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	As they embrace, the camera starts to pan off to the waste-paper 
	basket.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A happy ending, you may think. Loose ends tied up, the books
		balanced. And yet ... and yet .. what of our friend the blind
		flower-seller?
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Cut to Patrick selling to another passer-by.'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	Old Man's Wrinkle, madam. Otherwise known as the Fighting
		Buttercup. They do say that the smell of these flowers brings
		out all the anger in a person ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Passer-by', 'text': '
	Really?
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': "
	And then, when they've done that for a bit ... they explode.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "
	There is the sound of a distant explosion, and after a few seconds, a 
	tinkle of broken glass and falling debris. The passer-by doesn't seem 
	to notice."}, {'speaker': 'Passer-by', 'text': '
	How much?
'}, {'speaker': 'Patrick', 'text': '
	To you, madam, nothing.
'}, {'speaker': 'Passer-by', 'text': '
	Oh. Thanks very much.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	She takes them and sniffs deeply. Close-up on Patrick as he starts to 
	cackle fiendishly. We get closer and closer as his laugh gets louder 
	and louder until suddenly, a fist knocks him out of view.
	   Cut to Stephen in his chair.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sleep well. If you can ...
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	In the morning? Oh, I used to use one of those things that
		automatically pour you a cup of tea and make a horrid
		screeching noise in your ear. But she divorced me. Now I use a
		Goblin Teasmade.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(as a woman) Well, I'm aroused every morning by a very insistent cock.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Footage of Formula One cars getting the chequered flag. A sweaty Hugh,
	as a racing driver, is being interviewed by Stephen. Distant sounds of 
	engines and crowds.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Michael, you must be thrilled with that result. Take us through
		the race.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes, well, I was not very happy with the car ... we had a lot
		of problems, the car was not so good, I think, and ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	But you won, it's a great result, you must be very happy.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, we had a lot of problems with the car, and I was not so
		happy, it was very hard ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes but you won ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I won, yes, but there were many, many problems, and it was very
		hard, and difficult, and I was not happy at all with the car...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	But you did actually, can I get this straight, you did actually
		win the race?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	With a lot of problems, yes, I won the race, but it was very
		hard ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Leaving aside how hard it was, are you happy to have won the
		race?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, it was very difficult, you know ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes, presumably it was. Presumably, that's why you get paid
		half a million pounds per race and get as much sex as you can
		eat. My point is, that HAVING won it ... you must be very
		HAPPY. Pleased. Excited. Enchante. Over the frigging moon.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, we had a lot of problems ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	ARE ... YOU ... HAPPY?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Many problems ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	ARE ... YOU ... HAPPY?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	It was very hard ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	ARE ... YOU ... HAPPY?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Difficult ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	ARE ... YOU ... HAPPY?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Proble ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	ARE ... YOU ... ARSING WELL HAPPY, YOU DISMAL, MOANING, FRENCH
		TWAT?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You do a job that half of mankind would kill to be able to do,
		you can go to bed with the other half any time you like, you
		are richer than Croesus, I just need to know if this makes you
		HAPPY?
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Pause.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	We had a lot of problems ...
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Stephen lunges forward and punches Hugh full in the face.'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen M. and Phyllida sit behind a kind of bench as for a tribunal of 
	some kind. Stephen, rat-faced and moustached, is up before them.'}, {'speaker': 'Phyllida', 'text': '
	You are Councillor Kenneth Wade?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I am.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen M.', 'text': '
	I hope you are aware, Councillor Wade, that this is an informal
		hearing?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Indeed. I would like it understood at the outset that I have
		done nothing of which I am ashamed and that I stand by my
		record in local government. Having said that I am very happy to
		co-operate fully with this enquiry and answer such questions as
		might be put.
'}, {'speaker': 'Phyllida', 'text': '
	You were elected to Grangely City Council, Mr Wade, on a ticket
		of ... let me see ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	... on a ticket of providing value for money for our charge-
		paying customers and injecting new standards of decency, honour
		and family values into the community.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen M.', 'text': '
	Fine words, no doubt, Mr Wade. You were, I believe, in charge
		of the "contracting out" of the Council's cleaning services?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Cleansing.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen M.', 'text': '
	I beg your pardon?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Cleansing services. We call them cleansing services, not
		cleaning services.
'}, {'speaker': 'Phyllida', 'text': '
	Why?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Um ... because it annoys people, I suppose.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen M.', 'text': '
	And the company you contracted those cleansing services out to
		was called Wade Cleaning Ltd.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Cleansing. Wade Cleansing. Slogan: we know the Meansing of
		Cleansing.
'}, {'speaker': 'Phyllida', 'text': '
	Wade Cleansing is wholly owned and run by your wife.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	The matter has already been fully investigated by an
		independent enquiry ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen M.', 'text': '
	Yes. Wade Independent Tribunals Ltd.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Certainly. The old publicly-run enquiry procedures were
		expensive and inefficient, we contracted out to Wade
		Independent Tribunals Ltd, who offered a competitive, hard-
		headed, business-orientated tribunal and enquiry service.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen M.', 'text': '
	But which is wholly owned and run by your son, Geoffrey.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	As it happens, yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen M.', 'text': '
	Who is five months old.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Five and a half months old. Geoffrey put together a very
		attractive bid. I was proud of him.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen M.', 'text': "
	Mm. Geoffrey's mother, however, is not your wife, but Miss
		Valerie Jephcott, your secretary.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes. The sexual service my wife was offering was old-
		fashioned, inefficient, unwieldly and ... after my older
		children's birth ... overstreched and with a tendency to too
		much waste. I decided to contract out my sexual requirements,
		open them for competitive tender in the market-place. Valerie
		offered a sexual service that was faster, tighter, more
		efficient, more imaginative and more slimmed down than my
		wife's.
"}, {'speaker': 'Phyllida', 'text': '
	I thought you stood for family values and clean living?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Cleanse living.
'}, {'speaker': 'Phyllida', 'text': '
	Cleanse living. In your electoral literature, for instance, you
		promised to come down hard on homosexuals.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Since I've been in office I have spent a lot of money and
		energy coming down very hard indeed on homosexuals.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen M.', 'text': '
	To return to financial matters, Mr Wade. Do you think it is
		appropriate that in these very lean times for ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	In these very lens times ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen M.', 'text': '
	Whatever. The point is, you have been accused of making a lot
		of money from being a councillor.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes. Well. There you have it: "accused". That's the attitude I
		have to deal with all the time. Making money is a crime,
		something to apologise for. Well, I'm sorry but when I grew up
		"profit" wasn't a dirty word. "Arse" was a dirty word. "Profit"
		wasn't. "Scrotum" was a pretty dirty word too and so was
		"titty". Well, I'm not ashamed to say that I've never been
		afraid of hard graft, sheer bloody graft ... or is "graft" a
		dirty word too, like "botty" and "helmet"?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen M.', 'text': "
	I think we've heard enough, Councillor. This may be an informal
		hearing, but frankly, I'm sure we're agreed ...
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	He cocks his head at Phyllida.'}, {'speaker': 'Phyllida', 'text': "
	No quarrels. It's all there.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen M.', 'text': '
	Yes. Yes. Uh-huh. Good. (To Stephen, solemnly.) Kenneth Wade.
		Your name will now go forward as that of our officially adopted
		Parliamentary Candidate for the Grangely Constituency.
		(Smiles.) Congratulations, Ken.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen comes up for a handshake. We see for the first time that we are 
	in the Meeting Room of the Grangely Conservative Constituency HQ.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen M.', 'text': '
	Long live Britain.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	God Save the Quense.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh is in the studio.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Bit of a surprise piece of news here. We don't normally carry
		news stories, but this one does seem fairly major, and it would
		be silly to ignore it. According to a Reuters news flash, the
		British Government has apparently just been bought by Honda.
		The deal went through in the early hours of this morning, and
		has just been announced by Honda's Group Managing Director,
		Ralph Tokana. According to Reuters, Honda fought off rival bids
		from Unilever and the John Lewis Group, and is believed to have
		paid upwards of four hundred million for the troubled democracy
		giant. I think we have some footage here ...

		Cut to Stephen emerging from a Whitehall building. Cameras and flash 
	bulbs. Hugh in voice-over.
	
		... of ... yes, that's Nigel Pargitter, no relation, Deputy
		Director of the Board of Trade ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	... we believe, very firmly, that this was a fair price, and
		that the British taxpayer has got a good deal here. Honda ...
		may I just finish here? Honda have given us satisfactory
		undertakings to the effect that they will not be making any
		massive changes to the structure of government for at least six
		months, and that their only social alterations will involve
		converting Wales into a seven-million-hole golf course, and
		replacing all the houses and flats in Britain with perspex
		living-pods.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen M.', 'text': '
	Have you tried ...?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes, I've tried one of these pods myself, and it was very ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Phyllida', 'text': '
	What about unemployment?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh what about unemployment? You people, you're obsessed ...
		every time some change comes along, some new idea that might
		really do this country a bit of good, it's the same old "What
		about unemployment?" I mean, change the bleeding record, can't
		you? Yes, there will be some unemployment. Honda have pointed
		out that we really don't need 620 people in the House of
		Commons, for instance. They will be investing in a new, laser-
		guided legislative machine ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen M.', 'text': '
	So there will be no elected body?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh come on! Just rejoice, can't you? It's a compliment: it
		shows that this government, as we've always claimed, is an
		attractive proposition to our customers. This is a good deal
		for Britain, a good deal ...
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Cut back to the studio.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, I think I ought to say at this point, that that was all
		made up. Honda haven't really bought the British Government.
		It's a completely silly idea.
		
	He gets up and runs over to a camera and looms into the lens.
		
		Or is it?
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I said to the Captain, I said you want to watch out for those
		icebergs, because a lot of them are a lot bigger under the
		water than they look on top of the water, but no, he just had
		to plough on, showing off to all the women, so then, obviously,
		wallop. Big hole in the side, went down in under ten minutes.
		Egg on his face, I say.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "
	Hugh and Stephen are sitting in a vet's surgery waiting-room. Stephen 
	has a long-haired dachshund on a lead. Hugh has a basket by him.
	Stephen's character is perfectly horrible in its tweeness."}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Wot'cha-got in there, I wonder?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Cat.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Got a mogs in there, have you? A kitti-puss? Lovely. This is
		Clover, my daxie. I've always had daxies. I like daxies with
		long coaties.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Do you, do you, really? Is that right?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What sort of mog-wog is your pussy-kit? A tabbles, a tom-tom or
		what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Burmese.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A Burmie! I love a Burmie. Boy or girl Burmie?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh God ... male.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(into basket) Hello, Mr Burmie. What's your name?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes, it can't speak actually.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh, but they can understand every word, can't they?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Not much evidence for that.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	My first dax, my first little dax was called Sculley. I named
		him after Hugh Sculley from the Antiques Roadshow. I love that
		programme, don't you?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Pervertedly.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Do you know what I do of a Sunday? After I've taken Clover for
		walkums ... we go walkums after lunch, don't we Clover ... just
		Clover and me and of course my little pooper-scooper, because
		that nasty Parkie man doesn't like to see poochie-poop on his
		best grass, does he?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh Christ ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	We come back and I make myself a cheese and tommy-toe toastie.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Cheese and what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Tommy-toe. Tommy-toe. Tommy-toe.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Tomato.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Tommy-toe. Tommy-toe.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Don't say it again.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I make myself a cheese and tommy-toe toastie, sometimes two
		toasties, and a lovely old muggles of tea and I snudget down in
		time for the Roadshow. I love Sunday afternoonies.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Jesus Christ oh help.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	If it's not the Roadshow, they have the animal programme with
		Desmond.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Desmond Morris.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	We just call him Desmond in our house, cos he's like a friend.
		An old chum. Or there's Masterchef or the Clothsies Show.
		Clover and I love our Sunday afties, don't we Clover?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	So what's wrong with Mr Burmie?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Mr Burmie. Why's he come to see Vettiloo? Got a poorly tums?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Did you just say Vettiloo?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Sore throatie? (Into basket.) What's wrong with Mr Burmie?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I've brought him in to be killed.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Scusie?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	He's got cancer of the liver, so I've brought him in to be put
		to death.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	A pause.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Cancer?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Cancer of the liver?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Cancey-wancey.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh Jesus ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(to the cat) Cancey-diddlies. They going to put you to
		deathies, Mister Burmie? They going to stop your heartipoos
		from going beaty-weat-weat? Are they going to go killichum-
		chums? Put your coldy-woldy body-wods in a holey-ploppy-poo-
		woo?
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "
	The door to the vet's office opens and Phyllida pops her head round."}, {'speaker': 'Phyllida', 'text': '
	Clover?
'}, {'speaker': 'Dachsund', 'text': '
	(looking up) Yeah?
'}, {'speaker': 'Phyllida', 'text': '
	What can I do for you?
'}, {'speaker': 'Dachsund', 'text': "
	(looking at Stephen) I'd like to have him put down, please. As
		soon as possible.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I hate you, I despise you, I loathe you. Everything about you
		DISGUSTS me. Your ears, eyes, nose, mouth, tongue, legs, knees,
		stomach, ribs and bottom make me want to vomit up. You're
		repulsive, loathsome, grotesque and insupportable. I want to
		kill you, I want to twist your nipples off and throw them to
		the dogs. You scum. You low, corrosive lump of fecal horror,
		you maniac bastardly turd. I would rather drink stale urine
		from Norman Fowler's arse-pit than remain one moment more in
		your defiling company. You're filth, you're cack, you're the
		ooze of a burst boil, I abominate you, you towering mound of
		corrupted slime. Your every utterance is like the slithering
		hiss of a fat maggot in the putrid guts of a decomposing rat,
		your face is fouler than the unwiped inner ring of Satan's
		rectum.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Camera widens to show the sweetest, whitest-haired old granny ever 
	seen. She pushes a cream cake towards Stephen.'}, {'speaker': 'Granny', 'text': '
	Have a cream slice, dear.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Thanks.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I went on one of these wild man weekends. You know, reclaim
		one's nature, rediscover the innate masculinity inside me,
		confront the demons and angels of manhood in a wild,
		untrammelled journey of the soul. Bloody nearly froze to death.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Stephen is there. Hugh enters.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Good morning.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I beg your pardon?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I said good morning.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Stephen stands back, ashen-faced.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	At last ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	After all these years ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Sorry ...?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Welcome, comrade. Welcome. Sit down. Rest your weary elbows.
		You'll take a glass of vodka? (Calling.) Mr Dalliard! Break out
		the false passports and the rabbit-skin hats. We are going to
		Moscow.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Moscow?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What news? Comrade Stalin in rude health, I trust?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I'm sorry. I'm not with you. All I said was "good morning".
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Precisely. The code.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Code?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	It is now twenty-seven summers since Comrade Molenski stood
		slightly to the left of where you are now and told me that, one
		day, a man would come into this shop and give notice of his
		alliegance with the phrase "good morning". And that, on hearing
		these words, Mr Dalliard and I were to detonate our relatives
		and fly to Dover.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Fly to Dover?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Where a man called Smith would see us safely on to a goods
		train carrying livestock to Minsk.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Wait a minute. When I said "good morning", all I meant was ...
		good morning.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I mean ... that's all I meant.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ah. In that case, please accept my green felt apologies, and
		allow me to sing the fourth verse of "An English Country
		Garden" omitting the line "Where tom tits dwell" by way of
		recompense.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No, really, don't bother ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Are you quite sure, sir? Mr Dalliard will be happy to accompany
		me on his knees.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Knees?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes, sir. One of the most accomplished knee-players in this
		shop, is Mr Dalliard.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No, that's alright. I just came in here to buy a model.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A model?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A model?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A model?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Pause.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A model?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's right. I want to buy a model.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	With or without plastic struts?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Um ... I'm not really sure. I thought an aeroplane ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Let me ask a different question in the same way. Who is this
		model for?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It's for my son.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Your son?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Just your son?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And when is this "birthday" of his?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Wednesday.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Yes, that's what I said. When's the day?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Wednesday.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Are you stupid or just plain deaf?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Wednesday.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(overcome with embarrassment) Oh, you are genuinely stupid. I'm
		so sorry. I thought you were just being deaf. Mr Dalliard,
		command the earth to swallow me up. I'm so sorry, life must be
		hard enough for stupid people without tactless old bastards
		like that lady over there rubbing it in with salt in your face
		widely. Mr Dalliard, I've gone peculiar.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh looks round.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What lady?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	So. In plain-flavoured English. When ... is ... your ... son's
		birthday?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	W ... the day after Tuesday.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	The day after Tuesday. Doctors are so specific these days,
		aren't they? And are you expecting him to be a boy or a girl?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It's my son. He's nine. It'll be his tenth birthday.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	His tenth? Sir, you're spoiling him. I was only ever allowed
		one. On my birthday, usually. However. No doubt you know your
		own business best. Just don't come bleating to Mr Dalliard and
		me if this over-indulged child grows up to be one of those
		drug jockeys that you're always reading about on television. A
		glass of water?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No thank you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A cup of water?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A plate of water, then?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Thank you, no. Just a model aeroplane.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A model aeroplane of water?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No. Forget the water. I don't want any water. Just the model
		aeroplane kit. I thought perhaps that Messerschmitt 109E in the
		window.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	The Messerschmitt 109E in the window.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes please.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	(with his hand on his head) Fizzy or still?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	That doesn't count. I had my hand on my head. You must ignore
		anything I say with my hand on my head.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Oh.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So, the Messerschmitt 109E. Sir has a wonderful eye.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Thank you.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So blue. The ear is a disappointment. Not blue at all. I have a
		little tin of Humbrol paint in cobalt blue ... perhaps you
		would allow me to ...?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	No thank you. Just the model and I suppose some glue.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh dear. Glue. So your son is already a drug jockey. Mr
		Dalliard and I warned you on bended legs, but would you listen?
		No. And now look at him.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen gets from under the counter a beautifully finished and painted 
	model of a Messerschmitt and a plastic bag with glue smeared inside it.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	What's this?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A Messerschmitt 109E and a fix for your degenerate junkie of a
		son, sir.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	But the model's done.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sir?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	It's ready assembled.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You can't expect us to do all the work ourselves, sir. The
		whole joy of modelling lies in carefully scraping off the
		paint, soaking off the transfers and taking the plane apart
		piece by piece, and putting each of the pieces into a little
		plastic bag which is then sealed and placed inside the box.
		Something to be proud of. An achievement. Strange words in
		these days of Supersonic Hedgehog brothers and ready-sliced
		golf-shots.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Alright. Forget it. Just forget it. I'll go somewhere else.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Mr Dalliard has a gun trained on you through the curtains. If
		you take so much as one step towards that door, sir, he will,
		at a word from me, shoot you clean through the head with as
		much pity as if you were a helpless seal-pup called Arnold.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	WHAT?
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Stephen indicates to show that his hand is on his head.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	So sorry that we couldn't help you, sir. We try to accomodate
		our customers, but not being a hotel we find it almost
		impossible.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes. Well. This hasn't been a very good morning.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Good morning! Mr Dalliard! We have been activated. After all
		these years.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	You know that historian, David Irving? He doesn't exist.
		Completely made up.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen addresses the camera in his normal clobber.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Hello, I'm Oprah Winfrey. Today we're looking at self-esteem,
		what is it, do we have enough, where can we get more if we need
		it? With me is Louella Della Twee, author of I Think I'm Great:
		Why Don't You?

		Cut wider to include Hugh, lolling in a chair in extravagant garb.
		
		Louella, first of all, have you got self-esteem?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No. I don't have it. Don't ask me why.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh. Alright.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	God knows I should have it.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Really?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm an intelligent, beautiful, warm, loving, funny, sexy, rich,
		almighty heap of a woman. The only thing I don't have is self-
		esteem.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	That's a bugger, isn't it? Now your book contains several uses
		of the word "me".
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I would agree with that.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	If ...?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	If what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	You would agree with that if ...?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	If I had enough self-esteem.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I see. No, what I was going to say was the first chapter
		contains nothing but the word "me". You have written the word
		"me" 3,416 times.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Seventeen.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Is it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	The chapter is called "me".
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So it is. Now, can I ask you this question. Why?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Why me?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Precisely.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I don't love myself any more. I used to love myself when I was
		a kid, but then I stopped. I stopped talking to myself, seeing
		myself for what I really am. I took myself for granted.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Let's have a pointless round of applause there.
		
	Applause.
		
		So what did you do?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I confronted myself. I waited till I got home one day, and I
		said to myself, what are you doing?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	How unbearably tense. And how did you answer yourself?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I shifted around, started blaming all kinds of things, then
		eventually I had to admit to myself that yes, I was sleeping
		with someone else.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Had you suspected this?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I knew. I knew all along. I just didn't want to face it. It was
		the deceit. But then I realised that the only person I was
		really deceiving was myself.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I don't think I've ever been more emotionally knotted-up than I
		am at this moment. Yes, madam?
		
	Phyllida stands up in the audience.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Phyllida', 'text': '
	I just wanted to ask Louella where she gets her strength from?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Louella, lady wants to know where the mascara arse you get your
		strength from?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Can I answer that with a question?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Can she?
'}, {'speaker': 'Phyllida', 'text': "
	I'd like that.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	She'd like that.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I want you to do something for me. I want you to stand in front
		of a mirror, take your clothes off, every shred ...
		
	Laughter from the audience.
		
		Hey, no. I'm serious, why not? You're you. I want you to stand
		naked in front of that mirror and I want you to say "I like me
		just the way I am. I like my fat hips, and my lisp and my
		whining aggression. I love the fact that I'm neurotic. I'm
		happy that I demand the world's respect without having to earn
		it. I'm me, I'm special, I'm kinda crazy about me just the way
		I am." Would you do that for me?
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Wild applause from the audience.
	   Another woman gets up.'}, {'speaker': 'Woman', 'text': "
	Can I ask Louella something with a question? I have high self-
		esteem. It's ruining my life. I'm the only person I know with
		high self-esteem. It's terrible. I feel like I'm missing out.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Honey, you've just got to learn to lower your self-esteem. Try
		and make up some story about being maybe abused as a child.
		Pretend your husband doesn't appreciate how artistic and
		special and interesting you are. It'll come.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Applause.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	We've got a vomit break right now. Don't go away.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh is supervising the gathering of thirty or so six-year-olds.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(voice-over) Tony Racklin is headmaster of Lannark Primary
		School in Thurlow. The school has eighty-four pupils, of mixed
		race, religion, gender and shoe size. So how does he deal with
		religious instruction at the school's morning assembly?
		
	Hugh sits at the piano and plays. The children vaguely join in.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	We worship you oh God or Gods,
		Whoever you may be,
		We realise that you operate
		Supernaturally,
		We thank you for the birds and bees,
		For creatures live or dead,
		But if you actually don't exist,
		Please ignore what we've just said,
		Aaaaaaaaaa
		Cut to Hugh in interview.
		What I've tried to do, what we've tried to do, I should say, is
		develop a religious agenda that serves the needs of the kids in
		a real sense. You must understand that we have here Muslim
		kids, Hindu kids, Christian kids, Jewish kids, atheistic kids,
		agnostic kids. What they've all got in common is that they're
		all ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Kids?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Exactly. That's very important. And therefore, the religious
		package we offer must take account of all those different
		elements under the over-arching umbrella of basic caring.
		
	Stephen, listening to this, turns out of shot and vomits quite noisily.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Sorry ... don't know what happened there ... so how have you
		done that? How have you accommodated these different ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	What I've done, what WE'VE done, I should say, is sweep away
		all the old divisions and invent a new religion.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A new religion?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's right. It's a kind of religious Esperanto, if you like.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Nope. Don't think I do ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	We've called this religion Lip Wip Wip Wip.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Lip Wip Wip Wip. Now is that the name of the God ...?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	There is no one, single God in Lip Wip Wip Wip.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It's a pantheon, is it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I call it a committee of Gods. There are eight voting members
		and a non-executive chair who rotates every four years.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So what form does the worship take? What do you actually
		worship?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	We worship air ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Air, right ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And flexible work-share schemes ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Aha ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And anything that has a rounded corner on it.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Why rounded corners?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, they're a very important symbol in Lip Wip Wip Wip. The
		kids here worship the one on the edge of the activity table in
		our art room ...
		
	Close-up of worktop. Pull out to see kids chanting at it.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And what do rounded corners symbolise in Lip Wip Wip?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Er ... the roundedness of things generally. The fact that
		you're much less likely to hurt yourself on round things or get
		things snagged on them. We prefer them to have a stain-
		resistant wipe-free surface, ideally. Every Farkling we place
		large potato prints ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sorry, every Farkling?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Yes. Farkling is our equivalent of, oh, Christmas, Ramadan,
		Passover ... what you will. It's our major festival. We have it
		at the beginning of January so that parents can take advantage
		of the January sales when buying presents. It's traditional on
		Farkling Eve to place potato-printed pictures on a rounded-
		cornered surface overnight.
		
	We see kids doing so - looking frankly pissed off.
		
		Then, when the kids come down they find they've been marked out
		of ten by Parent Farkling.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Parent Farkling?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes ... a sort of Father Christmas figure, but eitherly
		gendered.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	And instead of leaving filled stockings or something similar,
		they mark a potato-print picture out of ten?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes - but of course, traditionally, every kid always gets ten.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Bloody hell. You say "traditionally", how long in fact has Lip
		Wip Wip Wip been a religion?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well, the religion arose out of some very exciting discussions
		we had during a level two resource allocation module steering
		committee meeting that the trust held last week ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	It's alright, I'm controlling myself. So, would you say the
		religion has been a success so far?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Well, I'll be as frank as I can. There have been problems, I'm
		afraid.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Mm. Just yesterday one of the kids in Mrs Tremloe's 2acvaw.xp5
		class, Tristram, formed a sect that decided to worship oblong
		surfaces.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh dear.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "
	Cut to Hugh, sitting on the desk in the class-room with a small child 
	stretched out on a torturer's rack. Hugh gives a turn of the wheel."}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Now, come on Tris. I'm very disappointed. What are you?
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Tris wails. Hugh turns the wheel again.'}, {'speaker': 'Tristram', 'text': "
	I'm a heretic.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's better. So, kids. What do you reckon we should do about
		that? Any thoughts?
"}, {'speaker': 'Kids', 'text': '
	Burn him! Burn the heretic! Torch him!
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	OK. That's agreed then. We'll burn you at the stake in the
		playground during break, Tris. Now. Anna. What's this about you
		being a witch?
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Cut back to Hugh and Stephen.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Early days yet, but we're hoping to iron out some of these
		teething snags pretty soon and get a permanent dungeon in the
		old chapel.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': "
	Robert and Jeanine are facing each other across a boardroom table. Hugh 
	is at Jeanine's side, Stephen at Robert's. Stephen and Hugh are opening 
	briefcases and setting up their stall."}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right, Richard, are you going to start?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Probably better if I start, Nick, yes. Thrash out the position
		in broad terms, so we all know where we stand.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	That's got to be the right course, Richard. Got to be.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	I think so, Nick, I really do.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Go you on ahead.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Position is that my client wishes, in very broad terms ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Broad terms?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	At this stage broad terms, yes, we can talk specifics later, my
		client wishes to engage in a protracted bout of sexual
		intercourse with your client.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Can I chip in here, Richard?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Chip in, chip in ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Might save us a lot of time if I just say that my client is
		willing to consider your client's position in a favourable
		light, as long as we can thrash out some of the nitty-gritty.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh, that's good news.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	So, shall we pencil a meeting, Richard, or ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	We could pencil a meeting, certainly, Nick, but I should say
		that my client is anxious to expedite matters and bring them to
		a speedy conclusion if at all possible.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	How speedy, Richard?
		
	Stephen turns and mutters to Robert.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	My client was thinking along the lines of the next half-hour,
		Nick. I don't know how that sounds ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Ah.
		
	Hugh confers with Jeanine.
		
		My client, Richard, would like it clearly understood that she's
		not easy.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	My client clearly understands that your client is not easy,
		Nick, in fact he wishes me to stress that he has an enormous
		respect for your client in a variety of personal, non-sexual
		ways.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	My client is reassured by your client's position, and would
		like to know how your client intends to proceed.
		
	Stephen and Robert mutter.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	My client was thinking in general terms of dinner at the Bombay
		Brasserie, after which, at some mutually agreeable time, he
		would place his tongue inside your client's mouth and move it
		around slightly.
		
	Hugh and Jeanine confer.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	That is broadly acceptable to my client.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	My client then suggests putting one of his hands up your
		client's skirt and having a bit of a feel.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Which hand, Richard?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	My client hasn't yet decided which hand ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Well perhaps you could fax us with that ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Certainly, that's no bother ...
		
	He makes a note.
		
		"Fax Nick ... Which ... hand ... up ... skirt ..."
		
	Hugh and Jeanine have been conferring.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I should say that after your client has put his hand up my
		client's skirt, my client reserves the right to moan slightly.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I don't see a problem there ...?
		
	Robert shakes his head.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	No, that's fine.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	At this point, my client will suggest that your client drives
		my client back to your client's flat, where your client will
		play some James Taylor.
		
	Stephen and Robert mutter.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	My client doesn't have any James Taylor at the moment, and
		wonders whether Art Garfunkel would be acceptable?
		
	Jeanine scribbles a note and pushes it across to Hugh.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Ah. My client insists that Art Garfunkel is definitely not
		acceptable, but would be prepared to consider Tom Waits.
		
	Robert nods.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Excellent. Moving on, my client would now like to insert ...
		
	Robert whispers something.
		
		Would now like to insert a clause allowing him to spill wine on
		your client's blouse and to mop it gently with a handkerchief,
		lightly brushing your client's breasts as he does so.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	We feel, in the interests of both parties, that a white wine
		spritzer should be specified.
		
	Robert nods.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A white wine spritzer it is. Now my client is keen to know
		whether your client can accomodate ... (Robert whispers)
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	My client is keen to know whether your client can accomodate
		a circular licking motion around the upper body area at this
		stage.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Perfectly acceptable. My client will be permitted to gaze at
		the ceiling and say the words "Oh God" and "Yes."
		
	Stephen writes down and mouths "Oh God" and "Yes" as Robert nods 
	briskly.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	A move to the bedroom is now indicated.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Indeed, I should point out, however, that my client is keen
		that this engagement should run along orthodox lines from
		hereonin.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Would that preclude the use of salad items?
		
	Firm nod from Jeanine.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm afraid so.
		
	Robert slightly disappointed.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	My client believes in that case that things can be
		satisfactorily brought to a conclusion in three minutes, after
		which time ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	My client feels that this would be premature. Ten minutes is
		more acceptable.
		
	Robert looks aghast and swallows slightly.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Shall we compromise with six?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Six minutes then. I assume your client will then roll over and
		turn his back on my client?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	My client will most certainly do so. Your client will attempt
		to hold him and he will behave coldly.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Quite so. My client will feel spurned and shamed as your client
		refuses to share the afterglow.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	My client then plans to sneak into his clothes at five in the
		morning and go very early to work, leaving no note for your
		client.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	My client will feel immensely rejected and angry at this.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Quite so. My client will pick up the phone once during the
		afternoon, but fail to go through with calling, after which
		time he will not be in touch again.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	My client will from hereonin refer to your client as "that
		bastard".
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	My client will blush and look away if ever he sees your client
		at a party.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Precisely so. I think that's all satisfactory.
		
	Robert and Jeanine both nod. Robert looks guilty, Jeanine looks cross.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	If your client will sign here ...
		
	Passes over contract.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And yours here ...
		
	They each sign.
		
		Excellent.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	First-rate.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Robert and Jeanine stand. From across the table Jeanine slaps Robert in 
	the face.'}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Bastard.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	She storms out. Robert shuffles out through the other door.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Marvellous.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Splendid.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Pause.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Fancy a quick shag?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh alright.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'A bedroom. Hugh is playing a video game, sullen teenager-wise. Stephen enters.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Terry. Got a moment?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Do you have a window in your packed schedule? If so, could you
		open the curtains and let me look through? Just for a moment.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yeah.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Good. Now Terry. School. I've had Mr Stroke on the phone,
		asking where you've been. He says you didn't turn up today.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	So?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So why not?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	'S boring.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	How would you know that, Terry? According to Mr Stroke, you
		haven't been to school for nearly four years.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	So?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So? So? So? So what have you been doing? What the hell have you
		been doing for the last four years?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I've got to level nine.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Level nine? What do you mean, level nine?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Level nine. Top level.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	But school, Terry. Improvement. Learning. Discovery. Growth.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	What's the point?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	What's the point? What do you mean, what's the point?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	There's no point.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	There doesn't have to be a point, you blithering twerp. School
		is school. What's the point of ear lobes? What's the point of
		fabric conditioner, or tag wrestling, or butterfly-shaped
		pasta?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	School's boring.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes? Your point being?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I don't want to go to school, cos it's boring.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You don't want? You don't want? And who, please be good enough
		to tell me, is supposed to give an electrically operated shag
		about what you want? Hmm? Hmmm? Hmmmmm?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Just leave me alone, can't you?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Leave you alone? Leave you alone? Why the hell should I leave
		you alone? Are you making a cheese sauce? Working on a cure for
		cancer? An oboe concerto is starting to take shape in your
		mind? What?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm on level nine.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Bugger level nine. Bugger up the arse of level nine with an
		anglepoise lamp. I'm talking about your life.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	What about it?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Never mind what about it? What IS it, Terry? What the hell is
		your life? Tell me what your life is.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	What's yours?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	What do you mean, what's mine?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	What's your life?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	My life. My life. My life is about work, dedication, energy.
		Thirty-three bloody years with Russell and Bromley, that's
		what. My life is about having you. I had you, didn't I? That
		was supposed to be a good thing.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I didn't ask to be born.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You didn't ask to be born. Judas Priest on a two-stroke
		moped ... what is that supposed to mean? Hm? What does that
		mean, you didn't ask to be born? You'd rather be dead, would
		you?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Maybe.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Maybe? Maybe? Maybe? Maybe? I mean ... what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I've thought about it.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	About killing yourself?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Yeah.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Well, what's stopped you? Couldn't be bothered, I suppose.
		Couldn't be bothered to go down to the kitchen and get a knife
		out of the drawer.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	I wanted to get to level nine.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	You've got to level nine, for crying out loud from the bloody
		roof-tops. You're at level nine now.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Right.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Right.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	So when I finish this game, I'm going to top myself.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh great. As long as I know. I'll go and book the bloody
		headstone now then. "Here lies Terry Gardner, he got to level
		bloody nine." Care for some singing cherubs round it, or do you
		want it plain?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Bingo. Done it.
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh throws down the video game.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	So. Knife, or out the window?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Knife, I think.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Knife, good.
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh goes out. Stephen listens for a moment, then picks up the video 
	game.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	About bloody time.
'}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Stephen and Hugh are there.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Ladies and gentlemen, bit of a shadow has been cast over the
		show this week. Hugh has received a death threat.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	That's right.
		
	He holds up a letter.
		
		I got this letter this morning, addressed to "Dear Sir or
		Madam, you are a cow son bastard sucking mental, you die
		heavily in wet throat ripping everywhere, don't like the Queen
		this country, for tear out lungs and replace with portable
		clothes, brackets yes please brackets, National Service who is
		she, stripping scrotum through eary leery pastures of deep
		smell." Pretty upsetting, as you can imagine.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(taking the letter) I've tried to persuade Hugh to take this
		threat seriously, but he insists on carrying on as if nothing
		had happened.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	If you give in to these people then ... you've given in.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	At the very least, Hugh, I don't think it's safe for you to do
		your song tonight.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	No. If I don't do the song then he's won and democracy might as
		well take an early shower.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	But (looking at the letter, trying to make out the handwriting)
                this ... whoever this is, this "M. Pontillo" might be in the
		audience tonight, armed.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	One has to make a stand.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I think we would all understand if we skipped your song
		tonight. This Pontillo is probably lurking in the piano, with a
		mobile rocket launcher. M'colleague, listen to me, YOU MUST NOT
		SING TONIGHT.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I know you mean well, m'colleague, but my face is made up. For
		evil to flourish it only needs the good man to spout cliches.
		I'm going on.
		
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh moves towards the singing area.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Ladies and gentlemen, m'colleague will now bravely entertain us
		with a young song. (Ripping up letter: sotto voce.) Well,
		that's thirty pence postage and package down the drain.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh strums a guitar and blows a harmonica. Then ...'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	The poor keep gettin' hungry,
		The rich keep gettin' fat,
		Politicians change,
		But they're never gonn' change that,
		But you an' me girl,
		We got the answer right in our hands,
		All we gotta do is ...
		
	Mumbles feebly.
		
		The winds of war are blowin'
		And the tide is comin' in,
		Don't you be hopin' for the good times,
		Because the good times have already been,
		But girl, we got the answer,
		So easy you won't believe,
		All we gotta do is ...
		
	Mumbles.
		
		It's so easy to see,
		If only they'd listen to you and me,
		We got to ...
		As fast as we can,
		We got to ...
		Every woman every man,
		We got to ...
		Time after time,
		We got to ...
		... dka and lime ...
		
		The world is gettin' weary,
		And it wants to go to bed,
		Everybody's dyin',
		'Cept the ones that are already dead,
		But girl, we got the answer,
		It's starin' us right in the face
		All we gotta do is ...
		
	Long pause. Then he goes back to the opening harmonica riff. Fade out.
	
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Stephen, in huge close-up, monologises at really quite ripsnortingly immense speed.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	When I was seventeen I had already tried fourteen different
		jobs, married twice, fathered many many many children, eaten a
		perfectly enormous quantity of food over a long time period,
		been weaned off six types of class A dangerous drugs, given up
		smoking, taken it up again, given it up again, taken it up
		again, given taking it up and taken giving it up again and
		again and again. By the time I was twenty, alcohol had never
		passed my lips, yet I was a reckless and predatory alcoholic:
		my life was in pieces, my marriages were shattered, my children
		lay in ruins, my coffee was tasting incredibily bitter, I was
		paying alimony along the sinuses, behind the dark interior
		passages of the skull and through the nose. Nothing smelt felt
		dealt me right. My friends, ha! Friends? Friends, more like. My
		friends shunned me as you might shun a cigarette lighter or a
		brown caravan. In my twenty-fourth year I had increasing
		problems coping with live music. I lost my sense of utterness,
		and all feeling and movement in both testicles. Testicles? Did
		I say testicles? Testicles, more like. Rashes came and went:
		more wives, more children. My first daughter was severalteen by
		this time and inclined to chat. Nothing, nothing had prepared
		me for this. Life, they call it. Life? Life? Life? A living
		life, I called it. Desire, mood, memory, heat, sweat, effort,
		power, diction and a great quadratic equation of violent
		wanting, needing and rinsing. Words tumbled from me then as I
		knew that the answer lay, not in poetry, not in music, art,
		sculpture, drama, dance or investment analysis. The answer lay
		in a new way. A new way on. Some infection gripped me by the
		kidneys and said "a new way, Randall, a new way". So still
		barely twenty-five and three-quarters I rode that mountain, I
		trod that vineyard, I slept that great sleep of destiny, I
		danced to that music of memory and pogoed my soul to the insane
		rhythms of the heart's mind's vapid texture of journeys.
		Journeys? Gurneys more like. No, journeys, I was right. Still
		the fat gathered to my sinews and the corpuscles sang in my
		veins. Answers? No answers: fate had dealt me a dog turd and I
		read it as a full house. No answers, just the dead timing of
		those twin tomb-black, doom-muffled husbands of decay,
		Bitterness and Rice. But then, then: opportunity knocked once
		for no, twice for yes. The labial seam of lead-grey cloud
		opened its fiery slit and showed me one glimpse, one escape,
		one chance to cut and run and never look back, no not once,
		just run, dead-run, blind-run. Fortune shat gold and told me
		under whose pillow to hide it. No wives now, no children, they
		had all grown up, got married themselves, got safe oh-so-
		spittingly-secure jobs and retired to golf-villas in the
		Algarve with beige cardigans, Beefeater and slimline and
		heavily descended testicles. But at thirty, that chance, that
		chance to ... is "redeem" the right word? That chance to redeem
		a bin-liner of broken shards and sworn devices. If I didn't
		take that chance what would I be? What would I become? Just
		another friendless acid spot on the back buttock of a weeping
		society. So I took it, took the chance, picked up the ball and
		ran, went for it, threw caution to the teeth of the gale, never
		look back, just keep running, I did it. Forget the past,
		there's nothing there, not even memories, just a road you never
		travelled unwinding backwards to a place you never came from...

		Hugh enters behind Stephen, looking worried.

		... where fruit grows on trees you never climbed, in an orchard
		where you lost your virginity to a boy called Timothy who died
		of Horlicks poisoning before you were born. No answers there. I
		went on. I ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Stephen?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Lie down for a while.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	OK.
'}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(as a woman) I've got three. Amanda, Lucy and little Emma. Just
		the three: I'm a busy woman, I think three lesbian lovers is
		plenty.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen and Robert hover over a Whitehall desk. The door opens and Hugh 
	enters.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Peter. Glad you could join us. You know Admiral Farquharson, I
		believe.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Admiral.
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	Good afternoon, Peter. How's the model coming along?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Getting there.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Model? Something I should know?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	Last time Peter and I worked together, he was building a model.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Really? What of?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I'm making a box of matches out of bits of old warship.
"}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	Surprising, wouldn't you say? Man like that.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I gave up being surprised by Peter Haggard a long time ago.
		
	Stephen and Robert chuckle.
		
		Now then, Peter, I expect you're wondering what all this is
		about?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	With respect, Sir, I'm not paid to wonder. I'm paid to do.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	But one of the things you do, surely, is wonder. Isn't it?
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	Wondering is a luxury I can't afford.
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Really?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	May I, Sir Richard?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Of course.
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	We have a problem, Peter. A sticky one.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Is there another kind?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Oh yes, I should say so ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	Sir Richard ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Sorry.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Robert opens a drawer and pulls out a stapler.'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	Ever seen one of these before, Peter?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	A stapler.
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	Yes?
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh picks up the stapler and hefts it.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Rexel Taurus. 56 half-inch staples. Comes in black, red or blue.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Hah. I told you he was good.
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	No. I told you he was good.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Did you?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	I assume there's a point to all of this?
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	Oh there's a point, alright.
"}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	If it came to it, Peter, and I'm not saying it will, I'm
		saying if...
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Understood.
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	Do you think you could use one of these?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	You mean ...?
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I think you know what the Admiral is saying, Peter. He's asking
		you whether you'd be prepared to staple two pieces of paper
		together.
"}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	If it came to it. And I'm not saying it will ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	He's not saying it will. He's saying if ...
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh looks at the stapler.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Been a long time.
'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Been a long time for all of us, Peter. Too long, I sometimes
		think.
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	And if I say no? Turn round and walk out of here, pretend none
		of this ever happened?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	That is of course your right. Nobody is ordering you to do this
		thing.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh chews his lip.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	What say you, Peter? Give it a go?
'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	And the pieces of paper? I'm not saying I'll do it, but if ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	Sir Richard and I understand perfectly. Over there.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Robert points to a side table and Hugh picks up two pieces of paper.
	Robert is about to say something, but Stephen stops him.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	(sotto voce) If he does it, it'll be his decision. You don't
		push a man like Peter Haggard.
"}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	You're right, of course.
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Hugh lines up the pieces of paper and picks up the stapler. He looks 
	into the distance. We superimpose shots of a woman running, explosions,
	laughing children, searchlights. Then come back to Hugh for a moment of 
	indecision; he slides the stapler over the paper, grits his teeth and 
	snaps it shut.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': '
	Good man, Peter.
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	Thank you, Peter. That's not just from us. The nation thanks
		you.
"}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'Hugh smiles.'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': '
	Any time.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': 'He goes out.'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	Thank God he's on our side.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	I have an old tape of Carlo Maria Giulini conducting the Vienna
		Philharmonic in a perfectly transcendent version of Schubert's
		seventh symphony. I've rigged it up so that at exactly half
		past seven every morning it falls from the ceiling on to my
		face.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	(as a woman) I haven't got an alarm clock, I've got three
		children instead. It was a difficult choice, but I thought the
		children would go better with the wallpaper.
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Jeanine is behind the counter of a Dixons or similar enshoppment.
	Robert enters.'}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Good morning, sir.
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	Morning. I'd like to speak to someone about a refund, please.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	Oh I see. I have an appliance, bought from this shop, and it's
		sort of broken. So ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Oh dear. What is the appliance, sir?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	It's a time machine.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	A what?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	A time machine. Panasonic. KL 500.
'}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	You bought a time machine in this shop, sir?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	Well, I didn't. My niece did.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	I see. When was this, sir?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	July '97.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': "
	Right. And there's something wrong with it, is there?
"}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	Well yes, I set it to go back to October 5th, 1970, because I
		wanted to see the last ever Janice Joplin concert, and it broke
		down. I don't know why ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	You travelled back in time from 1997.
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	'98. I left it in its box for six months because I didn't have
		an adaptor.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Aha. Have you got the receipt?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	'Fraid not. It was a present from ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Your niece, right. Has she got the receipt?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	Doubt it. She hasn't been born yet.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': "
	Hhhmm. Tricky. Er ... how much did she pay for this machine, if
		you don't mind me asking?
"}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	Will she pay?
'}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Will she pay?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	99.99.
'}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Cheap for a time machine.
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	Not if it doesn't work.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': "
	No, of course not. I'm going to talk to the manager, if you
		don't mind waiting.
"}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	Not at all.
		
'}, {'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Jeanine departs and Robert fiddles with gadgets: Jeanine comes back.'}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Good morning, sir.
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	Morning. I'd like to speak to someone about a refund, please.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	Yes.
'}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Yes?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	Oh I see. I have an appliance, bought from this shop ... you
		see, it's done it again.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Done what again?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	It's sticking. It keeps sticking, for some reason ...
"}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	What does?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	The time machine.
'}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Time machine?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	Yes. My niece is going to give me this time machine, but it's
		not going to work properly, so I'd like a refund.
"}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Are you alright?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	Perfectly. But the time machine keeps sticking, you see ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Are you alright?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': '
	Perfectly. But the time machine keeps sticking, you see ...
'}, {'speaker': 'Jeanine', 'text': '
	Are you alright?
'}, {'speaker': 'Robert', 'text': "
	No, I'm insane.
"}, {'speaker': None, 'text': 'Vox Pop'}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
	My favourite film? What's that one where Julia Roberts plays a
		convent-school fifth-former who comes round to my house and
		mistakes my face for a chair? Or did I make that one up?
"}]

[{'speaker': 'direction', 'text': '
	Stephen addresses the camera while Hugh lets his fingers lightly dance
	on the keys of the old pianner.'}, {'speaker': 'Stephen', 'text': "
	M'colleague, m'colleague ... what a melancholy occasion is
		this.
"}, {'speaker': 'Hugh', 'text': "
